Smokingmeat ID section step
Smokingmeat ID section step
4c6790a0-e7b0-4cfe-b5b5-a6b3ab79e2e5 Make the Brine Make a brine using ½ gallon of cold water, ½ cup of coarse kosher salt, and ½ cup brown sugar (the brown sugar adds some flavor but is optional).
4c6790a0-e7b0-4cfe-b5b5-a6b3ab79e2e5 Make the Brine Pour the salt and brown sugar into the water and stir for about a minute or until the water becomes a clear amber color.
4c6790a0-e7b0-4cfe-b5b5-a6b3ab79e2e5 Brine the Chicken Place the tenderloins into a medium sized plastic/glass container.
4c6790a0-e7b0-4cfe-b5b5-a6b3ab79e2e5 Brine the Chicken Pour the brine over the chicken to cover.
4c6790a0-e7b0-4cfe-b5b5-a6b3ab79e2e5 Brine the Chicken Lid it and place in the fridge for about 60-90 minutes. 60 minutes will do the trick if you're in a hurry.
4c6790a0-e7b0-4cfe-b5b5-a6b3ab79e2e5 Brine the Chicken When the brining process is complete, rinse the chicken one time in cold water.
4c6790a0-e7b0-4cfe-b5b5-a6b3ab79e2e5 Seasoning Lay the brined chicken out on a pan/rack if you have one otherwise you can just lay them out on parchment paper or a large sheet of foil.
4c6790a0-e7b0-4cfe-b5b5-a6b3ab79e2e5 Seasoning Lightly sprinkle my Texas style rub on the top of the chicken.
4c6790a0-e7b0-4cfe-b5b5-a6b3ab79e2e5 Smoke ‘Em Set up your smoker for cooking at 225-240°F and if your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up. I used a mix of hickory and cherry. Should take 80-90 minutes to reach 155-160°F.
4c6790a0-e7b0-4cfe-b5b5-a6b3ab79e2e5 Quick Sear When the chicken reaches about 135°F, if you have a griddle or a hot pan, throw them chicken tenderloins in and give them a quick sear on both sides.
4c6790a0-e7b0-4cfe-b5b5-a6b3ab79e2e5 Quick Sear When they reach anywhere between 155 and 160°F, place them in a covered foil pan to keep them hot as they get finished.
4c6790a0-e7b0-4cfe-b5b5-a6b3ab79e2e5 Finish and Serve Bring into the house and serve them up with some sides or use them to make an amazing sandwich with melted cheese, veggies and condiments.
fea4bf1b-b1be-4fa6-99cf-da5b54985bf5 Slice Slice the rack of lamb into individual chops
fea4bf1b-b1be-4fa6-99cf-da5b54985bf5 Dry Brine Sprinkle a pinch of coarse kosher salt onto the top side of each chop. Place pan of chops into fridge for at least 2 hours or overnight. No need to rinse when finished.
fea4bf1b-b1be-4fa6-99cf-da5b54985bf5 Glaze and Season Make a glaze using 3/4 cup of Jeff's barbecue sauce, 1/2 cup balsamic vinegar, 3 TBS of A1 sauce.
fea4bf1b-b1be-4fa6-99cf-da5b54985bf5 Glaze and Season Brush the top side of each chop with the glaze.
fea4bf1b-b1be-4fa6-99cf-da5b54985bf5 Glaze and Season Sprinkle the top of each chop with Jeff's Texas style rub.
fea4bf1b-b1be-4fa6-99cf-da5b54985bf5 Smoke Set up your smoker for cooking at 220℉ using indirect heat. If your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up.
fea4bf1b-b1be-4fa6-99cf-da5b54985bf5 Smoke I recommend oak for smoke wood if you have some, otherwise use whatever smoking wood you have available.
fea4bf1b-b1be-4fa6-99cf-da5b54985bf5 Smoke Smoke cook chops for about 25-30 minutes or until they reach medium rare (128-130℉).
fea4bf1b-b1be-4fa6-99cf-da5b54985bf5 Smoke Rest for 10 minutes under foil before searing.
fea4bf1b-b1be-4fa6-99cf-da5b54985bf5 Sear Use a griddle, hot pan, hot grill or broiler to quickly sear the top and bottom sides of the lamb chops.
fea4bf1b-b1be-4fa6-99cf-da5b54985bf5 Finish and Serve Keep warm until serving time. Enjoy!
6a80ebd5-6e56-423a-937d-8c5f36fcfeb1 Prepare Jalapenos Cut peppers in half lengthwise leaving part of the stem on each piece.
6a80ebd5-6e56-423a-937d-8c5f36fcfeb1 Prepare Jalapenos Scrape out/remove the seeds and white parts inside the jalapenos
6a80ebd5-6e56-423a-937d-8c5f36fcfeb1 Stuff Peppers Use storebought or homemade pimento cheese to stuff peppers full and slightly heaped up.
6a80ebd5-6e56-423a-937d-8c5f36fcfeb1 Wrap with Bacon Cut the bacon slices in half and wrap a half piece around each pepper.
6a80ebd5-6e56-423a-937d-8c5f36fcfeb1 Wrap with Bacon Use a toothpick to secure if needed.
6a80ebd5-6e56-423a-937d-8c5f36fcfeb1 Smoke Set up your smoker for cooking at 225-240℉ using indirect heat and your favorite hardwood for smoke. We recommend maple or cherry.
6a80ebd5-6e56-423a-937d-8c5f36fcfeb1 Smoke If your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up.
6a80ebd5-6e56-423a-937d-8c5f36fcfeb1 Smoke When the smoker is ready, place the peppers on the grate.
6a80ebd5-6e56-423a-937d-8c5f36fcfeb1 Finish and Serve Cook for about 3 hours or until the bacon is crisp and peppers are soft. Remove and serve immediately.
6a80ebd5-6e56-423a-937d-8c5f36fcfeb1 Finish and Serve Make plenty!
d45c5972-1a01-45de-8520-e146b47767df Trim Fat Trim the fat cap from the top side of the beef ribs.
d45c5972-1a01-45de-8520-e146b47767df Season Apply a generous coat of Jeff's Texas style rub to the top side of the beef ribs.
d45c5972-1a01-45de-8520-e146b47767df Season After applying the rub, I let it sit for about 20 minutes while you go get the smoker ready.
d45c5972-1a01-45de-8520-e146b47767df Smoke Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225°F with indirect heat.
d45c5972-1a01-45de-8520-e146b47767df Smoke If your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up.
d45c5972-1a01-45de-8520-e146b47767df Smoke Leave them alone while they cook for the first 4 hours or until the ribs reach about 160 degrees in the thickest part between the bones.
d45c5972-1a01-45de-8520-e146b47767df Wrap After 4 hours of cooking or when they reach 160°F in the thickest part of the meat between the bones, wrap the meat in foil or place them in a disposable foil pan with about 8 ounces of beef broth. If you use a pan, cover the top tightly with foil.
d45c5972-1a01-45de-8520-e146b47767df Wrap Place the wrapped, covered ribs back into the smoker and crank up the heat to 275°F.
d45c5972-1a01-45de-8520-e146b47767df Wrap The goal temperature is 201-203°F which will take about 1 to 1.5 hours to reach after they are covered while cooking at 275 degrees.
d45c5972-1a01-45de-8520-e146b47767df Wrap Also check them with a probe to ensure they are very tender and there is no resistance.
d45c5972-1a01-45de-8520-e146b47767df Rest After removing them from the smoker, place the entire pan into a cooler for at least an hour. 2 to 3 hours would not be a bad thing if you get them done way ahead of dinner time.
d45c5972-1a01-45de-8520-e146b47767df Serve Slice the ribs right between the bones and serve 'em up to your guests.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Remove Membrane Place the rib section bone side up and pry up the membrane with your fingers or a sharp implement such as a butter knife.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Remove Membrane Grab ahold of it with a paper towel for better grip and pull firmly to remove it completely.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Seasoning Apply the Texas style rub first then apply the original rub over the top of that.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Seasoning First place the ribs bone side up and apply the Texas style rub all over and don't forget the sides.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Seasoning Next apply a coat of the original rub in the same way.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Seasoning Now flip them over and repeat the Texas style rub and the original rub on the meaty side.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Seasoning If you are doing this in advance (highly recommended) you can now place them in the fridge to dry brine and they will be good to go in as little as 4 hours although 8-10 hours is even better.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Smoke Time for Pellet Smoker I recommend you cook them for 1 hour at the lowest setting or the specialized smoke setting. I use the Camp Chef Woodwind and I used “lo smoke”.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Smoke Time for Pellet Smoker Once the smoker is ready place the ribs on the grate or you can use a pan and rack like I did to keep the smoker clean and eliminate some of the cleanup.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Smoke Time for Pellet Smoker After the initial 1 hour, turn them up to 225°F. (On the Woodwind, I turned them up to Hi Smoke which maintains an average of 220°F)
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Smoke Time for Pellet Smoker Maintain the 220-225°F temperature in your smoker for 6.5 to 7 hours or until the ribs are tender. You can also check them with a temperature probe if you prefer– they are done when they reach about 200°F in the meat between the bones. Make sure the probe does not touch the bone.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Smoke Time for Pellet Smoker Tip: Mist the ribs with apple juice every 30 minutes or as often as possible while they are cooking using a food grade plastic spray bottle.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Smoke Time for All Other Smokers Preheat your smoker to 225 using indirect heat. If your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Smoke Time for All Other Smokers Once the smoker is ready place the ribs on the grate or you can use a pan and rack like I did to keep the smoker clean and eliminate some of the cleanup.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Smoke Time for All Other Smokers Maintain 225 to 240°F temperature in your smoker for 6 to 7 hours or until the ribs are tender. You can also check them with a temperature probe if you prefer– they are done when they reach about 200°F in the meat between the bones. Make sure the probe does not touch the bone.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Smoke Time for All Other Smokers Tip: Mist the ribs with apple juice every 30 minutes or as often as possible while they are cooking using a food grade plastic spray bottle.
45a6d44d-22c2-4c5c-9e4b-c57e6895c948 Rest, Slice and Serve When the ribs are finished cooking, let them rest for about 10 minutes under tented foil then slice them between the bones and serve.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Remove Membrane (optional) Flip the ribs to bone side up, use a knife, spoon or just your finger to start pulling up on that plastic-like membrane that covers the bones.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Remove Membrane (optional) Tip: use a paper towel or catfish pliers for better grip.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Slice Ribs To do this make sure the ribs are bone side up so you can see the bones better and slice off the first bone to your left, right against the bone.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Slice Ribs Now slice as close against the third bone from left as you can leaving maximum meat on the bone in the center
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Slice Ribs Doing it this way, you get a bone in the center with maximum meat on both sides of the bone.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Slice Ribs Continue these same cuts until you end up with about 6 center ribs with lots of meat on both sides.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Slice Ribs You'll end up with about 7 bone fragments with very little meat on them. Those can be saved for a soup, pot of beans, etc.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Add Sauce and Rub Lay the extra wide ribs down in a foil pan–
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Add Sauce and Rub A little sauce on each one first– Get your hands dirty and rub it in to the top, sides and bottom of each one.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Add Sauce and Rub Now apply ample amounts of Jeff's original rub on all sides.. pat it in a little to make it stay before you flip them over.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Overnight in the Fridge Place the pan of ribs in the fridge for at least 4 hours but overnight is MUCH better.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Set up Smoker Use whatever smoker you have or want to use whether it's charcoal, splits, gas, electric, you get the idea. Run about 225°F no matter what smoker you use.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Set up Smoker If your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up for good measure.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Set up Smoker I used pecan but hickory or almost any smoking wood that you have available will work great for these ribs and give them an amazing flavor.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Set up Smoker Once your smoker is preheated and ready to cook, let's get the ribs in there.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Smoke the Meat Place the pan of ribs into the smoker or you can place them directly onto the grates if you prefer.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Smoke the Meat Let them cook for about 3 hours first to form a really good crust. Check them at this point and if they look like the rub on the top is nice and dry, feel free to spritz them with some apple juice, Pepsi, whatever you have. Something with a little sugar in it is best.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Sauce and Sear At hour 4, it's time to put some sauce on them, of course you should use Jeff's original barbecue sauce but if you have another favorite, well, whatever
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Sauce and Sear Coat them good and spread it out over the top and sides.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Sauce and Sear Now crank up the heat. I have a Camp Chef Woodwind so I pushed it on up to 425°F to get a good finish on them. If you also have a smoker that can cook hot like that, then I recommend you do the same otherwise as hot as you can.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Sauce and Sear Tip: Another option is to bring them in at this point and put them into the oven preheated to 425°F.
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Sauce and Sear At 425°F, it took mine an additional 40 minutes to be get the color I wanted on the ribs and to get some char on the sauce.. they turned out beautiful if you ask me!
63256a86-bcb5-41f8-96b2-c1aee98d7feb Serve 'em Up Serve them just as soon as they are finished and watch the smiling faces and enjoy the quietness as everyone stops talking to eat.. that's how you know the food is amazing
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Dry brine and Season Use ½ teaspoon per pound of meat when dry brining meat such as this chuck roast. This chuck was 3 lbs so I can use about 1.5 teaspoons of salt.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Dry brine and Season I made the decision to use 1 teaspoon of coarse kosher salt and some of my Texas style rub which has a small amount of salt as well.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Dry brine and Season First the salt..
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Dry brine and Season Then the Texas style rub..
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Dry brine and Season Now place that pan with the chuck roast in the fridge overnight or for at least 6 hours to let the salt and seasoning to do its magic!
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Set Up Smoker Just before the brine time is over, set up your smoker for cooking indirect at about 225-240°F and if your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Set Up Smoker You will notice that I used my new 20×36 by Lone Star Grillz.. not only was it super easy to maintain my temperature but the quality and craftsmanship on this thing is phenomenal!
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Set Up Smoker If you're in the market for a patio sized offset smoker.. this one is perfectly sized and of course they have other sizes as well. You can check them out at lonestargrillz.com
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Set Up Smoker You'll hear me talking more about this smoker in future newsletters and videos.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Smoke Time Once the smoker is ready and the dry brining is done, place the meat in the smoker.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Smoke Time You will notice that I like to use a pan with a rack to cut down on smoker cleaning while still allowing the smoke to get to every side of the meat. The one I use was purchased on Amazon but anything similar will work just fine. Mine is a full size stainless steel pan with fitted stainless steel rack and it came with (2) sets of these.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Smoke Time Maintain 225 to 240°F for the entire cook time. I used a mix of cherry and hickory but use what you have available.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 In the Pan Let the chuck roast smoke along until it reaches about 145-150°F and then move it to a foil pan filled with a can of beef broth and a half can of cream of mushroom soup.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 In the Pan I mixed the ingredients into a small bowl before adding it to the pan..
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 In the Pan Place the meat down into the foil pan with the liquid and let it continue cooking.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Wrap it Up When the meat reaches 175°F, you'll want to wrap it up or just place a piece of foil tightly over the foil pan. This will allow the liquid to create steam and braise the meat to make it more tender.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Wrap it Up Let it stay wrapped and cooking until it is fall apart tender. Mine ended up going all the way to 208°F and I figure that you'll probably have a similar experience. Fortunately, these have plenty of fat to keep them moist even when you cook them to these extremes to tenderize them.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Rest and Pull/Shred the Meat When the meat is tender, best determined by pushing a probe or other sharp object into the meat and feeling for no resistance, remove the pan from the smoker and let it sit, still covered, and rest for up to an hour or two but at least 10-15 minutes.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Rest and Pull/Shred the Meat If you have some help, let them pull the meat into pieces while you grill up the onions and toast the bread. Otherwise, you can go ahead and pull the chuck roast while the onions and bread are on the griddle.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Grill Onions and Toast Bread If you have a griddle such as Camp Chef or Blackstone, that will work great. This new smoker came with a griddle over the top of the firebox and boy it worked great! It was right around 365 °F when I started and that worked perfectly for what I was doing.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Grill Onions and Toast Bread If you want to grill some onions, use half slices or even the whole rings if you want to. Pour the onions on the griddle with about a tablespoon of olive oil and about a tablespoon of my Texas style rub on top. Mix it all in and just stir it around here and there until they get really soft and wimpy. Delicious!!
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Grill Onions and Toast Bread To grill the bread, just butter both sides and grill both sides until it gets a nice crisp surface.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Grill Onions and Toast Bread I went ahead and mixed the meat with some of the onions on the griddle to warm it all up for the sandwich.
9bdcb17a-4225-419a-b4eb-e6b19019fd17 Put Together and Serve Pile the meat and grills onions on the toast and make yourself a sandwich that will make you smile!
2d377549-d0ff-4a3f-8078-d1bf51240b82 Rinse Well Rinse the brisket well under cold water.
2d377549-d0ff-4a3f-8078-d1bf51240b82 Test the Saltiness Cut a small, thin slice of the brisket and fry it in a pan until tender. Taste it to determine if it is too salty.
2d377549-d0ff-4a3f-8078-d1bf51240b82 Test the Saltiness If too salty, soak in a pan of cold water in the fridge for 3-4 hours to remove some of the salt. Repeat this process of frying, tasting, soaking until it is perfect. Note: This recipe is a relatively mild concentration and usually does not require any soaking.
2d377549-d0ff-4a3f-8078-d1bf51240b82 Season it Up Pour enough coriander seeds into a mortar and pestle to obtain 1 TBS of crushed coriander. Mix 1 TBS of crushed coriander with 3 TBS of Jeff's Texas style rub.
2d377549-d0ff-4a3f-8078-d1bf51240b82 Season it Up Apply a light to medium coat of the rub to the top side of the brisket and on the sides as much as possible. Press down all over with a fork to make it stick.
2d377549-d0ff-4a3f-8078-d1bf51240b82 Smoke Time Preheat smoker to 225 degrees using indirect heat. Once it's ready, place the brisket in the smoker and let it cook until it reaches 165 degrees F.
2d377549-d0ff-4a3f-8078-d1bf51240b82 Smoke Time Place brisket in pan and cover with foil or wrap the brisket in unlined, unwaxed butcher paper or foil and continue cooking until the brisket reaches about 200 degrees.
2d377549-d0ff-4a3f-8078-d1bf51240b82 Smoke Time The brisket is finished cooking when a probe inserted in the thickest part gives no resistance.
2d377549-d0ff-4a3f-8078-d1bf51240b82 Finish and Taste Rest the brisket covered for at least 1 hour then slice across the grain and serve.
3284473c-f31f-4607-9f8b-57c67b10f13f Trim the Brisket Trim all of the fat from the larger point end and to at least 1/4 inch or less on the flat end. If the brisket has plenty of fat marbling, you can remove all of the fat.
3284473c-f31f-4607-9f8b-57c67b10f13f Make the Curing Brine Add the curing salt and the coarse kosher salt to the water and stir until it becomes clear (about 2 minutes)
3284473c-f31f-4607-9f8b-57c67b10f13f Make the Curing Brine Add the brown sugar and stir until dissolved.
3284473c-f31f-4607-9f8b-57c67b10f13f Toast the Pickling Spices Heat an iron skillet over high heat and place pickling spices in the pan to toast. Keep the spices moving for about a minute or until you smell their aroma.
3284473c-f31f-4607-9f8b-57c67b10f13f Toast the Pickling Spices Transfer toasted pickling spices to the curing brine and stir.
3284473c-f31f-4607-9f8b-57c67b10f13f Begin the Cure Place the meat into a large food-safe plastic, glass or non-reactive container. Pour brine over the meat to cover.
3284473c-f31f-4607-9f8b-57c67b10f13f Begin the Cure If necessary, weigh the meat down with a plate and/or a zip top bag filled with water to keep the meat submerged.
3284473c-f31f-4607-9f8b-57c67b10f13f Begin the Cure Cover the container and place in the fridge.
3284473c-f31f-4607-9f8b-57c67b10f13f The Wait Keep the meat in the fridge for 6-10 days flipping the brisket every day for more even brining/curing.
55c6d771-58d9-45f1-97b8-04c48ca709d3 Combine the Snacks Measure out each of the snacks into a large foil pan.
55c6d771-58d9-45f1-97b8-04c48ca709d3 Make the Flavored Butter Melt the butter then add the hot sauce and 2 TBS of Jeff's original rub and mix well.
55c6d771-58d9-45f1-97b8-04c48ca709d3 Mix Flavored Butter with Snack Mix Drizzle the butter mixture over the snack mix and stir well to coat.
55c6d771-58d9-45f1-97b8-04c48ca709d3 Smoke Setup your smoker to maintain indirect heat of 225°F. If you are using a pellet smoker, I recommend going with 180°F or the low smoke setting for better smoke flavor.
55c6d771-58d9-45f1-97b8-04c48ca709d3 Smoke Once the smoke is going, place the pan(s) of snacks into the smoker and close the lid.
55c6d771-58d9-45f1-97b8-04c48ca709d3 Smoke Stir the mix occasionally for more uniform smoke flavor.
55c6d771-58d9-45f1-97b8-04c48ca709d3 Smoke Smoke the snack mix for about an hour or until the snacks are as crisp and smoky as you like. Note: In a pellet smoker, I recommend 180°F for 2 hours.
55c6d771-58d9-45f1-97b8-04c48ca709d3 Smoke Remove the pans from the smoker and bring them into the house to cool.
55c6d771-58d9-45f1-97b8-04c48ca709d3 Serve or Store for Party Time Serve the snack mix right away.
55c6d771-58d9-45f1-97b8-04c48ca709d3 Serve or Store for Party Time If you are not serving them right away: Allow them to cool completely on the counter then store them in zipper bags.
adb25e09-0dfd-4fa7-bce3-a34c969c2dcf Prep Vegetables Clean and deseed the yellow bell pepper and the jalapenos then dice them up.
adb25e09-0dfd-4fa7-bce3-a34c969c2dcf Prep Vegetables Dice up a small yellow onion.
adb25e09-0dfd-4fa7-bce3-a34c969c2dcf Saute Vegetables Pour 2 TBS of vegetable or olive oil into a large chili pot over medium heat then add all of the diced vegetables. Stir occasionally until the peppers and onion soften and begin to char.
adb25e09-0dfd-4fa7-bce3-a34c969c2dcf Prep and Add Meat Cube 2 lbs of brisket burnt ends into 1/2 inch pieces then add to the pot once the vegetables are sauteed.
adb25e09-0dfd-4fa7-bce3-a34c969c2dcf Prep and Add Meat Let the vegetables and meat cook together for about 10 minutes.
adb25e09-0dfd-4fa7-bce3-a34c969c2dcf Add Everything Else Add Ro-tel, tomato paste, water and spices and stir well to combine.
adb25e09-0dfd-4fa7-bce3-a34c969c2dcf Cook the Chili While still on medium heat, cover the pot and bring the chili to a boil.
adb25e09-0dfd-4fa7-bce3-a34c969c2dcf Cook the Chili Once it boils, turn the heat down to low and remove the lid. Let the chili continue to cook on low for about 2 hours or until it obtains the thickness you are looking for.
d22ab1d2-adda-4a14-86d2-bc5ebbdade20 Brine Pour 1 gallon of cold water into large pitcher. Add salt and sugar and stir until dissolved.
d22ab1d2-adda-4a14-86d2-bc5ebbdade20 Brine Place chicken into non-reactive container and pour brine over chicken to cover. Refrigerate.
d22ab1d2-adda-4a14-86d2-bc5ebbdade20 Brine After 4 hours, remove the chicken, rinse and pat dry. Discard brine.
d22ab1d2-adda-4a14-86d2-bc5ebbdade20 Prepare Cut along both sides of backbone to remove. Press chicken open and place skin side down on cutting board.
d22ab1d2-adda-4a14-86d2-bc5ebbdade20 Prepare Mix together 1 cup of mayonnaise and 1/4 cup of Jeff's original rub. Place 1/2 of mixture on meat side of chicken. Spread to coat.
d22ab1d2-adda-4a14-86d2-bc5ebbdade20 Prepare Flip chicken to skin side up and apply other half of mayo/rub mixture to skin side spreading it all over the breast, wings and legs to coat. Push some of it under the skin wherever you can.
d22ab1d2-adda-4a14-86d2-bc5ebbdade20 Smoke Setup smoker for cooking indirect at 275 degrees using pecan wood for smoke. If your smoker uses a water pan, leave it dry.
d22ab1d2-adda-4a14-86d2-bc5ebbdade20 Smoke Place chicken meat side down- cook chicken until internal temperature reaches 165 degrees F in the thickest part of the breast and thigh.
d22ab1d2-adda-4a14-86d2-bc5ebbdade20 Smoke While the chicken is cooking, mix together 1 stick of melted butter and 2 TBS of Jeff's original rub. Brush this all over the skin side of the chicken 2 to 3 times during the cooking process or anytime it starts to look dry.
d22ab1d2-adda-4a14-86d2-bc5ebbdade20 Rest and Serve Once the chicken is finished cooking, remove it to the counter and let it rest for 15 minutes with foil tented over the top.
d22ab1d2-adda-4a14-86d2-bc5ebbdade20 Rest and Serve Carve the chicken and serve.
693dc8aa-ac72-4ce6-9685-c5c5dedb64c5 Into the Pan Open the bag of Cheetos® Puffs and pour them into a large sheet pan. Something like a Weber grill pan would also work well.
693dc8aa-ac72-4ce6-9685-c5c5dedb64c5 Into the Pan Pour the little puffs of goodness into the pan(s) making sure the smoke can get to all of them.
693dc8aa-ac72-4ce6-9685-c5c5dedb64c5 Smoke Setup your smoker to maintain indirect heat of around 180°F or lower if possible. You do NOT need heat, only smoke, however, a little heat will not hurt them.
693dc8aa-ac72-4ce6-9685-c5c5dedb64c5 Smoke Once the smoke is going, place the pan(s) of Puffs into the smoker and close the lid.
693dc8aa-ac72-4ce6-9685-c5c5dedb64c5 Smoke Leave them alone for 30 minutes and try to not raise the lid until they are finished for maximum smoke flavor.
693dc8aa-ac72-4ce6-9685-c5c5dedb64c5 Smoke When the time has expired, remove them from the smoker and bring them into the house to cool.
693dc8aa-ac72-4ce6-9685-c5c5dedb64c5 Devour These can be devoured in any way that you see fit.. enjoy the smoke flavor!
693dc8aa-ac72-4ce6-9685-c5c5dedb64c5 Devour Once they are cooled down, you can store them in zipper bags.
ebc3360e-0a17-4aa7-8b8b-ca1a34119fe4 Into Pan Open the bag of potato chips and pour them into one or more Weber grill pans or a large sheet pan.
ebc3360e-0a17-4aa7-8b8b-ca1a34119fe4 Into Pan If you want to put some of my Jeff's original rub on them, spray them with the cooking oil so the rub will stick better then apply the rub to them generously on one side only.
ebc3360e-0a17-4aa7-8b8b-ca1a34119fe4 Into Pan The potato chips are now ready for the smoker.
ebc3360e-0a17-4aa7-8b8b-ca1a34119fe4 Smoke Setup your smoker to maintain indirect heat of around 180°F or lower if possible. You do NOT need heat, only smoke, however, a little heat will not hurt them.
ebc3360e-0a17-4aa7-8b8b-ca1a34119fe4 Smoke Once the smoke is going, place the pan(s) of chips into the smoker and close the lid.
ebc3360e-0a17-4aa7-8b8b-ca1a34119fe4 Smoke Leave them alone for 45 minutes and try to not raise the lid until they are finished for maximum smoke flavor.
ebc3360e-0a17-4aa7-8b8b-ca1a34119fe4 Smoke When the time has expired, remove them from the smoker and bring them into the house to cool.
ebc3360e-0a17-4aa7-8b8b-ca1a34119fe4 Devour The smoked potato chips are delicious warm so you can eat them right away. Once they are cooled down, place them into zipper bags for storage.
5466e8f1-b682-4c9d-a0c3-6056bd0d636b Pre-prep and Dry Brine To get started, I laid down a bed of rosemary sprigs in my pan. Then the steaks are laid right on top.
5466e8f1-b682-4c9d-a0c3-6056bd0d636b Pre-prep and Dry Brine Coat each of the steaks with about 1/4 tsp of coarse kosher salt
5466e8f1-b682-4c9d-a0c3-6056bd0d636b Pre-prep and Dry Brine Place the entire pan of steaks in the fridge for about 2 to 3 hours. When the steaks are done brining, there is no need to rinse.
5466e8f1-b682-4c9d-a0c3-6056bd0d636b Seasoning After brining, give them a good application of the Texas style rub. They are ready to be smoked.
5466e8f1-b682-4c9d-a0c3-6056bd0d636b Smoker Time Set up your smoker for indirect heat at about 225°F. If your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up.
5466e8f1-b682-4c9d-a0c3-6056bd0d636b Smoker Time Once the smoker is ready, place the pan of steaks right on the grate and let the smoking commence.
5466e8f1-b682-4c9d-a0c3-6056bd0d636b Brown and/or Sear Once the steaks reach about 120°F, increase the heat in your smoker to about 450°F or you can move the pan to your oven broiler to give the steaks some sear on the outside.
5466e8f1-b682-4c9d-a0c3-6056bd0d636b Brown and/or Sear When the reach 130°F or a good medium rare, they can be removed from the heat.
5466e8f1-b682-4c9d-a0c3-6056bd0d636b Rest and Serve Rest the steaks for 15 minutes with foil tented over the top of the pan before serving.
5466e8f1-b682-4c9d-a0c3-6056bd0d636b Rest and Serve Just before serving, brush some melted butter with original rub over the top.
5466e8f1-b682-4c9d-a0c3-6056bd0d636b Rest and Serve Rub Butter is made using 1/2 stick of melted butter with 1 tablespoon of Jeff's original rub. Stir while using to keep it mixed up well.
5466e8f1-b682-4c9d-a0c3-6056bd0d636b Rest and Serve Serve and enjoy one of the best steaks you've ever tasted!
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Butterfly (spatchcock) the Duck First let's cut off that annoying long piece of extra skin!
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Butterfly (spatchcock) the Duck Cut along both side of the backbone to remove it.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Butterfly (spatchcock) the Duck Flip the bird over and press down to flatten it out.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Dry Brine With meat side facing up, sprinkle about 1.5 to 2 teaspoons of coarse kosher salt evenly all over. Leave it in this position for about 5 or 10 minutes or until you see the salt starting to dissolve
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Dry Brine Now flip the bird over the skin side up and place it on a rack inside of a cookie sheet or pan. I used a Bradley rack as usual but a cooling rack or even a Weber grill pan would work great.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Dry Brine Sprinkle another 1.5 to 2 teaspoons of coarse kosher salt evenly all over the wings, legs and breast..
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Dry Brine Now place the whole pan with the duck into the fridge, uncovered overnight or for 8 to 12 hours.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Dry Brine There is no need to rinse the duck after brining.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Season Generously Apply my original rub all over the duck, both sides. Then apply a light sprinkling of the Texas rub.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Smoke Time Set up your smoker for cooking with indirect heat at about 225°F and if your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Smoke Time Use pecan and cherry wood (or a mix) for smoke
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Smoke Time Once your smoker is ready, place the whole pan into the smoker, with the duck skin side up.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Smoke Time Let the duck cook at 225°F for 2 hours for some good smoke flavor.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Smoke Time Several times during the cook brush the duck with a mixture of 1 stick of butter and 2 TBS of Jeff's original rub.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Sear the Breast Using kitchen shears, make a few snips in the skin over the breast. These are drain holes so the fat can bubble out as it renders.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Sear the Breast If you have a smoker that will cook at higher temperatures, I recommend turning up the heat to 325°F for about an hour or until it reaches 150°F in the thickest part of the breast. Then you can flip it over and finish it off over a direct flames on the grill or you can leave it skin side up and use the broiler in your oven.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Sear the Breast If your smoker will not cook this hot, consider moving the pan with the duck to the oven at 325°F for about an hour or until it reaches 150°F in the thickest part of the breast. Then you can finish using the broiler in your oven.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Rest and Serve When the duck is finished cooking, remove it from the heat and tent some foil over the top for about 15 minutes.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 Rest and Serve Remove the wings and legs then slowly and carefully remove the breast meat by following right along the breast bone with a very sharp knife. Slice the breast into cutlets and call dinner.
397e570a-29c2-4fb4-9a31-246405281ed8 The Cranberry Sauce For cranberry sauce, Add1 cup of orange juice, 1 cup of granulated sugar and 12 ounces of fresh cranberries to a small sauce pan over medium high heat and bring to a boil. Once it boils reduce the heat to low and let it simmer until it thickens to your liking.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Maple Syrup and Rub Sit the ham into a shallow pan.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Maple Syrup and Rub Peel back each slice and douse it with maple syrup.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Maple Syrup and Rub Now, go back through and peel back every slice giving it a good application of my original rub.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Maple Syrup and Rub Don't forget to get that very front piece and the sides and back of the ham as well.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Maple Syrup and Rub Pin the very front slice in place with some toothpicks around the perimeter so it doesn't fall over during cooking.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Maple Syrup and Rub The ham is now ready for the smoker.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Smoke It Setup you smoker for indirect cooking at about 225°F and my recommendation is to use pecan wood for smoke if you have that available. Otherwise, any smoking wood will work.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Smoke It If your smoker has a water pan, fill it up.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Smoke It Place the pan with the ham on the smoker grate and let it go for about 3 to 4 hours.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Smoke It Make up a batch of ham glaze using ½ cup of maple syrup and 2 TBS of Jeff's original rub.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Smoke It About once every hour, glaze the outside of the ham with this stuff. You don't need to peel back the slices, just the outside will do.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Slice and Serve When the ham starts to get some nice crispiness to the edges or when you can no longer stand the amazing smell without taking a bite, call it done.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Slice and Serve Remove the toothpicks and tear the slices off into a serving plate.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Slice and Serve All those sweet and smoky juices in the pan can now be poured over the top of the slices.
b5ff8874-c430-4e0c-bc30-ef1796e2341e Slice and Serve Serve and enjoy!
bc405998-c55c-43e6-91a2-ccbf69548959 Wet Brine Make a brine mixture using 1 gallon of water, 1 cup of coarse kosher salt and 1 cup of brown sugar (light or dark).
bc405998-c55c-43e6-91a2-ccbf69548959 Wet Brine Place the turkey legs in a plastic or glass container and pour the brine mixture over them to cover. Chill in the fridge for 8 to 10 hours.
bc405998-c55c-43e6-91a2-ccbf69548959 Wet Brine Rinse turkey legs when they are finished brining.
bc405998-c55c-43e6-91a2-ccbf69548959 Seasoning Make together 1 cup of mayonnaise and 1/4 cup of rub.
bc405998-c55c-43e6-91a2-ccbf69548959 Seasoning Apply mixture to all of the turkey legs getting it under the skin wherever possible.
bc405998-c55c-43e6-91a2-ccbf69548959 Smoke Time Set up smoker for cooking at 225-250 degrees F using indirect heat.
bc405998-c55c-43e6-91a2-ccbf69548959 Smoke Time Place turkey legs on smoker grate to cook.
bc405998-c55c-43e6-91a2-ccbf69548959 Glazing When the turkey reaches about 160 degrees F, glaze the turkey with a mixture of 1 cup maple syrup, 1 stick of butter and 1/4 cup Jeff's origiinal rub.
bc405998-c55c-43e6-91a2-ccbf69548959 Glazing Glaze again in about 15 minutes.
bc405998-c55c-43e6-91a2-ccbf69548959 Finish and Serve When the turkey reaches 180 degrees in the thickest part, it is finished and can be removed from the heat.
bc405998-c55c-43e6-91a2-ccbf69548959 Finish and Serve Serve immediately.
3afd7905-c89b-416f-a43d-942507fe56e1
Cut a "T" into each jalapeno pepper by cutting halfway through the pepper just below the stem then cutting a slit from the top of the "T" to the tip of the pepper.
3afd7905-c89b-416f-a43d-942507fe56e1
Carefully pry open the pepper and deseed and devein the peppers with a thin, sharp knife then give them a good rinse under cold water to remove any remaining seeds.
3afd7905-c89b-416f-a43d-942507fe56e1
Make the stuffing mixture using 2 cups of pulled brisket, 16 ounces of softened cream cheese, 2 cups of shredded smoked gouda, and 1/2 cup of Jeff's original rub. Mix well.
3afd7905-c89b-416f-a43d-942507fe56e1
Stuff the peppers with the stuffing mixture.
3afd7905-c89b-416f-a43d-942507fe56e1
Stretch thick slices of bacon then wrap a single piece around each pepper. Secure with a toothpick.
3afd7905-c89b-416f-a43d-942507fe56e1
Setup smoker for cooking at 225 degrees with indirect heat. Use pecan wood for smoke and if your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up.
3afd7905-c89b-416f-a43d-942507fe56e1
Cook peppers directly on the grate for about 3 hours or until the bacon has a good bite-through and the peppers are soft to your liking.
3afd7905-c89b-416f-a43d-942507fe56e1
When the peppers are ready to eat, give them a good glazing with thinned barbecue sauce and crank up the heat to 350 degrees for 15 minutes.
3afd7905-c89b-416f-a43d-942507fe56e1
Serve immediately.
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
Trim the fat cap to 1/4 inch and remove any hard fat on the brisket.
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
Score the fat cap in a crosshatch pattern at 1-inch intervals.
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
Place the brisket in a large foil pan fat cap up.
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
Douse the top with Worcestershire sauce and apply Jeff's Texas style rub generously.
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
Flip the brisket to fat side down
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
Douse the new top side with Worcestershire sauce and apply Jeff's Texas style rub generously.
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
Cover with foil and place the pan of brisket in the fridge overnight.
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
Setup the smoker for cooking at 225 degrees using indirect heat.
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
When ready, place the pan of brisket on the smoker and let it cook for 6-7 hours or until it reaches 165 degrees F.
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
Douse the brisket with Worcestershire every 90 minutes until it reaches 165 degrees F.
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
At 165 degrees, place another equally sized pan upside down on top of the pan with the brisket sealing the meat inside. You can also just cover with foil if desired.
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
Continue cooking the brisket until it reaches ~200 degrees and a probe inserted in the meat shows no resistance.
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
Remove the brisket from heat and wrap in unlined/uncoated butcher paper or foil. Place in a empty cooler to rest for 4 hours.
4333b507-4a19-402f-bca7-598bf28ab97c
After resting, remove brisket from cooler and slice 1/4 inch thick across the grain.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Make the Meatball Mixture Place the breadcrumbs into a separate bowl and pour the buttermilk over the top.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Make the Meatball Mixture Add onions, Texas style rub, Worcestershire and chopped parsley.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Make the Meatball Mixture Give it a good mix and then leave it sitting so the ingredients could get to know each other for about 10 minutes while you get the smoker ready.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Make the Meatball Mixture Break the meat up into chunks and add that to a large bowl with the bread crumb mixture on top.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Make the Meatball Mixture Blend that carefully with your hands making sure to only mix as much as absolutely necessary. Over-mixing is not good for meatballs and tends to make them tough.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Form the Meatballs To make the meatballs more uniform in size, you can either weigh them or just use a scoop so you get the same amount of mixture for each one.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Form the Meatballs Roll the mixture between your palms to form as many uniform meatballs as you need.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Set Up Your Smoker Setup your smoker for cooking at about 225 to 240°F using indirect heat.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Set Up Your Smoker I recommend oak or cherry smoke or a mixture of these if you have it.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Set Up Your Smoker Lastly, if your smoker utilizes a water pan, fill it up and use it.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Smoke 'em Once the smoker is preheated and ready to go, place the meatballs on the grate or you can leave them on the pan if you are using something like a Bradley rack or a Weber grill pan like I do.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Smoke 'em Keep a close eye on these meatballs since they'll most likely be done in an hour or less depending on the size that you make them and the temperature that you run in your smoker.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Smoke 'em Use a handheld thermometer that reads fast for best results.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Smoke 'em The meatballs are done when they reach an internal temperature of 160°F however, when they reach about 150°F, you have a decision to make– keep reading!
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 To Sauce or Not To Sauce If you want to glaze the meatballs with sauce, then read on. Otherwise skip to step 6
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 To Sauce or Not To Sauce Pour a cup of my barbecue sauce into a bowl and mix in ½ cup of Worcestershire sauce.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 To Sauce or Not To Sauce Glaze the meatballs with this sauce mixture then let them finish cooking.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Serve When the meatballs reach 160°F they are finished and should be removed from the heat and served immediately.
c1b0ce98-d52b-4ff1-87ad-b55fc5a022b0 Serve Add a little chopped parsley on top for garnish.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Trim the Fat If you are cooking the tri-tip low and slow, then there is no reason to leave the fat cap intact. Remove it with a sharp knife.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Dry Brine Apply coarse kosher salt to both sides of the meat at a rate of about 1/2 teaspoon per lb. 1 teaspoon of coarse kosher salt covers a 2 lb tri-tip.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Dry Brine Place meat in a lidded container and into the fridge for 2 hours.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Dry Brine It is not necessary to rinse the salt from the meat.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Season with Texas Rub Apply a light coat of Jeff's Texas style rub to the top side of the tri-tip.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Season with Texas Rub Set the meat aside while you go get the smoker ready.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Setup the Smoker Setup your smoker for cooking at about 225°F with indirect heat if possible. If your smoker uses a water pan fill it up.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Setup the Smoker Let the smoker preheat for about 30 minutes before proceeding to the next step.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Cook with Smoke Lay the tri-tip right on the smoker grate or you can use something like a Weber grill pan or Bradley rack to make it easy to move it to and from the kitchen.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Cook with Smoke Use oak and/or pecan for smoke if you have it and keep that smoke going the entire time if possible.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Cook with Smoke Keep a CLOSE eye on the temperature since that is the ONLY way to truly know when it's perfect.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Sear It! When the meat reaches about 110 to 115°F is a great time to remove it from the smoker and place it over a fire, some hot coals or under the broiler of your oven to sear the meat.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Sear It! The idea here is to brown the outside of the meat not just to make sear marks. This browning improves the flavor greatly.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Sear It! If the meat has not reached 130°F when you are done searing, place the meat back in the smoker to finish.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Rest and Serve When finished, remove the tri-tip from the heat.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Rest and Serve For best results, loosely wrap it in foil for a little rest time. I usually allow about 10-15 minutes before slicing.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Rest and Serve Slice it up into pieces about the thickness of a pencil.
016bc913-881e-434a-8967-ae8b5e39d9b2 Rest and Serve Serve and enjoy!
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Remove Rind/Skin if Required Use a very sharp knife to remove skin/rind if required.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Make Cuts in Fat Cap With the pork belly laying flat in front of you, fat cap side up, use a very sharp knife to make cuts (back to front) about ¼ inch deep and about 1 inch apart.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Make Cuts in Fat Cap Make the same cuts from side to side.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Season Fat Cap Apply barbecue sauce or yellow mustard all over the fat cap to help the rub to stick.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Season Fat Cap Sprinkle rub generously onto the fat cap.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Season the Meaty Side Flip the pork belly over.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Season the Meaty Side Apply the same barbecue sauce or mustard and rub on the meaty side.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Set Up Smoker Set up your smoker for cooking at 225°F using indirect heat and if your smoker has a water pan, fill it up.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Set Up Smoker Once the smoker is ready, go get the meat and get it on the grates.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Cook with Smoke Place the pork belly on the smoker grate fat side up.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Cook with Smoke Let it cook for about 4 hours or until it reaches 160°F.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Foil or Paper Wrap Wrap the meat in foil, butcher paper or you can place it down in a foil pan and cover that with foil.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Foil or Paper Wrap After wrapping or covering, place it back on to the grate for another ~1.5 hours.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Finish and Serve Let the pork belly reach about 195 to 200°F before calling them done.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Finish and Serve Let the meat rest with foil tented over it for at least 15 minutes before serving. An hour is better.
cf389c6c-a15b-4e98-83f9-5da78e823c9a Finish and Serve Slice about ¼ inch thick and serve it up!
a8da8470-51c6-498a-ab19-580cc9ccc09b
Remove membrane from bone side of ribs
a8da8470-51c6-498a-ab19-580cc9ccc09b
Remove flap of meat from bone side using a sharp knife
a8da8470-51c6-498a-ab19-580cc9ccc09b
Apply Jeff's original rub to bone side of ribs
a8da8470-51c6-498a-ab19-580cc9ccc09b
Flip ribs over to meaty side up
a8da8470-51c6-498a-ab19-580cc9ccc09b
Apply Jeff's original rub all over
a8da8470-51c6-498a-ab19-580cc9ccc09b
Smoke cook ribs at 225 degrees for 6 hours
a8da8470-51c6-498a-ab19-580cc9ccc09b
Just before ribs are done, place jar of raspberry spreadable fruit in sauce pan over medium low heat and stir until smooth.
a8da8470-51c6-498a-ab19-580cc9ccc09b
Apply generous coat of the rasperry glaze onto meaty side of ribs about 15 minutes before they are finished cooking.
a8da8470-51c6-498a-ab19-580cc9ccc09b
Remove ribs from heat when they reach 194 degrees F in the meaty area between the bones.
a8da8470-51c6-498a-ab19-580cc9ccc09b
Slice ribs between the bones and serve.
fb709532-8a1f-4ab7-a012-c49aa2f826e7
Apply yellow mustard all over the outside of the meat to help the rub to stick better.
fb709532-8a1f-4ab7-a012-c49aa2f826e7
Pour ¼ cup of Jeff's original rub on top of the pork butt and massage it in to create a paste. Cover the top and sides with the rub/mustard paste.
fb709532-8a1f-4ab7-a012-c49aa2f826e7
Cover/wrap the pork butt and place it in the fridge overnight if possible
fb709532-8a1f-4ab7-a012-c49aa2f826e7
Set up smoker for cooking at about 300°F with indirect heat. Once it's ready, it's time to cook.
fb709532-8a1f-4ab7-a012-c49aa2f826e7
Place pork butt on grate fat side down and close lid/door.
fb709532-8a1f-4ab7-a012-c49aa2f826e7
When the pork butt reaches 165°F or when the color is perfect (about 3 hours), remove meat from smoker and wrap in a double layer of heavy duty foil.
fb709532-8a1f-4ab7-a012-c49aa2f826e7
Place pork butt back onto 300 degree smoker and continue to cook for 2 hours or until the internal temperature of the meat reaches 205°F.
fb709532-8a1f-4ab7-a012-c49aa2f826e7
Remove the meat from the heat and let it rest for at least 30 minutes.
fb709532-8a1f-4ab7-a012-c49aa2f826e7
Pull the meat into chunks, pieces discarding any clumps of fat that did not render during the cooking process.
fb709532-8a1f-4ab7-a012-c49aa2f826e7
Serve pork on slider buns with slaw, pickles, Jeff's barbecue sauce, onions, etc.
fb709532-8a1f-4ab7-a012-c49aa2f826e7
Enjoy!
d3cc9913-50d7-4ab0-ab3b-bffe1dc45a9b
Sprinkle approximately 1/8 teaspoon of kosher salt on the top of each steak and place tray of steaks in the fridge for 2 hours.
d3cc9913-50d7-4ab0-ab3b-bffe1dc45a9b
Remove steaks from fridge (no rinsing required) when they are finished brining.
d3cc9913-50d7-4ab0-ab3b-bffe1dc45a9b
Wrap a piece of bacon around the outside edge of each steak and secure with a toothpick.
d3cc9913-50d7-4ab0-ab3b-bffe1dc45a9b
Apply a light coat of olive oil and a light sprinkling of Jeff's Texas style rub to each steak.
d3cc9913-50d7-4ab0-ab3b-bffe1dc45a9b
Set up smoker for cooking at about 225°F using indirect heat.
d3cc9913-50d7-4ab0-ab3b-bffe1dc45a9b
Place the meat in the smoker for approximately 1 hour or until the steaks reach an internal temperature of 130°F (medium rare).
d3cc9913-50d7-4ab0-ab3b-bffe1dc45a9b
Let the steaks cool for about 10-15 minutes then sear the top and bottom of each steak on a very hot grill or in a screaming hot skillet. Leave them in the skillet only long enough to brown the meat. Do not let them burn.
d3cc9913-50d7-4ab0-ab3b-bffe1dc45a9b
As an option, you can use a handheld torch to crisp the bacon on the outside of each steak as 1 hour isn't quite long enough to do that in the smoker.
d3cc9913-50d7-4ab0-ab3b-bffe1dc45a9b
Serve immediately.
dfad1631-b62b-486d-ae16-7a5eebe39983
Remove skin on bone side of the ribs if desired
dfad1631-b62b-486d-ae16-7a5eebe39983
Sprinkle about 1 to 1.5 teaspoons of kosher salt on the meaty side of each rack of ribs
dfad1631-b62b-486d-ae16-7a5eebe39983
Place the ribs in the fridge for at least 2 hours but overnight is also good.
dfad1631-b62b-486d-ae16-7a5eebe39983
Do not rinse. Apply about 2 TBS of Jeff's Texas style rub to the top meaty side of each rack of ribs.
dfad1631-b62b-486d-ae16-7a5eebe39983
Set up the Pit Barrel Cooker according to manufacturers instruction and when it's ready, hang the racks() of ribs and replace the lid.
dfad1631-b62b-486d-ae16-7a5eebe39983
Check the temperature of the ribs after about 2 hours and when they reach 190 °F, apply about ¼ cup of sauce all over (if desired)
dfad1631-b62b-486d-ae16-7a5eebe39983
The ribs are finished cooking when they reach 195 °F internal temperature and can be removed from the cooker.
dfad1631-b62b-486d-ae16-7a5eebe39983
Rest for about 10 minutes then slice between the bones and serve.
ec5facbb-2cb9-47fd-b505-bb87fbc6d40d
Separate meat from large clumps of fat
ec5facbb-2cb9-47fd-b505-bb87fbc6d40d
Cut meat into pieces of consistent size. I recommend about 1 x 1 inch.
ec5facbb-2cb9-47fd-b505-bb87fbc6d40d
Place meat into a bag and pour ½ cup of Jeff's original rub over the meat.
ec5facbb-2cb9-47fd-b505-bb87fbc6d40d
Roll, knead, and shake the bag to coat the meat with the rub.
ec5facbb-2cb9-47fd-b505-bb87fbc6d40d
Place the bag of seasoned meat into the fridge for at least 2 hours or overnight to let the flavor absorb better.
ec5facbb-2cb9-47fd-b505-bb87fbc6d40d
Thread the meat onto skewers. I recommend 4-6 pieces per skewer depending on how large the pieces are.
ec5facbb-2cb9-47fd-b505-bb87fbc6d40d
Setup smoker for cooking indirect at about 225-240°F. If the smoker uses a water pan, fill it up. Use pecan, cherry and/or maple for wood smoke.
ec5facbb-2cb9-47fd-b505-bb87fbc6d40d
Place the meat on the grate and smoke cook for about 2 hours and 10 minutes or until they reach an internal temperature of 185-190°F.
ec5facbb-2cb9-47fd-b505-bb87fbc6d40d
Optional: Brush with barbecue sauce and place the skewers over a hot grill or under the oven broiler for a minute or two per side to get a good sear on them.
ec5facbb-2cb9-47fd-b505-bb87fbc6d40d
Serve to your guests.
5438c81b-f9be-437b-94d7-13140071edd8
Dry brine the turkey by sprinkling kosher salt evenly over the breast, legs, wings and back of the turkey. Total salt usage should be about 2 TBS. Place the turkey in the fridge uncovered for about 8 hours or overnight.
5438c81b-f9be-437b-94d7-13140071edd8
Mix together 1 cup of mayonnaise with about ½ bottle of Jeff's original rub (½ cup).
5438c81b-f9be-437b-94d7-13140071edd8
Make sure the turkey is nice and dry then apply the mayonnaise/rub mixture all over the outside of the turkey. Get some under the skin wherever possible.
5438c81b-f9be-437b-94d7-13140071edd8
Set up Pit Barrel Cooker according to directions in manual. If using a regular smoker, set it up to cook at about 240°F using indirect heat.
5438c81b-f9be-437b-94d7-13140071edd8
Place the turkey in the Pit Barrel using hooks or the special turkey hanger. You can also just set it on the included grate if you prefer.
5438c81b-f9be-437b-94d7-13140071edd8
Let the turkey cook in the PBC for approximately 4 hours or until a thermometer reads 165°F in the thickest part of the breast or thigh. If you are cooking at a lower temperature such as 240°F using a normal smoker, the time will be closer to 6 or 7 hours.
5438c81b-f9be-437b-94d7-13140071edd8
When the turkey reaches the finish temperature, remove it from the cooker/smoker and let it rest under foil for about 20 minutes before carving.
5438c81b-f9be-437b-94d7-13140071edd8
Enjoy!
b858a339-cce3-48f4-9485-0613bdd4393a
Make a brine by mixing a gallon of cold water, 1 cup of kosher salt and 1 cup of brown sugar. Mix until dissolved.
b858a339-cce3-48f4-9485-0613bdd4393a
Place the chicken into a large plastic container and pour the brine over the chicken to cover. Place contain in the fridge for 3 hours. Rinse chicken with cold water when complete
b858a339-cce3-48f4-9485-0613bdd4393a
Pat the chicken dry with a paper towel and put back into brining container.
b858a339-cce3-48f4-9485-0613bdd4393a
Cover chicken with about 1 cup of Jeff's original rub and stir to coat or place lid on container and shake to coat.
b858a339-cce3-48f4-9485-0613bdd4393a
Setup smoker for cooking at about 180°F using indirect heat. If you have a water pan, leave it dry.
b858a339-cce3-48f4-9485-0613bdd4393a
Place chicken on smoker grate and smoke cook at 180°F for 45-60 minutes.
b858a339-cce3-48f4-9485-0613bdd4393a
Increase smoker temperature to 350-400°F if possible and continue cooking wings for about 30 minutes or until they reach 180°F in the thickest part.
4b54abd0-6115-404b-891e-ffba0bdf54d9 Prepare Pork Butt I recommend a boneless pork butt. If you purchase a bone-in, you will need to remove the bone with a sharp knife prior to cooking.
4b54abd0-6115-404b-891e-ffba0bdf54d9 Prepare Pork Butt To create a nice round shape for slicing, tie the pork butt up along the length and from end to end.
4b54abd0-6115-404b-891e-ffba0bdf54d9 Prepare Pork Butt Add a thin coat of mustard all over and then apply a heavy coat of Jeff's original rub. The pork butt is ready to smoke or it can be placed in the fridge overnight.
4b54abd0-6115-404b-891e-ffba0bdf54d9 Smoke Time Set up the smoker for cooking at about 250°F using indirect heat and if you smoker has a water pan, fill it up. If you are using a gas, charcoal, or electric smoker, you need to have enough smoking wood to last about 4 hours. I used an equal mix of apple and cherry but you can use whatever smoking wood you have available. Once the smoker is ready, place the pork butt on the smoker grate.
4b54abd0-6115-404b-891e-ffba0bdf54d9 Smoke Time Once the meat reaches 175°F (about 8 hours), remove it from the smoker and set the pan on the counter for about an hour to rest and cool down.
4b54abd0-6115-404b-891e-ffba0bdf54d9 Cool and Slice Let the roast cool for about an hour then place it in the fridge for about 5-6 hours or overnight to firm up for slicing.
4b54abd0-6115-404b-891e-ffba0bdf54d9 Cool and Slice Slice the smoked pork butt with an electric slicer or a very sharp knife into pieces that are about 1/8 inch thick.
4b54abd0-6115-404b-891e-ffba0bdf54d9 Prepare the Slider Components Make the campfire sauce using 1 cup of Jeff's barbecue sauce and 1 cup of mayonnaise. Mix thoroughly.
4b54abd0-6115-404b-891e-ffba0bdf54d9 Prepare the Slider Components Spread a thin layer of softened butter onto the tops and bottoms of each slider bun and toast under the broiler until golden brown. Watch carefully and do not burn.
4b54abd0-6115-404b-891e-ffba0bdf54d9 Prepare the Slider Components Warm the sliced meat in a 275°F oven covered with foil for about 15 minutes.
4b54abd0-6115-404b-891e-ffba0bdf54d9 Assemble the Sliders Place a dollop of campfire sauce on the bottom, stack 3-4 layers of meat on top of that, a spoonful of slaw, more campfire sauce on top with a toasted bun.
4b54abd0-6115-404b-891e-ffba0bdf54d9 Assemble the Sliders Serve immediately!
0b04b701-f795-4979-af49-f194ce4ed5fe
Cut the link of smoked sausage into ½ inch pieces.
0b04b701-f795-4979-af49-f194ce4ed5fe
Cut the slab of bacon in half.
0b04b701-f795-4979-af49-f194ce4ed5fe
Combine the cream cheese with 3 TBS of Jeff's original rub and spoon into a quart sized zip to bag. Snip off a small corner at the bottom for piping the cream cheese into the "cups".
0b04b701-f795-4979-af49-f194ce4ed5fe
Wrap a half slice of bacon around a piece of smoked sausage and secure all the way through with a toothpick.
0b04b701-f795-4979-af49-f194ce4ed5fe
Place a cube of cheddar cheese into the bacon cup
0b04b701-f795-4979-af49-f194ce4ed5fe
Pipe cream cheese filling into the cup until it's just below the top of the bacon.
0b04b701-f795-4979-af49-f194ce4ed5fe
Spoon in about ½ teaspoon of diced onions and sprinkle more of Jeff's original rub on top.
0b04b701-f795-4979-af49-f194ce4ed5fe
Setup your smoker for cooking at about 250°F with indirect heat and apple wood for smoke. If your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up.
0b04b701-f795-4979-af49-f194ce4ed5fe
Place the pig shots on a Weber grill pan, Bradley rack or even a cooling rack and place that into the smoker for about 90 minutes or until the bacon has a good eating texture and the cheese is melted.
0b04b701-f795-4979-af49-f194ce4ed5fe
Remove the pig shots from the smoker and serve immediately.
778f0a01-0c6b-4f3f-bdc8-42612987f729
Rub the pork butt with thin coat of yellow mustard. You can omit this step but it helps the rub to stick better.
778f0a01-0c6b-4f3f-bdc8-42612987f729
Apply Jeff's original rub onto all sides of the roast.
778f0a01-0c6b-4f3f-bdc8-42612987f729
Set the meat aside while you get the smoker ready to cook.
778f0a01-0c6b-4f3f-bdc8-42612987f729
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-250°F using indirect heat.
778f0a01-0c6b-4f3f-bdc8-42612987f729
If your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up.
778f0a01-0c6b-4f3f-bdc8-42612987f729
Place the meat directly on the smoker grate and close the lid. If you are using a pellet grill/smoker, I recommend starting out in the special "Smoke" setting for about 1 hour then adjust to 225-250°F
778f0a01-0c6b-4f3f-bdc8-42612987f729
When the meat reaches 160°F, it's a great idea to place it into a foil pan to catch the drippings and to help it to cook faster.
778f0a01-0c6b-4f3f-bdc8-42612987f729
Use a thermometer such as the ThermoWorks Smoke to monitor the internal temperature of the roast.
778f0a01-0c6b-4f3f-bdc8-42612987f729
When the meat reaches 205-207 °F it is done and perfectly tender.
778f0a01-0c6b-4f3f-bdc8-42612987f729
Allow it to rest under a tent of foil for about an hour before proceeding.
778f0a01-0c6b-4f3f-bdc8-42612987f729
Pull the meat into pieces using a couple of forks and discard any fat and gristle that you find.
778f0a01-0c6b-4f3f-bdc8-42612987f729
Serve with Jeff's barbecue sauce on the side.
74414f2d-ede3-4430-aac8-7a464620bf9a
Lay the tri-tip on a cutting board or in a pan.
74414f2d-ede3-4430-aac8-7a464620bf9a
Sprinkle coarse kosher salt onto the top of the meat at a coverage of about 1 teaspoon per lb.
74414f2d-ede3-4430-aac8-7a464620bf9a
Place the meat in the fridge for 2 hours.
74414f2d-ede3-4430-aac8-7a464620bf9a
Flip the meat over and dry brine the bottom side with the same coverage of coarse kosher salt.
74414f2d-ede3-4430-aac8-7a464620bf9a
No need to rinse.
74414f2d-ede3-4430-aac8-7a464620bf9a
Season the top and sides of the tri-tip with Jeff's Texas style rub (purchase recipes here).
74414f2d-ede3-4430-aac8-7a464620bf9a
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F using a blend of hickory, maple and apple or whatever smoking wood you have available.
74414f2d-ede3-4430-aac8-7a464620bf9a
Place the tri-tip on the smoker grate.
74414f2d-ede3-4430-aac8-7a464620bf9a
Combine butter and rub ingredients and keep the mop warm stirring occasionally while you use it.
74414f2d-ede3-4430-aac8-7a464620bf9a
Mop the meat with this mixture about every 20-30 minutes while it cooks to keep the meat moist.
74414f2d-ede3-4430-aac8-7a464620bf9a
Let the meat cook for about 2 hours with smoke or until it reaches about 130°F internal temperature as measured by a digital remote meat thermometer.
74414f2d-ede3-4430-aac8-7a464620bf9a
Let the meat rest under foil for about 10 to 15 minutes then slice against the grain at about ¼ inch thick.
74414f2d-ede3-4430-aac8-7a464620bf9a
Serve and enjoy!
405fad5c-a970-4dc9-999b-0e9a538a8e80 Brine the Chicken(s) Make the brine in a large 1 gallon pitcher by adding the water, kosher salt and brown sugar.
405fad5c-a970-4dc9-999b-0e9a538a8e80 Brine the Chicken(s) Mix well until all ingredients are dissolved and the liquid becomes a clear amber color.
405fad5c-a970-4dc9-999b-0e9a538a8e80 Brine the Chicken(s) Place the chicken(s) into a zip top bag or other plastic or glass container and pour the brine over the chicken to cover. Place the container with the chicken into the fridge for about 4 hours.
405fad5c-a970-4dc9-999b-0e9a538a8e80 Brine the Chicken(s) At the end of the brining time, rinse the chicken under cold water and pat dry.
405fad5c-a970-4dc9-999b-0e9a538a8e80 Season the Birds Place the chickens over cans of beer, root beer or other soft drink and use the legs to support some of the weight.
405fad5c-a970-4dc9-999b-0e9a538a8e80 Season the Birds Mix 1 cup of mayonnaise with 3 tablespoons of Jeff's original rub and apply this mixture all over the outside of the chickens.
405fad5c-a970-4dc9-999b-0e9a538a8e80 Cook in the Smoker and Serve Preheat the smoker to 275°F and once it's ready place the chickens on the grate and cook until the internal temperature reaches 165 °F in the thickest part.
405fad5c-a970-4dc9-999b-0e9a538a8e80 Cook in the Smoker and Serve Rest the chicken for 10 minutes before serving.
dada4ed0-060a-4ff1-9c63-52f1a47bd267
Place the corned beef brisket into a pan, fat side down, for ease of cleanup.
dada4ed0-060a-4ff1-9c63-52f1a47bd267
Slather a thin coat of Dijon mustard on the top and sides of the brisket.
dada4ed0-060a-4ff1-9c63-52f1a47bd267
Apply Jeff's original rub (get the recipes here) generously all over the top and sides of the brisket and let it continue to sit until it get's a "wet" look. (about 10-15 minutes)
dada4ed0-060a-4ff1-9c63-52f1a47bd267
Flip the brisket over to fat cap up and repeat the mustard and rub on the fatty side of the brisket.
dada4ed0-060a-4ff1-9c63-52f1a47bd267
Let the brisket sit while you go get the smoker ready for cooking at 240°F using indirect heat.
dada4ed0-060a-4ff1-9c63-52f1a47bd267
Place the pan of brisket on the smoker grate and let it cook until it reaches about 160°F.
dada4ed0-060a-4ff1-9c63-52f1a47bd267
Cover the top of the pan with a piece of foil and let it continue cooking with just heat until the meat reaches a temperature of 195-200°F.
dada4ed0-060a-4ff1-9c63-52f1a47bd267
Use a skewer or toothpick to check for tenderness. It should have little to no resistance when inserted.
dada4ed0-060a-4ff1-9c63-52f1a47bd267
Let the meat rest with a piece of foil loosely tented over the top for approximately 30 minutes before slicing.
f2dd996d-ff4d-4a13-bfa5-03c6ae89f9ab
Lay the strips of pork belly on a flat sheet pan for dry brining.
f2dd996d-ff4d-4a13-bfa5-03c6ae89f9ab
Sprinkle salt on the top side of the meat at about 10% coverage then place in the fridge for 1 hour.
f2dd996d-ff4d-4a13-bfa5-03c6ae89f9ab
Flip the meat over, salt the other side in the same way and place it back in the fridge for another hour.
f2dd996d-ff4d-4a13-bfa5-03c6ae89f9ab
After the 2nd hour, the meat is ready to be seasoned with the original rub.
f2dd996d-ff4d-4a13-bfa5-03c6ae89f9ab
Season both sides liberally with Jeff's original rub waiting in between top side and bottom side for the rub to acquire that "wet' look before flipping them over.
f2dd996d-ff4d-4a13-bfa5-03c6ae89f9ab
Smoke the pork belly slices at 240°F for approximately 90 minutes or until they reach an internal temperature of 200-205 °F as measured by an instant-read hand-held digital thermometer such as the Thermapen or ThermoPop.
f2dd996d-ff4d-4a13-bfa5-03c6ae89f9ab
When finished, remove them from the smoker and let them cool for about an hour. You can also place them in the fridge to cool for longer if you are making them ahead of time.
f2dd996d-ff4d-4a13-bfa5-03c6ae89f9ab
Just before serving, heat a skillet or electric griddle to medium heat and cook both sides of the pork belly slices until they are seared but not blackened.
f2dd996d-ff4d-4a13-bfa5-03c6ae89f9ab
Serve immediately.
e15cdf5b-6be5-459b-a485-c30cf75da207
Make the cream cheese mixture by combining the softened cream cheese, ½ cup grated cheese, 1 tablespoon of Jeff's original rub and and 2 tablespoons of chopped jalapeños into a small to medium sized mixing bowl. Mix well.
e15cdf5b-6be5-459b-a485-c30cf75da207
Wrap the half pieces of bacon around the sausage slices and secure with a toothpick.
e15cdf5b-6be5-459b-a485-c30cf75da207
Fill the "cups" with the cream cheese but not all the way to the top. The bacon will shrink as it cooks.
e15cdf5b-6be5-459b-a485-c30cf75da207
Setup your smoker for indirect cooking at about 250-275°F or as close to this temperature as you can.
e15cdf5b-6be5-459b-a485-c30cf75da207
Place the pig shots on the smoker grate and smoke cook for approximately 90 minutes or until the bacon is cooked through and has good "bite-through" or texture.
e15cdf5b-6be5-459b-a485-c30cf75da207
When the appetizers are finished cooking, you can glaze with barbecue sauce if you like. I used my original barbecue sauce thinned with a little apple juice. Let the pig shots continue in the heat for about 10 minutes after cooking to allow the sauce to set.
e15cdf5b-6be5-459b-a485-c30cf75da207
Serve immediately.
5749b3d2-ed90-4585-b9ed-f5c502801efd
Thaw the cornish hens in the fridge for 1-2 days or in a sink of cold water, changing the water every 30 minutes until they are completely thawed.
5749b3d2-ed90-4585-b9ed-f5c502801efd
Cut along both sides of the backbone to to remove the backbone and open up the chickens like a book.
5749b3d2-ed90-4585-b9ed-f5c502801efd
To dry brine the chickens, sprinkle about ½ teaspoon of kosher salt on the inside cavity of the birds and place them in the fridge for one hour.
5749b3d2-ed90-4585-b9ed-f5c502801efd
Remove from the fridge and flip over to skin side up. Sprinkle with about ¾ to 1 teaspoon of coarse kosher salt and place back into the fridge overnight or for 8-16 hours.
5749b3d2-ed90-4585-b9ed-f5c502801efd
There is no need to rinse the chickens after dry brining.
5749b3d2-ed90-4585-b9ed-f5c502801efd
Make a mayo/rub/herb mixture by mixing (1) cup of mayonnaise, (4) heaping TBS of Jeff's original rub, (2) TBS chopped parsley and (1) TBS chopped thyme.
5749b3d2-ed90-4585-b9ed-f5c502801efd
Place equal portions or a heaping TBS of the mixture onto the chicken and spread it all over the top and sides with your hands.
5749b3d2-ed90-4585-b9ed-f5c502801efd
The chicken is now ready to cook.
5749b3d2-ed90-4585-b9ed-f5c502801efd
Set up your smoker for cooking at 250-275°F and once it's ready, place the chicken directly on the grates, skin side up.
5749b3d2-ed90-4585-b9ed-f5c502801efd
Cook for approximately 1 hour or until it reaches 165°F in the thickest part of the breast.
5749b3d2-ed90-4585-b9ed-f5c502801efd
About 10 minutes before the chicken is finished cooking, mix 1 TBS of Jeff's original rub into a stick (¼ lb) of melted butter and brush that onto the tops of the chicken.
5749b3d2-ed90-4585-b9ed-f5c502801efd
Once the chicken is finished cooking, remove it from the smoker and serve immediately.
5749b3d2-ed90-4585-b9ed-f5c502801efd
07eb17de-50f2-4409-b12a-af81b15f358f
Trim the fat from the tri-tip using a sharp knife.
07eb17de-50f2-4409-b12a-af81b15f358f
To make the brine, pour 4-5 cups of coffee into a ½ gallon pitcher or large bowl.
07eb17de-50f2-4409-b12a-af81b15f358f
Add the kosher salt and stir until it is dissolved. Add the cocoa and red pepper flakes and stir well again to make sure the cocoa is dissolved into the liquid.
07eb17de-50f2-4409-b12a-af81b15f358f
If the coffee is still warm, it will need to be cooled before use.
07eb17de-50f2-4409-b12a-af81b15f358f
Place the meat into a shallow container or even a 1- gallon sized ziptop bag and pour the brine over the meat to cover. Place in the fridge for about 3 hours.
07eb17de-50f2-4409-b12a-af81b15f358f
Remove the meat from the fridge after brining. Set the meat aside and discard the brining liquid. There is no need to rinse the meat.
07eb17de-50f2-4409-b12a-af81b15f358f
Season the top side of the meat and the edges with Jeff's Texas style rub, flip it over and season the bottom side as well.
07eb17de-50f2-4409-b12a-af81b15f358f
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225°F using indirect heat. If your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up.
07eb17de-50f2-4409-b12a-af81b15f358f
Once your smoker is heated to 225-240°F and holding steady, Place the meat in the smoker and let it cook for approximately 2 hours with at least 1 hour of smoke action.
07eb17de-50f2-4409-b12a-af81b15f358f
At about the 110-115 degree mark, melt a stick of butter (¼ lb) and stir in 1 heaping TBS of the Texas style rub. Baste the meat liberally with this mixture.
07eb17de-50f2-4409-b12a-af81b15f358f
When the meat reaches 137°F or a perfect medium rare, remove it from the smoker and let it rest with foil tented over the top on the cabinet for about 10-15 minutes before slicing or cutting into it.
07eb17de-50f2-4409-b12a-af81b15f358f
Slice the meat pencil thick across the grain and serve immediately with plenty of vegetables and sides.
16bcf6ee-6bf6-4d64-9f48-9e744c50fa43
Clean and deseed the jalapenos then cut them into ¼ inch strips. Cut the block of cream cheese into 8 equally sized pieces. Set aside.
16bcf6ee-6bf6-4d64-9f48-9e744c50fa43
Clean the fat from the boneless, skinless chicken thighs. Lay them flat on the cutting board and season liberally on the inside with Jeff's original rub (purchase recipes here).
16bcf6ee-6bf6-4d64-9f48-9e744c50fa43
Lay a piece of the cream cheese and 2-3 pieces of the jalapeno strips in the center of each thigh and fold over to close.
16bcf6ee-6bf6-4d64-9f48-9e744c50fa43
Wrap a piece of stretched bacon around each chicken thigh to hold it closed. Place the stuffed and wrapped thighs into the holes of a muffin pan to help them hold their shape while they cook.
16bcf6ee-6bf6-4d64-9f48-9e744c50fa43
Season the top of the thighs with Jeff's original rub (purchase recipes here) and lay a small pat of butter on top of each.
16bcf6ee-6bf6-4d64-9f48-9e744c50fa43
Preheat the smoker to 275°F using indirect heat and hickory or pecan for smoke.
16bcf6ee-6bf6-4d64-9f48-9e744c50fa43
Once the smoker is ready, place the pan of chicken onto the grate of the smoker and let them cook for about 40 minutes.
16bcf6ee-6bf6-4d64-9f48-9e744c50fa43
After 35-40 minutes, cover the pan with a piece of foil to tenderize the chicken and let them continue cooking for about 20-25 minutes or until they reach 170-175°F.
16bcf6ee-6bf6-4d64-9f48-9e744c50fa43
When they are finished, remove from the pan and lay them on a cooling rack, cookie sheet or Weber grill pan. Coat with Jeff's barbecue sauce (purchase recipes here) and continue cooking for about 10 minutes to let the sauce set.
16bcf6ee-6bf6-4d64-9f48-9e744c50fa43
Remove from the smoker and serve immediately.
ed910e82-e4a1-4c32-b246-b68583731f51
Sprinkle coarse kosher salt onto top sirloin steaks and place into the fridge for 2 hours.
ed910e82-e4a1-4c32-b246-b68583731f51
Remove from fridge, flip them over and repeat salting on the other side. Leave steaks out to warm to room temperature for 1 hour. No need to rinse.
ed910e82-e4a1-4c32-b246-b68583731f51
Dry steaks well with paper towel then sear on all sides in heavy skillet over medium high heat with just a couple of TBS of vegetable oil.
ed910e82-e4a1-4c32-b246-b68583731f51
Let the steaks cool for a few minutes then coat with Jeff's Texas style rub on all sides.
ed910e82-e4a1-4c32-b246-b68583731f51
Setup smoker for cooking at 230°F with indirect heat.
ed910e82-e4a1-4c32-b246-b68583731f51
When the smoker is ready, place the steaks on the grate and let them smoke cook with oak or whatever smoking wood you have available.
ed910e82-e4a1-4c32-b246-b68583731f51
At about 30 minutes in, baste the steaks with a concoction of ½ cup low sodium soy sauce, ½ cup Worcestershire, and ¼ cup of olive oil. Stir the ingredients constantly as you use it to keep them from separating.
ed910e82-e4a1-4c32-b246-b68583731f51
When the steaks reach 137°F as measured with a meat thermometer, remove them from the smoker and let them rest for 4-7 minutes.
ed910e82-e4a1-4c32-b246-b68583731f51
They can be sliced into ¼ inch slices or served as whole steaks.
6c2c0fec-d2d2-48ff-b98e-9abfe09ad548
If meatballs are frozen, place them in the fridge for a few hours or up to a day to thaw.
6c2c0fec-d2d2-48ff-b98e-9abfe09ad548
Wrap half pieces of bacon around each meatball and secure with a toothpick.
6c2c0fec-d2d2-48ff-b98e-9abfe09ad548
Place the meatballs on a Bradley rack, Weber grill pan or a cooling rack to make them easy to carry to and from the smoker.
6c2c0fec-d2d2-48ff-b98e-9abfe09ad548
Season on all sides with a low salt barbecue rub such as my original rub recipe.
6c2c0fec-d2d2-48ff-b98e-9abfe09ad548
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 240°F using indirect heat and hickory or pecan for smoke.
6c2c0fec-d2d2-48ff-b98e-9abfe09ad548
If your smoker has a water pan, fill it up with hot water.
6c2c0fec-d2d2-48ff-b98e-9abfe09ad548
When the smoker is ready to go place the wrapped meatballs on the smoker grate and let them cook for 2 hours or until they reach an internal temperature of 160 and the bacon is firm.
6c2c0fec-d2d2-48ff-b98e-9abfe09ad548
When the meatballs are finished or nearly finished cooking, glaze the outside of the meatballs with barbecue sauce thinned with beer, juice, melted butter, etc.
6c2c0fec-d2d2-48ff-b98e-9abfe09ad548
Let the glaze set for about 10 minutes then bring them in and serve right away.
6a209195-475e-47a5-929a-60f13595725d
Rinse pork tenderloins with cold water.
6a209195-475e-47a5-929a-60f13595725d
Use a sharp knife to remove any extra fat and silver skin.
6a209195-475e-47a5-929a-60f13595725d
Coat the outside of each tenderloin with a tablespoon of mayonnaise.
6a209195-475e-47a5-929a-60f13595725d
Generously sprinkle Jeff's original rub on to all sides of the pork tenderloins.
6a209195-475e-47a5-929a-60f13595725d
Prepare your smoker for cooking at 225-240°F with indirect heat.
6a209195-475e-47a5-929a-60f13595725d
If your smoker has a water pan, fill it up with water or liquid of your choice.
6a209195-475e-47a5-929a-60f13595725d
When the smoker is ready, place the pork tenderloins on the smoker grate and close the door/lid.
6a209195-475e-47a5-929a-60f13595725d
Prepare the maple barbecue glaze by mixing 1 cup of maple syrup to 2 heaping tablespoons of Jeff's original rub. Stir well to combine.
6a209195-475e-47a5-929a-60f13595725d
Baste the meat with the glaze every 30 minutes until it is finished cooking.
6a209195-475e-47a5-929a-60f13595725d
When the pork reaches 145°F as measured with a digital meat thermometer, it is perfectly done and should be removed from the smoker right away.
6a209195-475e-47a5-929a-60f13595725d
Allow the meat to rest under foil for about 10 minutes before slicing.
6a209195-475e-47a5-929a-60f13595725d
Serve and enjoy!
9c48a397-3661-4d96-83ec-8e046f974d91
Remove the rind from the pork belly using a sharp knife.
9c48a397-3661-4d96-83ec-8e046f974d91
Place the pork belly in the freezer for 30 minutes to allow the fat to get really solid so it will cut more easily.
9c48a397-3661-4d96-83ec-8e046f974d91
With the pork belly laying in front of you on a cutting board, slice the pork belly into pieces that are about 1.5 inches wide. Further cut the slices into pieces that are 1.5 inches wide giving you cubes of meat that are 1.5 x 1.5 inches square.
9c48a397-3661-4d96-83ec-8e046f974d91
Place ⅓ cup of Jeff's original rub into a zip top back and then place 2 lbs of meat into the bag. Shake and massage bag to coat the meat with the rub. Pour the coated pieces of meat out onto a cutting board or bowl.
9c48a397-3661-4d96-83ec-8e046f974d91
