Arrange the pieces of meat onto a cooling rack, Bradley rack or Weber grill pan to make them easy to move into and out of the smoker.
9c48a397-3661-4d96-83ec-8e046f974d91
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-240 °F using indirect heat. If your smoker has a water pan, fill it up. When the smoker is ready, place the racks of meat onto the smoker grate and quickly close the lid/door.
9c48a397-3661-4d96-83ec-8e046f974d91
Let the meat cook and smoke until a crust forms and the bark on the outside of the meat starts to turn to a light mahogany.
9c48a397-3661-4d96-83ec-8e046f974d91
Place the meat into a foil pan and coat with about ¼ to ⅓ cup of honey and ¼ to ½ cup of Jeff's barbecue sauce per 2 lbs of meat. Optional, you can omit the barbecue sauce and add 2-3 heaping tablespoons of hot pepper jelly with the honey. Mix the glaze with the meat.
9c48a397-3661-4d96-83ec-8e046f974d91
Cover the pan with foil and place back into he smoker for an additional 60-90 minutes or until the meat reaches 200°F. (no smoke required).
9c48a397-3661-4d96-83ec-8e046f974d91
When the pork belly burnt ends are finished cooking, remove the foil and let them cool for a few minutes before serving.
bde1c6d7-d806-406d-b74e-38a70b47a6c4
Trim fat and silver skin from the top of the beef short ribs. Sprinkle about 1 to 1.5 tsp of coarse kosher salt onto the top of the beef ribs to and place them in the fridge for 4 hours. When 4 hours is up, there is no need to rinse. Generously sprinkle my Texas style rub onto the top and sides of the ribs and let them sit while you go get the smoker ready. Fire up the smoker and let it preheat to 240°F using indirect heat. If your smoker uses a water pan, fill it up. Place the seasoned beef short ribs into the smoker on a shallow pan. Make the basting sauce using 2 cups of root beer, 1 cup of low sodium soy sauce and 1 cup of Worcestershire. Pour the basting sauce over the meat and let it run down into the pan. Continue basting the meat with the sauce from the pan using a turkey baster every 30-45 minutes while it cooks in the smoker. When the beef short ribs are fork tender they are finished cooking. This is usually at 190-195°F but can be lower or higher than that. Let the meat rest under foil for about 10 minutes before slicing and serving.
83f49b6f-1c5a-480f-884d-c96d6a511912
Using ⅓ lb of beef, form balls in your hands. Smash them into patties that are about the same size as your buns. Use your thumb to dimple the center of the burger patty. Place the burgers in the fridge until ready to use them. Once ready to use, sprinkle the top side of the burgers generously with Jeff's Texas style rub recipe. Preheat smoker to 225 using indirect heat. Place burgers on smoker grate and smoke for about 1 hour or until they reach 150°F in the center. While the burgers are smoking, prepare all of the vegetables, grill the onions if desired and grill the buns. Set up a very hot gas or charcoal grill and when the burgers reach 150°F, sear both sides for about 1 minute. Just before the burgers are done, lay a piece of cheese over the meat so it can melt. Build the burgers or let each person make their own.
fd4afec7-a43a-4099-86f8-20f69272662a
Rinse chicken drumsticks with cold water and pat dry with a paper towel.
fd4afec7-a43a-4099-86f8-20f69272662a
Place chicken on a wire rack or sheet pan and place in fridge for several hours to help dry the skin. This helps to ensure a better texture in the finished skin.
fd4afec7-a43a-4099-86f8-20f69272662a
While the chicken is drying, mix up the Alabama white sauce using 2 cups of mayonnaise, 1/2 cup of apple cider vinegar, 1/4 cup of finely ground black pepper and 1 teaspoon of cayenne pepper. Mix until smooth and refrigerate until needed.
fd4afec7-a43a-4099-86f8-20f69272662a
Once you are ready to season the chicken, brush some of the Alabama white sauce onto the chicken then coat the outside of the chicken with Jeff's original rub. This can be done the night before or 8-10 hours in advance if desired.
fd4afec7-a43a-4099-86f8-20f69272662a
Setup your smoker for cooking at 225-240°F using indirect heat. If your smoker has a water pan, leave it dry if possible to reduce humidity and help the chicken skin to end up with a better texture.
fd4afec7-a43a-4099-86f8-20f69272662a
Place the chicken on the smoker grate and let it smoke with a mix of maple, cherry and hickory or whatever smoking wood you have available. Leave the chicken alone for about 30 minutes.
fd4afec7-a43a-4099-86f8-20f69272662a
After 30 minutes you can crank the heat up to about 275°F if your smoker is capable of higher heat otherwise, maintain normal smoking temperatures.
fd4afec7-a43a-4099-86f8-20f69272662a
We will also begin brushing the Alabama white sauce on the chicken every 15 minutes until it is finished cooking.
fd4afec7-a43a-4099-86f8-20f69272662a
When the chicken reaches 180°F as measured by an accurate meat thermometer, it is finished and should be removed from the smoker.
fd4afec7-a43a-4099-86f8-20f69272662a
Serve immediately with more white sauce for dipping.
846c197a-0e2a-4451-a072-55d32475d49b
Wash the jalapeños
846c197a-0e2a-4451-a072-55d32475d49b
Cut off the stems and remove the seeds and veins
846c197a-0e2a-4451-a072-55d32475d49b
Cut the peppers in half lengthwise so they become boats.
846c197a-0e2a-4451-a072-55d32475d49b
Combine 16 oz of cream cheese, 2 cups of shredded extra sharp cheddar and ½ cup of Jeff's original rub into a large bowl. Mix well.
846c197a-0e2a-4451-a072-55d32475d49b
Stuff the mixture into the boats just slightly heaped up over the edges.
846c197a-0e2a-4451-a072-55d32475d49b
Cut the bacon slices in half and wrap a half slice of bacon around each stuffed pepper.
846c197a-0e2a-4451-a072-55d32475d49b
Place the stuffed, bacon wrapped jalapeños onto a Bradley rack for easy transport into and out of the smoker.
846c197a-0e2a-4451-a072-55d32475d49b
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 230°F and enough wood for about 2 hours of smoke.
846c197a-0e2a-4451-a072-55d32475d49b
Smoke cook the stuffed jalapeños for 3 hours or until the peppers are wimpy and the bacon is done and has good bite thru.
846c197a-0e2a-4451-a072-55d32475d49b
Serve immediately.
fcc6d735-17e6-49d2-8c29-9ca82733f138
Remove the turkey roast from it's plastic net and packaging but leave it in the cotton net. Rinse the meat, net and all, under cold water.
fcc6d735-17e6-49d2-8c29-9ca82733f138
Set the roast aside and make a brine solution of ½ gallon of water, ½ cup coarse kosher salt and ½ cup brown sugar. Mix well until everything is dissolved.
fcc6d735-17e6-49d2-8c29-9ca82733f138
Place the netted roast down into the brine and place it in the fridge for 4 hours. After 4 hours, remove the meat from the brine and rinse well under cold water. Pat dry with a paper towel.
fcc6d735-17e6-49d2-8c29-9ca82733f138
Pour olive or vegetable oil all over the roast making sure it is well coated. Sprinkle Jeff's original rub onto all sides of the roast-- be generous.
fcc6d735-17e6-49d2-8c29-9ca82733f138
Place 3-4 pieces of bacon into the net if you are planning to hang it in your smoker or place the roast on a rack with the bacon draped over it if you plan to cook it on the grate.
fcc6d735-17e6-49d2-8c29-9ca82733f138
If hanging on a Bradley rack, push the net through one of the holes and thread a chopstick through to hold it in place. You can also use a spoon handle or other similar object.
fcc6d735-17e6-49d2-8c29-9ca82733f138
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225°F with indirect heat.
fcc6d735-17e6-49d2-8c29-9ca82733f138
Place the meat in the smoker and close the lid/door. Keep the smoke going for about 3 hours.
fcc6d735-17e6-49d2-8c29-9ca82733f138
The turkey roast should take about 5-6 hours to reach 160°F at which point it should be removed and allowed to rest for 10-15 minutes with foil tented over it.
fcc6d735-17e6-49d2-8c29-9ca82733f138
Once rested, cut the net and carefully remove it from the roast. Slice the meat as thick as you like and serve immediately with mashed potatoes, corn, peas, gravy and all of the fixins.
fcc6d735-17e6-49d2-8c29-9ca82733f138
Enjoy!
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
Remove ribs from package and rinse under cold water.
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
Cut brisket bone and square ends to make them St. Louis style spare ribs.
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
Remove membrane.
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
Generously coat bone side of ribs with Jeff's original rub.
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
Wait about 10 minutes for the rub to take on a "wet" look. This means the rub has mixed with the rib juices and will stick to the ribs without falling off when you turn them over.
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
Flip the ribs over to meaty side up and coat the top and sides with generous amounts of Jeff's original rub.
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
With the ribs on a cookie sheet, place them in the fridge overnight to allow the flavors in the rub to seep into the meat.
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 230 °F with indirect heat. If your smoker has a water pan, fill it up with hot water.
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
Follow this cooking schedule:
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
-4 hrs @ 230°F - laid on grate with pecan/cherry smoke
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
-2 hrs @ 230°F - wrapped (no smoke required)
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
-2hrs @ 200°F - wrapped (no smoke required)
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
-1.5 hrs @ 170°F - wrapped (no smoke required)
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
Remove the ribs from the foil and pull the bones out of the meat.
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
Slice the meat into ribs that are about 1-inch wide.
f60ba592-7409-4162-ab0d-24439c122be7
Serve right away.
217727e3-f723-4705-9190-458414ad2e30
Place the chicken wings on a cooling rack over a sheet pan and pat dry with a paper towel.
217727e3-f723-4705-9190-458414ad2e30
Set the chicken in the fridge to allow the skin to dry for about 4 hours or optimally overnight.
217727e3-f723-4705-9190-458414ad2e30
Apply a coat of mayonnaise all over the chicken.
217727e3-f723-4705-9190-458414ad2e30
Season the chicken wings liberally with Jeff's original rub recipe.
217727e3-f723-4705-9190-458414ad2e30
Setup your smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F using indirect heat and hickory wood for smoke.
217727e3-f723-4705-9190-458414ad2e30
Place the chicken wings directly on the smoker grate and let them cook for about 1.5 hours or until they reach 165°F in the thickest part of the meat.
217727e3-f723-4705-9190-458414ad2e30
Make a glaze of ½ cup Smucker's apricot simplyfruit® or any apricot spreadable fruit and ½ cup honey.
217727e3-f723-4705-9190-458414ad2e30
Heat the ingredients in a small saucepan to help the mixture to combine more easily.
217727e3-f723-4705-9190-458414ad2e30
Once the glaze is finished, brush it liberally onto the chicken wings.
217727e3-f723-4705-9190-458414ad2e30
Let the wings continue cooking until they reach about 175-180°F in the thickest part.
217727e3-f723-4705-9190-458414ad2e30
Serve the wings immediately.
91e062cd-97b5-41ce-8c19-0ffac9bc3eb5
Place lamb loin chops on a cooling rack or cookie sheet.
91e062cd-97b5-41ce-8c19-0ffac9bc3eb5
To dry brine, sprinkle salt generously on the top of the chops.
91e062cd-97b5-41ce-8c19-0ffac9bc3eb5
Place the chops in the fridge for 2 hours.
91e062cd-97b5-41ce-8c19-0ffac9bc3eb5
Remove the chops from the fridge, no rinsing is necessary.
91e062cd-97b5-41ce-8c19-0ffac9bc3eb5
Make an infusion of rosemary and olive oil by pouring ¼ cup of olive oil over 1 tablespoon of chopped rosemary. Let the infusion sit for about an hour before you use it if possible.
91e062cd-97b5-41ce-8c19-0ffac9bc3eb5
Brush the olive oil/rosemary on the top and sides of the lamb chops.
91e062cd-97b5-41ce-8c19-0ffac9bc3eb5
Sprinkle the top, bottom and sides of the chops with Jeff's original rub. Be as generous as you like.. it's low in salt and big on flavor.
91e062cd-97b5-41ce-8c19-0ffac9bc3eb5
Set up your smoker for cooking at 225°F with indirect heat.
91e062cd-97b5-41ce-8c19-0ffac9bc3eb5
Use a mix of pecan and apple for smoke for great results.
91e062cd-97b5-41ce-8c19-0ffac9bc3eb5
Monitor the internal temperature of the chops and when they reach 138 °F (medium rare) they are finished and should be removed from the smoker right away. This should take about 50 minutes.
91e062cd-97b5-41ce-8c19-0ffac9bc3eb5
Let the chops rest on the counter with foil tented over them for about 5-7 minutes.
91e062cd-97b5-41ce-8c19-0ffac9bc3eb5
Serve with a couple of Easter worthy sides and enjoy!
098fd4b7-56b8-4a9d-95b5-a653a320e5dd
Sprinkle coarse kosher salt onto the top side of the tomahawk steaks.
098fd4b7-56b8-4a9d-95b5-a653a320e5dd
Set the steaks on a cooling rack over a large pan in the fridge for 2 hours to let the salt melt and soak in.
098fd4b7-56b8-4a9d-95b5-a653a320e5dd
Flip the steaks over and repeat the salt and fridge time for 2 hours on the reverse side.
098fd4b7-56b8-4a9d-95b5-a653a320e5dd
Brush olive oil onto the top and sides of the steak and season liberally with Jeff's Texas style rub. Repeat the oil and seasoning on the reverse side of the steaks and they are ready for the smoker.
098fd4b7-56b8-4a9d-95b5-a653a320e5dd
Preheat the smoker to 225°F and once it's ready, place the steaks directly on the smoker grate.
098fd4b7-56b8-4a9d-95b5-a653a320e5dd
Let the steaks cook for about 1.5 hours or until they reach 100-110°F in the center.
098fd4b7-56b8-4a9d-95b5-a653a320e5dd
At this point, sear the steaks on a hot grill, over live coals or under the broiler of your oven. The idea is to get a good browning on the outside of the steaks for flavor.
098fd4b7-56b8-4a9d-95b5-a653a320e5dd
Let the steaks rest under tented foil for 10 minutes then slice ¼ inch thick and serve.
8815d768-a851-491c-abc6-fed21ee987cb
Put the country style ribs in a foil pan
8815d768-a851-491c-abc6-fed21ee987cb
Spray the top of the ribs with Cherry Dr Pepper.
8815d768-a851-491c-abc6-fed21ee987cb
Generously sprinkle the original rub on the top of the meat.
8815d768-a851-491c-abc6-fed21ee987cb
Turn the meat ¼ turn and repeat the Dr Pepper and rub.
8815d768-a851-491c-abc6-fed21ee987cb
Repeat the process 2 more times so that all 4 sides of the country style ribs are coated with rub.
8815d768-a851-491c-abc6-fed21ee987cb
Set up the smoker for cooking at about 240°F with indirect heat.
8815d768-a851-491c-abc6-fed21ee987cb
Place the meat directly on the smoker grate and close the lid/door.
8815d768-a851-491c-abc6-fed21ee987cb
Let the meat smoke with mesquite or hickory wood for about 1 hour.
8815d768-a851-491c-abc6-fed21ee987cb
If you have the ability to crank up the heat on the smoker, take it up to about 275 and let the country style ribs cook until they reach an internal temperature of 185°F.
8815d768-a851-491c-abc6-fed21ee987cb
Mix equal parts Cherry Dr Pepper with Jeff's original barbecue sauce and stir well to combine.
8815d768-a851-491c-abc6-fed21ee987cb
Brush the sauce onto the ribs and leave them for about 10 minutes to let the sauce caramelize.
8815d768-a851-491c-abc6-fed21ee987cb
Remove the meat from the smoker and serve immediately.
6d60aff3-72ee-4eb2-b4fd-07b2bcd22ece
Remove the corned beef brisket from the package.
6d60aff3-72ee-4eb2-b4fd-07b2bcd22ece
To remove extra salt, soak the meat in cold water in the fridge, changing out the water every 30 minutes.
6d60aff3-72ee-4eb2-b4fd-07b2bcd22ece
Three to four hours should be plenty of soak time to remove the extra salt.
6d60aff3-72ee-4eb2-b4fd-07b2bcd22ece
Remove any excess fat on the non fat cap side of the brisket.
6d60aff3-72ee-4eb2-b4fd-07b2bcd22ece
Coat the entire corned beef brisket with horseradish mustard then apply Jeff's original rub liberally to all sides.
6d60aff3-72ee-4eb2-b4fd-07b2bcd22ece
Pat the rub down as it is applied rather than massaging it in.
6d60aff3-72ee-4eb2-b4fd-07b2bcd22ece
Set up smoker for cooking at 225°F with hickory smoke.
6d60aff3-72ee-4eb2-b4fd-07b2bcd22ece
Place the corned beef brisket on the smoker grate and smoke cook for 2-3 hours or until it reaches 130-140°F in the center of the thickest part.
6d60aff3-72ee-4eb2-b4fd-07b2bcd22ece
Make a mustard sauce by mixing equal parts of Jeff's original barbecue sauce with horseradish mustard such as Dijon or Grey Poupon.
6d60aff3-72ee-4eb2-b4fd-07b2bcd22ece
Create a pad of mustard in the bottom of a pan and lay the meat on the pad fat cap side up.
6d60aff3-72ee-4eb2-b4fd-07b2bcd22ece
Brush more of the mustard sauce onto the fat cap and cover tightly with foil.
6d60aff3-72ee-4eb2-b4fd-07b2bcd22ece
Place the meat back into the smoker at 225°F and continue cooking until it reaches 185°F in the thickest part.
6d60aff3-72ee-4eb2-b4fd-07b2bcd22ece
Let the meat rest under foil for 30 minutes then slice pencil thick and serve.
2bc59d10-eebd-4216-a986-d500fdce9b64
Make the buttermilk brine by mixing 1 quart of buttermilk with ¼ cup of coarse kosher salt. Stir in salt until dissolved.
2bc59d10-eebd-4216-a986-d500fdce9b64
Sprinkle Jeff's original rub generously on one side of the chicken tenderloins and stir them around to coat.
2bc59d10-eebd-4216-a986-d500fdce9b64
Pour brine over chicken to cover.
2bc59d10-eebd-4216-a986-d500fdce9b64
Place the chicken in the fridge for 1 hour.
2bc59d10-eebd-4216-a986-d500fdce9b64
Remove the chicken from the fridge and rinse the chicken well under cold water. Discard the brine.
2bc59d10-eebd-4216-a986-d500fdce9b64
Lay the chicken pieces on a flat surface and sprinkle Jeff's rub on both sides.
2bc59d10-eebd-4216-a986-d500fdce9b64
Place the chicken in the smoker and smoke for about 1 hour or until they reach 165 °F as measured by a digital meat thermometer such as the Thermapen.
2bc59d10-eebd-4216-a986-d500fdce9b64
Cut or shred the chicken into small pieces.
2bc59d10-eebd-4216-a986-d500fdce9b64
Add 1-2 TBS of Jeff's original barbecue sauce to 1 cup of shredded chicken.
2bc59d10-eebd-4216-a986-d500fdce9b64
Place the Tostitos® Scoops!® on a cookie sheet and fill with a small amount of chicken.
2bc59d10-eebd-4216-a986-d500fdce9b64
Cover the top of the chicken with shredded cheese and place under the broiler for a minute or two to melt the cheese. Make sure it does not burn.
2bc59d10-eebd-4216-a986-d500fdce9b64
Add sour cream, guacamole, jalapeños, chopped tomatoes, salsa, etc. on top of each chip and serve right away.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Peel and devein shrimp.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Place shrimp into a foil pan.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Add ¼ cup of chopped parsley to the top of the shrimp.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Add ½ chopped poblano or 1 chopped jalapeno to the top of the shrimp.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Cut the lemon and orange in half and squeeze the juice from the halves over the shrimp.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Sprinkle about 2 TBS of Jeff's original rub onto the shrimp.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Turn the shrimp over or just toss them with a spoon.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Sprinkle another 2 TBS of Jeff's original rub onto the top of the shrimp.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Give the shrimp another toss and place the pan into the fridge for 2 hours to marinate.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Melt 2 sticks of butter and pour it over the shrimp. If you need more to cover better, melt another stick.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Set up the smoker for cooking at about 220°F using indirect heat.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Keep a light hickory or pecan smoke going for at least 30 minutes.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Check the shrimp after 40 minutes to make sure they aren't getting done to quick. When shrimp are done, the flesh will be slightly opaque (no longer transparent) and the shell will be pink to bright pink. The bite should be crisp, not rubbery.
88d13ef2-f977-4434-9d7c-a74be4d02980
Serve immediately when finished.
093dd0d3-09e5-4622-bca6-a8dd99eb88ee
To make the brine for this chicken, combine ½ cup of kosher salt into ½ gallon of water and stir until the mixture is clear. Set this aside.
093dd0d3-09e5-4622-bca6-a8dd99eb88ee
Place the chicken legs into a large plastic zip top bag and pour the brine mixture over the chicken to cover.
093dd0d3-09e5-4622-bca6-a8dd99eb88ee
Place the bag of chicken into a mixing bowl and into the fridge for 4 hours.
093dd0d3-09e5-4622-bca6-a8dd99eb88ee
Once the chicken is finished brining, rinse each piece under cold water and pat dry with paper towels.
093dd0d3-09e5-4622-bca6-a8dd99eb88ee
Further dry the chicken skin by placing it on a paper towel lined sheet pan and into the fridge for a couple of hours. This helps the skin to end up a little more crisp.
093dd0d3-09e5-4622-bca6-a8dd99eb88ee
Season the outside of the chicken with Jeff's original rub and it is ready to smoke.
093dd0d3-09e5-4622-bca6-a8dd99eb88ee
Setup the smoker or grill for cooking at about 275°F.
093dd0d3-09e5-4622-bca6-a8dd99eb88ee
Place the chicken on the grate and let it cook for about an hour or until it registers 180°F in the thickest part of the chicken. Note: chicken is safe to eat at 165°F however, chicken legs are often more tender if you cook them a little longer than what is required.
093dd0d3-09e5-4622-bca6-a8dd99eb88ee
Make mustard sauce by mixing equal parts yellow mustard with Jeff's original barbecue sauce.
093dd0d3-09e5-4622-bca6-a8dd99eb88ee
Brush on sauce during the last 10 minutes if desired
10452418-4d7b-48b9-9b8e-a54fe4039cf0
Tie up the pork loin using butchers twine to give it a round even shape.
10452418-4d7b-48b9-9b8e-a54fe4039cf0
Cut "X's" into the fat cap between the strings.
10452418-4d7b-48b9-9b8e-a54fe4039cf0
Coat the outside of the pork loin with Smucker's Simply Fruit® Strawberry spreadable fruit.
10452418-4d7b-48b9-9b8e-a54fe4039cf0
Apply Jeff's original rub to the entire outside of the pork loin.
10452418-4d7b-48b9-9b8e-a54fe4039cf0
Set up the smoker for cooking at 225-240 °F using indirect heat and cherry wood for smoke (any other smoking wood will also work).
10452418-4d7b-48b9-9b8e-a54fe4039cf0
When the smoker is ready, place the pork loin on the smoker grate and let cooking commence.
10452418-4d7b-48b9-9b8e-a54fe4039cf0
Let the pork loin smoke cook until it reaches 145°F in the center as indicated by a digital probe meat thermometer.
10452418-4d7b-48b9-9b8e-a54fe4039cf0
Lay the smoked pork loin on the counter with a piece of foil tented over it and allow to rest for 10 minutes.
10452418-4d7b-48b9-9b8e-a54fe4039cf0
Clip the strings and slice ½ to ¾ thick.
10452418-4d7b-48b9-9b8e-a54fe4039cf0
Make the strawberry balsamic glaze while the meat is resting.
10452418-4d7b-48b9-9b8e-a54fe4039cf0
To make the glaze, place 10 oz of Smucker's Simply Fruit® Strawberry spreadable fruit and 1/3 cup balsamic vinegar into a small pan over low heat.
10452418-4d7b-48b9-9b8e-a54fe4039cf0
As the ingredients get warm, stir to combine. When it's warm through, it's ready to use.
10452418-4d7b-48b9-9b8e-a54fe4039cf0
Drizzle the strawberry balsamic glaze over the pork loin slices and serve right away.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
Place the ribs on a cutting board or into a pan bone side up.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
Remove the flap of meat called the "skirt" using a sharp knife.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
Remove the brisket bone at the top edge of the ribs.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
Remove the plastic-like membrane using a paper towel or catfish pliers for better grip.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
Apply a coat of yellow mustard to the bone side of the ribs
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
Generously apply Jeff's original rub to the bone side of the ribs.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
Leave the ribs sitting until the rub gets a "wet" look showing that it has absorbed moisture from the mustard and the meat juices.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
Flip the spare ribs over to meaty side up.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
Apply a coat of yellow mustard to the meaty side of the ribs
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
Generously apply Jeff's original rub to the meaty side of the ribs.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
Leave the ribs sitting until the rub gets a "wet" look showing that it has absorbed moisture from the mustard and the meat juices.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
The ribs are now ready for the smoker.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-240 °F using indirect heat and cherry wood for smoke.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
Once the smoker is ready, place the ribs directly on the smoker grate and cook for 3 hours.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
At the end of 3 hours, wrap the spare ribs with 2 layers of heavy duty foil to allow the ribs to steam and tenderize.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
At the end of 2 hours wrapped in foil, unwrap them once again and place them back into the smoker at 225-240°F to firm up the crust and finish cooking.
3f23afbb-15dc-4cf1-8d1d-8d6427d7bd67
You can also place them on a 300°F grill for about 5 minutes each side. This is a great time to brush on sauce if you like.
d166b228-e024-4fa5-8bed-51a14cb21f8c
Cut the root end and stem end off the onion.
d166b228-e024-4fa5-8bed-51a14cb21f8c
Peel the skin from the outer layer of the onion.
d166b228-e024-4fa5-8bed-51a14cb21f8c
Cut the onion into ½ inch slices and remove the centers to only leave about 2 layers.
d166b228-e024-4fa5-8bed-51a14cb21f8c
Brush barbecue sauce onto the top of the onion slices then sprinkle with Jeffs' original rub.
d166b228-e024-4fa5-8bed-51a14cb21f8c
Flip the onion slices over and repeat the sauce and rub on the other side.
d166b228-e024-4fa5-8bed-51a14cb21f8c
Wrap strips of thin bacon around the edges of the onion slices. Expect to use about 2-3 slices each.
d166b228-e024-4fa5-8bed-51a14cb21f8c
Lay the bacon wrapped onion rings onto a Bradley rack or cooling rack and sprinkle with a little more rub.
d166b228-e024-4fa5-8bed-51a14cb21f8c
Set up your smoker for cooking at 240°F with indirect heat using pecan wood for smoke.
d166b228-e024-4fa5-8bed-51a14cb21f8c
Smoke cook the onion rings for about 2 hours or until the bacon is crisp and nicely browned.
d166b228-e024-4fa5-8bed-51a14cb21f8c
Serve immediately when finished.
fb92fba6-79cd-4fc4-915a-c4f1caff7e61
Place the two chuck roasts on a plate or other container and evenly sprinkle about a teaspoon of kosher salt on the top of each.
fb92fba6-79cd-4fc4-915a-c4f1caff7e61
Place the roasts in the fridge for two hours.
fb92fba6-79cd-4fc4-915a-c4f1caff7e61
Remove the roasts from the fridge, flip them over and apply salt in the same manner to the other side.
fb92fba6-79cd-4fc4-915a-c4f1caff7e61
Place the chuck roasts back into the fridge for 4 hours to finish the dry brining process. No rinsing required.
fb92fba6-79cd-4fc4-915a-c4f1caff7e61
Apply a layer of mustard to one of the chuck roasts and then a generous application of Jeff's original rub (top, bottom and sides).
fb92fba6-79cd-4fc4-915a-c4f1caff7e61
Apply a coat of olive oil to one of the chuck roasts and then a generous application of Jeff's Texas style rub (top, bottom and sides).
fb92fba6-79cd-4fc4-915a-c4f1caff7e61
Place the roasts into a smoker preheated to 225-240°F and smoke cook with pecan wood until the meat has reached an internal temperature of 160°F.
fb92fba6-79cd-4fc4-915a-c4f1caff7e61
Wrap the roasts in brown butcher paper and place them back into the smoker to continue cooking until they reach a finished temperature of 195-200°F.
fb92fba6-79cd-4fc4-915a-c4f1caff7e61
Let the meat rest for 2 hours, still wrapped, in an empty cooler or an oven/smoker heated to about 170°F.
fb92fba6-79cd-4fc4-915a-c4f1caff7e61
When the resting period is over, the meat can be unwrapped and sliced, pulled or chopped depending on how you want to serve it to your guests.
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Prepare the Sweet Potatoes Scrub the potatoes under cool water to remove any dirt, grime, etc.
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Prepare the Sweet Potatoes Dry them with a clean paper towel.
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Prepare the Sweet Potatoes I was always taught to poke potatoes before baking them to let the steam escape and prevent exploding.. there is a lot of skepticism regarding this being really necessary but I figure it's easy to do and life is too short for taking these kind of chances. It's your potatoes.. so, you assume the risk;-)
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Prepare the Sweet Potatoes Set them on a cooling rack, Bradley rack or Weber grill pan as this makes it really easy to transport them to and from the smoker but you can use anything you like.. even a large bowl.
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Prepare the Sweet Potatoes Brush on some olive oil.. Then some kosher salt.
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Prepare the Sweet Potatoes Voila! They are ready for the smoker!
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Smoke the Sweet Potatoes At 225°F, you are looking at 2.5 to 3 hours however if you crank the heat up to about 275-300, you can get these done in about 1 hour 30 minutes.
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Smoke the Sweet Potatoes Place the potatoes directly on the rack or leave them on the cooling rack and set the whole thing in the smoker.
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Smoke the Sweet Potatoes Let them cook with smoke flowing until they are soft just like you like them.
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Smoke the Sweet Potatoes If you like them al dente, then you can remove them a little sooner or if you like them really soft (like I do) then leave them longer.
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Smoke the Sweet Potatoes If they get done before the other food, keep them hot for several hours in the oven at 170°F.
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Smoke the Sweet Potatoes You can eat them savory or sweet or try both and see which you like better.
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Smoke the Sweet Potatoes A little butter with my original rub is really good or if you prefer, butter and plenty of brown sugar is good enough to be dessert.
50af1608-5129-422c-9aa8-39c682d019c4 Smoke the Sweet Potatoes I paired these sweet potatoes with some citrus rosemary cornish hens and the combination was a hit!
bcda14de-4af8-4b44-8f6e-d71aa4beecf0
Make the marinade by adding 3 cups of olive oil to a medium sized mixing bowl.
bcda14de-4af8-4b44-8f6e-d71aa4beecf0
Zest about ⅓ cup each of the oranges, lemons and limes.
bcda14de-4af8-4b44-8f6e-d71aa4beecf0
Squeeze the oranges, lemons and limes to get about 1 full cup of juice.
bcda14de-4af8-4b44-8f6e-d71aa4beecf0
Add the zest, juice, chopped rosemary, minced garlic, salt and pepper to the olive oil and stir well to combine.
bcda14de-4af8-4b44-8f6e-d71aa4beecf0
Halve the cornish hens by removing the backbone and the keel bone along the breast.
bcda14de-4af8-4b44-8f6e-d71aa4beecf0
Add the half chickens to a lidded container and pour the marinade over the chicken to cover. Place the chicken in the fridge for 12 hours.
bcda14de-4af8-4b44-8f6e-d71aa4beecf0
Do not rinse when finished. Sprinkle a thin layer of Jeff's Texas style rub onto the skin side of the chicken halves.
bcda14de-4af8-4b44-8f6e-d71aa4beecf0
Setup your smoker for cooking at about 275°F if possible using orange wood, or any citrus/fruit wood or even pecan, oak or hickory if that is all you have.
bcda14de-4af8-4b44-8f6e-d71aa4beecf0
Smoke cook the cornish hens skin side up for about 1 hour and 15 minutes at 275°F or until they reach 165°F in the thickest part as measured by a meat thermometer.
bcda14de-4af8-4b44-8f6e-d71aa4beecf0
When the chicken is done, it can be served immediately.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Remove fish from package and lay it on a cutting board.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Cut the fish into 8 equal servings.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Using a sharp knife, remove the skin from the flesh.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Rinse the fish under cold water to remove any scales.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Pat dry with paper towel.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Make dry brine mixture using 2 cups dark brown sugar, ¼ cup of kosher salt and 2 TBS of coarse ground pepper. Mix well.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Create a thin layer of the dry brine mixture in a lidded plastic or glass container.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Lay the dry pieces of fish onto the thin layer.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Create a thin layer of the dry brine mixture on the top and sides of the pieces of fish.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Pat it into place with your hand.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Put on the lid and place container into fridge for 6-8 hours.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Rinse the fish well under cold water and pat completely dry with a paper towel.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Place the fish onto a cooling rack and into the fridge to dry for 2-3 hours or until the outside of the fish is tacky to the touch and has a shiny appearance.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Sprinkle a very thin layer of Jeff's original rub onto the top of the salmon to season.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Setup your smoker for cooking at about 180°F with indirect heat using cherry wood for smoke.
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Let the fish cook for about 1.5 hours or until the fish reaches 125-145°F in the thickest part. (while USDA recommend 145 °F, most chefs recommend 125 for a more tender and moist salmon).
dca7e7bc-1cdf-4805-90e3-fadd49e15a81
Remove from the smoker and serve immediately.
9658ece1-ec34-43fe-91bf-558776def75c
Place the beef short ribs into a foil pan or plastic container.
9658ece1-ec34-43fe-91bf-558776def75c
Sprinkle coarse grained kosher salt onto the top of the beef short ribs. Coverage should be about 10-15% and should leave at least 1/8 to ¼ inch between the grains on average.
9658ece1-ec34-43fe-91bf-558776def75c
Place the beef short ribs in the fridge uncovered for at least 4 hours or overnight.
9658ece1-ec34-43fe-91bf-558776def75c
When they are done brining, there is no need to rinse them.
9658ece1-ec34-43fe-91bf-558776def75c
If necessary, move the beef short ribs to a foil pan that is about 2 to 3 inches deep.
9658ece1-ec34-43fe-91bf-558776def75c
Pour about ½ inch of cranberry juice or juice cocktail into the bottom of the foil pan. Pour the juice over the beef ribs so that they get wetted in the process. This will help the rub to stick better.
9658ece1-ec34-43fe-91bf-558776def75c
Sprinkle Jeff's original rub generously onto the top of each beef short rib and set aside.
9658ece1-ec34-43fe-91bf-558776def75c
Prepare the smoker for cooking at 225-240°F using indirect heat and cherry wood for smoke.
9658ece1-ec34-43fe-91bf-558776def75c
Place the pan of ribs into the smoker and let them smoke cook uninterrupted for 2 hours.
9658ece1-ec34-43fe-91bf-558776def75c
At the end of 2 hours, cover the pan with foil to let the braising really take place. This braising process should last for 2 hours.
9658ece1-ec34-43fe-91bf-558776def75c
Uncover the short ribs at the end of 2 hours and spoon some of the tasty juices up onto the ribs.
9658ece1-ec34-43fe-91bf-558776def75c
Garnish with some chopped parsley and rosemary and serve immediately.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Remove the membrane using a sharp knife, your fingers, the end of a spoon, etc. to get under the membrane. Grasp the membrane with a paper towel for better grip or you can use catfish pliers.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Place the ribs boney side up on the table or cutting board.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Sprinkle about 1 tsp of kosher salt evenly on the boney side of the ribs.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Place the ribs in the fridge for 2 hours.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Remove the ribs from the fridge, flip them over to meaty side up and sprinkle a tsp of kosher salt evenly on the meaty (top) side of the ribs.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Place the ribs back into the fridge for at least 4 hours or overnight is okay.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
There is no need to rinse the ribs after this dry brining process.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Season the outside of the ribs generously with my original rub on the top meaty side of the ribs.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Let the ribs sit there just a few minutes until they get that "wet" look. This is the rub mixing with the natural juices in the meat.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 230°F if possible. Be sure to use a tried and true thermometer to make sure that your smoker is running at the temperature that it says it is.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Once your smoker is heated up and ready to smoke, it’s time to get those ribs on the grate.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Place the ribs bone side down if possible.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Let the ribs cook at about 230°F and with smoke for 2 hours.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
At the end of 2 hours, wrap the ribs with foil.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Do this carefully so as to not tear the foil. If you do happen to tear it, just double wrap it with another piece.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Place the wrapped ribs back into the 230°F smoker and you can even stack them all together if you need to.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Let them cook in this wrapped state for about 2 hours.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
With a total of 4 hours past, you now want to unwrap them again.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
They will be very soft on the outside and very tender on the inside, and this last step is to firm up the outside just a little before serving them.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Remove the foil and place them back into the 230°F smoker for 1 hour.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Paint the ribs with sauce several times over the course of this last hour to make them nice and sticky.
e0c66c83-dd89-4878-b3cc-f6994eb809d6
Slice up the ribs and serve them
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
Remove the turkey breast from the packaging but leave the net intact as this is what holds it's shape while it cooks.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
To a medium pot add 1 quart of water, 1 TBS of course ground black pepper, 1 TBS of red pepper flakes, 2 long sprigs of thyme, 2 long sprigs of rosemary and 8-10 garlic cloves smashed with the side of a knife.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
Bring to a boil then remove it from the heat and let it steep covered for 20-30 minutes.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
Place the mixture in the fridge for several hours to cool.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
To make the brine, add 3 quarts of cold water to a gallon sized pitcher and 1 cup of kosher salt.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
Stir the mixture until the salt is dissolved.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
Add the cooled mixture from the fridge into the brine and stir to combine.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
Place the turkey breasts into a brining container and pour the brine over the turkey to cover and then into the fridge for 4 hours.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
After brining is complete, rinse the turkey breasts under cold water.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
With the net still intact, brush on a little cooking oil and season the outside of the turkey breasts liberally with Jeff's original rub.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
Set the seasoned turkey onto Weber grill pans, Bradley racks or regular cooling racks and they are ready to go into the smoker
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
Setup your smoker for cooking at 225-240 °F with indirect heat.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
When the smoker is preheated, place the pan with the turkey breasts into the smoker.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
Let the turkey cook until it reaches an internal temperature of 162°F.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
Remove the turkey from the smoker and let it rest under loose foil for about 10-15 minutes.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
Remove the net from the turkey breasts being careful to not disturb the crust more than necessary.
1eb5c194-5ba5-4fff-95c9-20570f47275e
Slice and serve.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
To a medium pot add 1 quart of water, 1 TBS of course ground black pepper, 1 TBS of red pepper flakes, 2 long sprigs of thyme, 2 long sprigs of rosemary and 8-10 garlic cloves smashed with the side of a knife.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
Bring to a boil then remove it from the heat and let it steep covered for 20-30 minutes.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
Place the mixture in the fridge for several hours to cool.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
To make the brine, add 3 quarts of cold water to a gallon sized pitcher and 1 cup of kosher salt.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
Stir the mixture until the salt is dissolved.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
Add the cooled mixture from the fridge into the brine and stir to combine.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
Place the turkey tenderloins into a plastic bowl or zip top bag and pour the brine over them to cover.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
Place the container with the brining turkey into the fridge for at least 4 hours or overnight.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
When the brining is complete, rinse the turkey under cold water to remove any residual salt and discard the brine.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
Season the turkey with Jeff's original rub then wrap the entire tenderloin with bacon. This will take approximately 4-6 pieces of bacon.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
Season the outside of the bacon wrap with Jeff's original rub then place the wrapped tenderloins onto a Weber grill pan, Bradley rack or cooling rack and it is ready for the smoker.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
Setup your smoker for cooking at about 240°F using indirect heat and cherry wood for smoke.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
When the smoker is ready, place the meat into the smoker and close the lid or door.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
Let the turkey smoke cook until it has reached 165°F in the thickest part.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
Remove the turkey from the heat and allow it to rest under a loose piece of foil for about 10 minutes.
758d9350-3ce6-48eb-ba5b-a5914803210f
Slice and serve.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
Remove chicken skin using a paper towel for better grip.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
Place chicken legs into a zip top bag.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
Place 2/3 cup of Dijon mustard into the bag and massage to cover all of the chicken.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
Place ½ cup of Jeff's original rub into the bag and massage/roll bag to coat the chicken evenly.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
Place the bag in the fridge overnight if desired or proceed with wrapping in bacon.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
Lay a strip of bacon on the cutting board
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
Place a piece of chicken about 4 inches from the end of the bacon.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
Wrap the short end over the top of the bacon then proceed to wrap the long end around the rest of the chicken.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
Repeat this process on all of the chicken legs.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
Place the wrapped chicken legs onto a Bradley rack or similar.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
Preheat the smoker to 250°F using indirect heat.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
To smoke cook the chicken, lay the chicken on the grate and close the lid.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
When the chicken reaches 145°F it can be brushed with Dr Pepper glaze made by mixing ½ cup of my barbecue sauce, ½ cup of Dr Pepper and 2 TBS of honey.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
Multiple coats can be applied if you want the chicken to be extra sticky.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
When the chicken reaches 175°F it is finished and should be removed from the heat.
cd09f2c3-d382-43c0-b738-39fa482ae200
Serve immediately with warm sauce on the side.
f6f730d4-8900-4178-b1f6-5c62a07e9e68
Lay the meat onto a cookie sheet and press it out flat.
f6f730d4-8900-4178-b1f6-5c62a07e9e68
Evenly layer all of the ingredients except for the barbecue sauce on top of the meat.
f6f730d4-8900-4178-b1f6-5c62a07e9e68
Roll the meat and ingredients up and press it gently into a loaf shape.
f6f730d4-8900-4178-b1f6-5c62a07e9e68
Place the meatloaf "dough" into a loaf pan or a loaf shaped bowl and into the fridge for at least an hour or longer.
f6f730d4-8900-4178-b1f6-5c62a07e9e68
Get the smoker ready by preheating it to 225-240°F using indirect heat.
f6f730d4-8900-4178-b1f6-5c62a07e9e68
When the smoker is ready, remove the meatloaf from the bowl and onto a cooling rack or Weber grill pan.
f6f730d4-8900-4178-b1f6-5c62a07e9e68
Place the rack on top of another pan so the grease can drain away and be caught by the pan. This prevents the meatloaf from sitting in grease and getting soggy.
f6f730d4-8900-4178-b1f6-5c62a07e9e68
Use pecan, hickory or cherry wood for smoke and let the meatloaf cook for 3-4 hours or until it reaches 160 in the center as measured by a digital meat thermometer.
f6f730d4-8900-4178-b1f6-5c62a07e9e68
Top the meatloaf with barbecue sauce about 30 minutes before it is finished cooking.
f6f730d4-8900-4178-b1f6-5c62a07e9e68
Let the meatloaf rest for 7-10 minutes then slice into ½ to ¾ inch servings.
f6f730d4-8900-4178-b1f6-5c62a07e9e68
Enjoy!
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
Place brisket fat cap down inside of a large foil pan.
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
Coat the top of the brisket with molasses then sprinkle 4-6 TBS of Jeff's original rub onto the top and sides of the brisket.
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
Give the rub a couple of minutes to stick then flip the brisket over to fat cap up.
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
Use a sharp knife to score the fat cap down to the meat using a crosshatch pattern with about 1-inch intervals.
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
Coat the scored fat cap of the brisket with molasses then pour 4-6 TBS of Jeff's original rub and rub it in. The idea is for the molasses and rub to get down into the score marks in the fat cap.
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
The brisket is now ready to cook in the smoker.
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 240-250°F with indirect heat using a mix of pecan and cherry wood for smoke or whatever smoking wood you have available.
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
Let the brisket smoke cook for about 5 hours or until it reaches 160°F in the thickest part of the flat area.
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
At this point you can wrap the brisket with foil or USDA approved natural brown (or pink) paper and continue the cooking process in the smoker.
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
The brisket is done when it reaches about 200°F. You can test the brisket for perfect tenderness by inserting a probe or skewer into the flat area. It should have very little resistance and feel like it's going into room temperature butter.
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
Once done, remove the brisket from the heat.
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
It should be wrapped in foil at this point and allowed to rest for 1.5 to 2 hours in a empty, dry cooler.
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
After resting, remove the brisket from the foil and slice across the grain into ¼ inch pieces.
4dfcae83-04fa-46c7-83f9-0ae7dd6b863e
Enjoy!
1a4bbbf9-7d51-473a-aadc-080a0b593b23
Make a brine by adding 1 cup of kosher salt to 1 gallon of water. Mix until the salt has dissolved and the water returns to clear.
1a4bbbf9-7d51-473a-aadc-080a0b593b23
Place the cornish hens in a large bowl or container and pour the brine over them to cover. Put the container into the fridge for 4 hours.
1a4bbbf9-7d51-473a-aadc-080a0b593b23
Once the brining process is complete, rinse the birds to remove any residual salt.
1a4bbbf9-7d51-473a-aadc-080a0b593b23
Use kitchen shears to cut along both sides of the backbone.
1a4bbbf9-7d51-473a-aadc-080a0b593b23
Press the carcass open to make them lay flat.
1a4bbbf9-7d51-473a-aadc-080a0b593b23
Brush olive oil onto the inside of the hen then sprinkle a generous amount of Jeff's Texas style rub onto the meat.
1a4bbbf9-7d51-473a-aadc-080a0b593b23
Flip the bird over and repeat this process of oil and rub on the skin side of the bird.
1a4bbbf9-7d51-473a-aadc-080a0b593b23
Prepare the smoker for cooking at about 240°F with indirect heat
1a4bbbf9-7d51-473a-aadc-080a0b593b23
Apply smoke for at least 1 hour using a mixture of pecan and maple or your own favorite smoking wood.
1a4bbbf9-7d51-473a-aadc-080a0b593b23
Use a digital thermometer to monitor the temperature of the hens while they cook.
1a4bbbf9-7d51-473a-aadc-080a0b593b23
When they reach 165°F in the thickest part of the breast and thigh, they are finished.
1a4bbbf9-7d51-473a-aadc-080a0b593b23
Remove from the heat and serve immediately.
b77a7992-a61a-454e-83ee-a8675548f4cd
Lay the pork steaks on a cookie sheet or pan.
b77a7992-a61a-454e-83ee-a8675548f4cd
Sprinkle about 1 tsp of Mortons kosher salt on the top side of the pork steaks.
b77a7992-a61a-454e-83ee-a8675548f4cd
Place the steaks in the fridge uncovered for 3 hours.
b77a7992-a61a-454e-83ee-a8675548f4cd
Rinse the steaks under cold water to remove any residual salt.
b77a7992-a61a-454e-83ee-a8675548f4cd
Season both sides of the meat with Jeff's original rub.
b77a7992-a61a-454e-83ee-a8675548f4cd
Set up the smoker for cooking at about 225°F with indirect heat.
b77a7992-a61a-454e-83ee-a8675548f4cd
Use the water pan if you have one.
b77a7992-a61a-454e-83ee-a8675548f4cd
Cook the steaks on the smoker for about 2.5 hours or until they reach 185°F in the center.
b77a7992-a61a-454e-83ee-a8675548f4cd
About 30 minutes before they are finished, you can sauce them if you like.
b77a7992-a61a-454e-83ee-a8675548f4cd
Brush sauce onto top side, wait about 15 minutes then flip over and do the other side.
b77a7992-a61a-454e-83ee-a8675548f4cd
Rest under loose foil for about 10 minutes before serving.
d5a31ac0-7254-47ea-b531-39a45ad9f093
Dry brine the steaks by sprinkling about 1 tsp of kosher salt on the top. If they are extra thick, do the bottom as well.
d5a31ac0-7254-47ea-b531-39a45ad9f093
Place the steaks on a plate or open container in the fridge for 2-4 hours. The thicker the steak, the longer it takes.
d5a31ac0-7254-47ea-b531-39a45ad9f093
When the brining is complete, rinse the steaks and set aside.
d5a31ac0-7254-47ea-b531-39a45ad9f093
Season the steaks, top and bottom with Jeff's Texas style rub and let them come to room temperature while you get the smoker ready.
d5a31ac0-7254-47ea-b531-39a45ad9f093
Prepare the smoker for cooking at 225°F with indirect heat and cherry wood for smoke. Pecan or oak are also great choices.
d5a31ac0-7254-47ea-b531-39a45ad9f093
Place the steaks on the smoker grate for about 1.5 to 2 hours or until they reach 120°F in the center as measured by an accurate digital thermometer.
d5a31ac0-7254-47ea-b531-39a45ad9f093
Remove the steaks from the heat and let them rest with foil tented over them for about 10 minutes.
d5a31ac0-7254-47ea-b531-39a45ad9f093
Meantime, heat an iron skillet over high heat and once water will spit in the pan, it is ready to use.
d5a31ac0-7254-47ea-b531-39a45ad9f093
Pour a little vegetable oil in the center and place the steak in the pan rotating it to spread the oil out.
d5a31ac0-7254-47ea-b531-39a45ad9f093
Sear each side for about a minute.
d5a31ac0-7254-47ea-b531-39a45ad9f093
Let the steaks rest for about 5 minutes, no foil this time and then serve to your guests.
f34a248c-b6ee-4ef2-a921-245d9350a3e5
Rinse the ribs with cold water.
f34a248c-b6ee-4ef2-a921-245d9350a3e5
Remove the membrane using a paper towel for better grip.
f34a248c-b6ee-4ef2-a921-245d9350a3e5
Apply a good coat of molasses to the bone side of the ribs.
f34a248c-b6ee-4ef2-a921-245d9350a3e5
Sprinkle Jeff's original rub over the layer of molasses and let them sit until they begin to look "wet".
f34a248c-b6ee-4ef2-a921-245d9350a3e5
Flip the rack of ribs over and repeat the molasses and rub on the meaty side of the ribs.
f34a248c-b6ee-4ef2-a921-245d9350a3e5
Place the ribs on the smoker grate and smoke cook them for 2 hours at 225°F using indirect heat.
f34a248c-b6ee-4ef2-a921-245d9350a3e5
Use cherry, hickory, maple and apple for smoke. A mix or any combination of these woods will work great.
f34a248c-b6ee-4ef2-a921-245d9350a3e5
Wrap the rack of ribs in heavy duty foil and put it back on the smoker grate to cook another 2 hours.
f34a248c-b6ee-4ef2-a921-245d9350a3e5
Place the ribs on the cutting board bone side up and cut them apart so you end up with 12-13 ribs.
f34a248c-b6ee-4ef2-a921-245d9350a3e5
Wrap each rib in a piece of stretched bacon. Secure with a toothpick if you need to.
f34a248c-b6ee-4ef2-a921-245d9350a3e5
Place the ribs on a cookie sheet and put them into an oven preheated to 450°F for 15-20 minutes or until the bacon is done.
f34a248c-b6ee-4ef2-a921-245d9350a3e5
You can also perform the last step in the smoker or grill and especially if you are able to increase the heat enough to cook the bacon to a crisp finish.
f34a248c-b6ee-4ef2-a921-245d9350a3e5
Serve the bacon wrapped ribs immediately.
f7b0a49b-5f0a-4d28-9cb5-966010b9ac48
Remove beef ribs from packaging and rinse under cold water.
f7b0a49b-5f0a-4d28-9cb5-966010b9ac48
Remove excess clumps of fat.
f7b0a49b-5f0a-4d28-9cb5-966010b9ac48
Peel membrane or skin from bone side of ribs.
f7b0a49b-5f0a-4d28-9cb5-966010b9ac48
Brush several tablespoons of barbecue sauce and/or mustard onto the meaty side of the ribs.
f7b0a49b-5f0a-4d28-9cb5-966010b9ac48
Sprinkle about 2 tablespoons of Jeff's rub onto the top of the ribs and rub it in to the top and sides creating a paste.
f7b0a49b-5f0a-4d28-9cb5-966010b9ac48
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F with indirect heat.
f7b0a49b-5f0a-4d28-9cb5-966010b9ac48
Use a mix of cherry and oak or whatever smoking wood you have available for smoke.
f7b0a49b-5f0a-4d28-9cb5-966010b9ac48
Place the ribs on the smoker grate and let them cook for 4-5 hours or until they are tender to your liking.
b604b49d-a67c-4c3d-bf49-39772ab21dbb
Rinse fish under cold water.
b604b49d-a67c-4c3d-bf49-39772ab21dbb
Brush olive oil onto the top and sides of the fish.
b604b49d-a67c-4c3d-bf49-39772ab21dbb
Apply my Texas style rub to the top of the fish.
b604b49d-a67c-4c3d-bf49-39772ab21dbb
Place into a lidded container or ziptop bag and place it in the fridge if the smoker is not ready or if you prepped it ahead of time.
b604b49d-a67c-4c3d-bf49-39772ab21dbb
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225°F with indirect heat and a light tasting wood such as alder and/or apple.
b604b49d-a67c-4c3d-bf49-39772ab21dbb
When the smoker is ready, place the fish on a piece of parchment paper and on to the smoker grate.
b604b49d-a67c-4c3d-bf49-39772ab21dbb
Smoke cook the fish for about 2 hours or until the internal temperature reads 140°F in the thickest part.
b604b49d-a67c-4c3d-bf49-39772ab21dbb
Remove the fish from the heat.
b604b49d-a67c-4c3d-bf49-39772ab21dbb
Slice and serve immediately.
6dcd7aa0-223f-46bc-8231-81b5ea8a6e61
Add all ingredients to large bowl and combine with your hands but do not over mix.
6dcd7aa0-223f-46bc-8231-81b5ea8a6e61
Form meatballs between the palms of your hands.
6dcd7aa0-223f-46bc-8231-81b5ea8a6e61
Flatten meatball and place a ¼ inch cube of cream cheese into the center of the meatball.
6dcd7aa0-223f-46bc-8231-81b5ea8a6e61
Wrap meat back around cream cheese and roll between your palms again to form into a meatball.
6dcd7aa0-223f-46bc-8231-81b5ea8a6e61
Place stuffed meatballs onto a Bradley rack or other pan for easy transport to the smoker.
6dcd7aa0-223f-46bc-8231-81b5ea8a6e61
Set up smoker for cooking indirect at about 225-240°F using pecan or other smoking wood.
6dcd7aa0-223f-46bc-8231-81b5ea8a6e61
Place meatballs into smoker and cook until they reach an internal temperature of 160°F.
6dcd7aa0-223f-46bc-8231-81b5ea8a6e61
Serve meatballs immediately while they are still hot.
00bf6346-b502-4775-b27f-4a08dd1b51a1
Cut pork loin into thirds or purchase 3 pieces of pork loin
00bf6346-b502-4775-b27f-4a08dd1b51a1
Remove the fat and silver skin using a sharp knife
00bf6346-b502-4775-b27f-4a08dd1b51a1
Prepare the first pork loin by applying 2 TBS of peach butter, 2 TBS of honey and about 2 TBS of Jeff's original rub onto the meat and massaging it into a paste on all sides.
00bf6346-b502-4775-b27f-4a08dd1b51a1
Prepare the second pork loin by applying 2 TBS of olive oil, 2 TBS of Jeff's Texas style rub and 2-3 TBS of minced garlic onto the meat. Massage the ingredients together onto all sides.
00bf6346-b502-4775-b27f-4a08dd1b51a1
Prepare the third pork loin by applying 2 TBS of olive oil, 2 TBS of Jeff's Texas style rub and the chopped herbs onto the top of the meat. Massage the ingredients together onto all sides.
00bf6346-b502-4775-b27f-4a08dd1b51a1
Place the individual pork loins into gallon sized zip top bags and place in the fridge to marinate overnight.
00bf6346-b502-4775-b27f-4a08dd1b51a1
The next morning, tie the pork loins about 4-5 times each to make them round and place them on a Weber grill pan or Bradley rack.
00bf6346-b502-4775-b27f-4a08dd1b51a1
Preheat the smoker to 225-240°F and when it is ready, smoke the pork loins with cherry wood for about 4 hours or until they reach an internal temperature of 145°F.
00bf6346-b502-4775-b27f-4a08dd1b51a1
Tent foil over the pork loins for about 10 minutes before slicing.
00bf6346-b502-4775-b27f-4a08dd1b51a1
Slice the pork loins and serve.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Place chuck roast into a lidded container.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Pour 4-6 ounces of Worcestershire over the meat.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Sprinkle some of Jeff's original rub onto the top of the meat.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Use a sharp knife to make cuts through the top into the center of the meat.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Drizzle on more Worcestershire so it can seep down into the holes.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Place a lid on the container and let the meat marinate overnight.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Preheat smoker to 240 °F using indirect heat and cherry wood for smoke.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Place chuck roast directly on smoker grate.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Let the meat smoke cook for about 8 hours or until it reads 190°F in the thickest part.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Cut the chuck roast into bite size cubes.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Place the cubes in a foil pan.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Add Jeff's original sauce and original rub onto the meat making sure it is well coated.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Place the meat back into the smoker at 240 °F for about 2 hours stirring every 30 minutes.
7c167952-5781-4d6c-9113-b7fb40d991bf
Note: you can also place the meat on the grill over high heat or in the oven on broil stirring every few minutes to get it done much quicker. When the color is right and the sauce/rub is caramelized, they are done.
18d8a37c-3d7a-4564-9b33-98ee1b47c9c9
Remove skin from thighs, snip knuckles from bones and remove any excess fat.
18d8a37c-3d7a-4564-9b33-98ee1b47c9c9
Add Jeff's original rub to chicken thighs on top and bottom. Refrigerate overnight if you like or get right on with it.
18d8a37c-3d7a-4564-9b33-98ee1b47c9c9
Replace skin on to chicken thighs.
18d8a37c-3d7a-4564-9b33-98ee1b47c9c9
Put chicken skin side down into special, pre-drilled muffin pan.
18d8a37c-3d7a-4564-9b33-98ee1b47c9c9
Place the muffin pan onto a cookie sheet filled with ¼ inch of chicken broth and smoke cook at 275 for 1.5 hours.
18d8a37c-3d7a-4564-9b33-98ee1b47c9c9
Flip chicken over in muffin pan to skin side up, add some seasoning and smoke cook at 275 for another 45 minutes.
18d8a37c-3d7a-4564-9b33-98ee1b47c9c9
Remove chicken from muffin pan and place skin side up onto cookie sheet.
18d8a37c-3d7a-4564-9b33-98ee1b47c9c9
Sauce top and sides and smoke cook at 275 for an additional 30 minutes to let the sauce caramelize or until the internal temperature reaches 175℉.
18d8a37c-3d7a-4564-9b33-98ee1b47c9c9
Serve immediately.
07ae2650-f798-4fcb-841b-8189b296f0a8
Cut top from pineapple.
07ae2650-f798-4fcb-841b-8189b296f0a8
Remove skin and eyes.
07ae2650-f798-4fcb-841b-8189b296f0a8
Core out inside leaving about ¾ inch wall on sides and bottom.
07ae2650-f798-4fcb-841b-8189b296f0a8
Fill with smoked country style ribs or baby back rib meat seasoned with rub.
07ae2650-f798-4fcb-841b-8189b296f0a8
Replace top and secure with long toothpicks.
07ae2650-f798-4fcb-841b-8189b296f0a8
Make a bacon weave large enough to wrap completely around pineapple.
07ae2650-f798-4fcb-841b-8189b296f0a8
Wrap in bacon weave -or-
07ae2650-f798-4fcb-841b-8189b296f0a8
Wrap stretched bacon around the pineapple.
07ae2650-f798-4fcb-841b-8189b296f0a8
Smoke at 240°F for about 4 hours or until bacon is crisp.
56617602-071c-4a74-b45a-7da30ac2c143
Coat beef with Jeff's Texas style rub
56617602-071c-4a74-b45a-7da30ac2c143
Add more coarse kosher salt to the meat to help with the dry brining process. See picture in web version of recipe to estimate proper coverage.
56617602-071c-4a74-b45a-7da30ac2c143
Place top round into lidded container and place into fridge overnight.
56617602-071c-4a74-b45a-7da30ac2c143
When the brining process is complete, remove the top round from the fridge and set aside.
56617602-071c-4a74-b45a-7da30ac2c143
Set up smoker for cooking at about 225-250°F with indirect heat.
56617602-071c-4a74-b45a-7da30ac2c143
Place the meat on the smoker grate and let it cook for 4-5 hours or until it reaches medium rare (130°F)
56617602-071c-4a74-b45a-7da30ac2c143
Use oak smoke for best results but any smoking wood will work fine.
56617602-071c-4a74-b45a-7da30ac2c143
Add smoke for at least 2 hours.
56617602-071c-4a74-b45a-7da30ac2c143
When the meat is finished cooking, let it rest for about 10 minutes then slice into steaks or strips.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Make a bacon weave with 8 horizontal strips and 8 vertical strips on a large piece of foil. It should end up being about 12 inches by 12 inches.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Season the top of the bacon weave with Jeff's original rub recipe.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Place the bacon weave in the fridge to firm up.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Place 2 lbs of ground sausage into a zip top bag.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Flatten the sausage inside the bag until is of equal thickness.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Use scissors to cut along the seams and remove the top layer of the plastic bag.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Season the top of the sausage with Jeff's original rub recipe.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Lay the flattened sausage onto the bacon weave with the top edge about 3 to 4 inches from the top edge of the bacon weave.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Place ½ lb of diced ham and 1.5 cups of sharp cheddar cheese onto the flattened sausage. Leave about 2 inches at the top and bottom and 1 inch on the sides.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Season the ham and cheese with Jeff's original rub recipe.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Using the plastic like a sushi mat, roll the sausage and stuffing into a roll and onto the bacon weave.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Seal the ends of the sausage roll with more sausage to keep the cheese and ham from falling out during the cooking process.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Using the foil like a sushi mat, wrap the bacon weave around the sausage roll.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Wrap the roll tightly in foil.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Place the wrapped sausage roll in the fridge to firm up for at least an hour or overnight.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Season the outside of the bacon with Jeff's original rub recipe.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Setup smoker for cooking at 225-240°F using indirect heat.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Place bacon wrapped sausage roll onto smoker grate or use a baking sheet, Weber grill pan or Bradley rack to make it easier.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Smoke cook for 3 hours or until the inside of the meat reaches 160°F.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Glaze the outside with Jeff's original barbecue sauce if desired and let it continue cooking for about 10 minutes to glaze the sauce.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Remove from the smoker and let it rest for 10 minutes.
7dd06d21-825b-4215-a4a6-bf26556720a3
Slice and serve.
1e1c2361-82fb-4857-9dd2-b185f0d07cdc
Cut along both sides of the backbone to remove it.
1e1c2361-82fb-4857-9dd2-b185f0d07cdc
Once the backbone is removed, press the chicken open so that it lays open like a book.
1e1c2361-82fb-4857-9dd2-b185f0d07cdc
Create a brine from 1 gallon of cold water and 1 cup of coarse kosher salt and mix together until the water returns to clear.
1e1c2361-82fb-4857-9dd2-b185f0d07cdc
Place the chicken into a lidded container or zip top bag and pour the brine over the chicken to cover.
1e1c2361-82fb-4857-9dd2-b185f0d07cdc
Refrigerate the chicken for 4-6 hours while it brines.
1e1c2361-82fb-4857-9dd2-b185f0d07cdc
While the chicken is brining, make the bacon butter mixture by adding 1 stick of butter, 3 TBS of chopped chives, 1 TBS of Jeff's original rub and 4 slices of uncooked, chopped bacon to a small mixing bowl.
1e1c2361-82fb-4857-9dd2-b185f0d07cdc
Mix the bacon butter ingredients together until it is well combined.
1e1c2361-82fb-4857-9dd2-b185f0d07cdc
When the chicken is finished brining, discard the brine and rinse the chicken under cold water.
1e1c2361-82fb-4857-9dd2-b185f0d07cdc
Set the chicken breast sides up on the cutting board and work the skin around the breast loose with your hands.
1e1c2361-82fb-4857-9dd2-b185f0d07cdc
Stuff the bacon butter mixture under the skin of the chicken.
1e1c2361-82fb-4857-9dd2-b185f0d07cdc
Brush olive oil onto the outside of the skin and season generously with Jeff's Texas style rub recipe or a salt/pepper mixture.
1e1c2361-82fb-4857-9dd2-b185f0d07cdc
Place the chicken into the smoker breast side up and cook at 225-325°F until it reaches 165°F in the thickest part. Some smokers will not cook beyond 225-240°F but you can get the chicken done faster and get a better bite through on the skin from higher temperatures if your smoker will do it.
1e1c2361-82fb-4857-9dd2-b185f0d07cdc
Let the chicken rest for about 10 minutes before carving and serving.
f09cbc4a-3840-4954-aa77-43cc5b6f7233
Place pork butt into foil plan fat side down
f09cbc4a-3840-4954-aa77-43cc5b6f7233
Apply mustard all over the top and sides of the pork butt spreading it out with your hands.
f09cbc4a-3840-4954-aa77-43cc5b6f7233
Add about ¼ cup of Jeff's original rub to the top of the pork butt and massage it into the top and sides of the meat allowing it to mix with the mustard and create a paste.
f09cbc4a-3840-4954-aa77-43cc5b6f7233
Set the pork butt aside and go get the smoker ready.
f09cbc4a-3840-4954-aa77-43cc5b6f7233
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F using indirect heat.
f09cbc4a-3840-4954-aa77-43cc5b6f7233
I recommend using pecan or hickory but any smoking wood will work.
f09cbc4a-3840-4954-aa77-43cc5b6f7233
Place the pork butt onto the smoker grate with a pan on a lower rack or you can leave the pork butt in the pan and set the pan and meat on the smoker grate. This is to contain the rendered juices.
f09cbc4a-3840-4954-aa77-43cc5b6f7233
Let the pork butt cook for about 12-14 hours or until it reaches an internal temperature of 205°F.
f09cbc4a-3840-4954-aa77-43cc5b6f7233
Remove the pork butt from the heat and let it rest with some foil tented over it for about 30-45 minutes.
f09cbc4a-3840-4954-aa77-43cc5b6f7233
Pull the meat apart into small pieces and chunks removing any fat clumps or pieces as you go.
f09cbc4a-3840-4954-aa77-43cc5b6f7233
A normal pork butt will yield about 4 lbs of finished pulled pork. To this add 6-12 cleaned, seeded and diced jalapeños, about 20 oz of crushed pineapple and another ¼ cup of Jeff's original rub.
f09cbc4a-3840-4954-aa77-43cc5b6f7233
Mix the meat, rub, jalapeños and pineapple together.
f09cbc4a-3840-4954-aa77-43cc5b6f7233
Use on tacos, nachos, sliders, etc.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
I purchased shrimp that still had the shell so I spent a little time peeling. Not my favorite job but it's worth it in the end.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
If your shrimp are frozen, pour them into a colander and run cold water over them for a couple of minutes to thaw.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
Peel the shrimp and leave the tail on if possible.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
Place the peeled shrimp in a bowl and set aside.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
Pour an ample amount of my Texas style rub over the shrimp and stir them around to coat. If you have time, place the bowl in the fridge for an hour to give it time to get "happy".
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
I tried this multiple ways and what seemed to work best for me was to make a ball of sausage about 1-inch in diameter then press it out flat and thin in my hand.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
I then laid the shrimp onto the sausage and wrapped the sausage around the body of the shrimp. Note: This is quick and easy if the shrimp are dry and the sausage is cold.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
Sprinkle some of my original rub onto the sausage and lay the completed appetizers on a Weber grill pan or Bradley rack.They are ready to smoke.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
Setup your smoker for cooking at about 240°F with indirect heat.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
If your smoker utilizes a water pan, fill it with hot water to create a moist environment.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
For smoke, I chose some cherry but almost any light tasting wood will work such as pecan, apple or any fruit wood.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
When your smoker is ready to go, place the shrimp appetizers on the smoker grate and let them cook for about 45 minutes with light smoke.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
You may want to check the temperature at the center of the sausage with a Thermapen at around 30 minutes to make sure everything is going as it should.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
The sausage needs to reach 160°F for it to be safe at which point the shrimp inside will be just perfect.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
When the sausage wrapped shrimp appetizers are finished cooking, remove them from the smoker right away.
c689c61f-ed17-4644-b54b-7047aea4e642
Serve these up with some warm barbecue sauce on the side.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Fill a large container such as a pitcher or bowl with 40 ounces (1 quart + 1 cup) cold water.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Add two 12-0z bottles of beer
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Stir in ½ cup of kosher salt and continue to stir until salt is diluted into the water and the water becomes clear.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Stir in ½ cup brown sugar making sure it is melted into the water.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Add the drumsticks to a lidded container for brining.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
If you see any large clumps of fat or extra skin, now is a great time to go ahead and remove it with kitchen shears or a sharp knife.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Once all of the chicken is in the container, pour the brine over the chicken to cover.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Cover with the lid, plastic wrap, etc. and place the brining chicken into the fridge for 3 hours.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
At the end of the brining time, discard the liquid brine and rinse each piece of chicken to remove any residual salt.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Lay the chicken on several layers of paper towels to drain before proceeding to the next step.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Drizzle olive oil or vegetable oil onto the chicken and use a basting brush to spread it out.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Move the chicken around to make sure it is well coated.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Season generously with Jeff's Texas style rub then roll each piece over and season the other side.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Make sure the Texas style rub recipe is on all sides of the chicken.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Chop 2-3 tablespoons of parsley and chives and sprinkle it all over the chicken.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Setup your smoker or grill for cooking at 275-300°F with indirect heat. You can cook them lower at around 225°F but the skin will not have a good bite through.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
If you normally use a water pan, I recommend leaving it dry. When cooking chicken legs, thighs or quarters, I seem to get better results in a smoking environment with lower humidity.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Keep the smoke going for the entire time for great flavor. I recommend cherry, apple or pecan if you have any of these.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Use a quick read thermometer to check the temperature after about 45 minutes or you can use a thermometer with a leave-in probe to keep you aware of the temperature throughout the entire process.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
When the drumsticks reach 160°F, spoon some beer barbecue sauce onto the drumsticks.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Beer barbecue sauce is simply about a cup of my barbecue sauce mixed with equal parts of beer or until it gets to the consistency that you like.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
I say "spoon it" simply because we do not want to disturb or brush off the seasoning that we applied. A turkey baster would also work well to pick up some of the sauce and apply it to the drumsticks in a way that does not wash away the seasoning.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
The chicken is done at 165°F.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
When cooking chicken, go high with the heat if you can or smoke it for half the time and then use the oven or grill to finish if that's what you have to do.
70f6873c-4dde-4f49-934e-82b3f80d3c4f
Once the chicken is done, serve it up right away while it's still hot!
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Remove all of the netting and wrapping from the ham and lay the ham on a cutting board or preferably down into a large foil pan.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Pull the slices apart one by one and drizzle honey down in there.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Add more honey to the top of the ham and the flat or front area. Spread it out with a brush or your hands.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Pull back the slices once again and sprinkle a bit of rub down in between each one. Oh so good!
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Now apply rub all over the outside of the ham including the flat area in the front.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
To finish things off, drizzle more honey all over the top,sides and front of the ham.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Tip: if the slices start to fall down in the front, use toothpicks to pin them up. I figured this out about halfway through the smoking process
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 240°F using indirect heat.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
If your smoker has a water pan, fill it with hot water.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
We are going to apply light apple smoke for the full 3 hours that the ham is in the smoker.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Most store bought hams do well if you smoke them at 230 to 240°F for about 3 hours. These are already cooked and the process is only to add more smoke flavor and to add seasoning and perhaps crisp up the outside here and there. If you want to smoke for less time, that is perfectly acceptable but results may vary.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
When the smoker is preheated, place the pan with the ham into the smoker. The pan will catch drippings and keep your smoker cleaner.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Note: Some smokers such as the Bradley advise strongly against using aluminum pans in their smokers. I recommend that you follow the manufacturers advice for the safety and well-being of your smoker.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
After about 2 hours, you can opt to make the pineapple/root beer glaze and pour it over the ham. This is optional but recommended.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Make the glaze using 1 cup of root beer, ¼ cup of brown sugar, 1 TBS of butter, 2 TBS of Jeff's original rub and ½ cup crushed pineapple (undrained).
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Add the ingredients into a sauce pan over medium-high heat.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Bring to a boil and let it reduce for 6-8 minutes to thicken.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
When it's finished, gently pour it all over the top of the ham.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Alternative glazing method if you did not use a pan in the smoker: Remove the ham from the smoker about 15 minutes early, place it in a oven safe pan or dish and pour the pineapple/root beer glaze all over the top of the ham.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Place into an oven preheated to 275°F for about 10 minutes.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
After 3 hours of smoking/cooking time, the ham is finished and can be removed from the smoker.
72931c0b-9a02-431d-926d-683657a362b9
Remove the ham from the pan onto a serving platter and call dinner.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
I used a simple buttermilk brine on the lamb shoulder chops as follows: 1 quart buttermilk, ¼ cup kosher salt (coarse), 1 cup (8 ounces) cold water
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Pour the buttermilk and water into a large pitcher. Add the salt and stir for about 30 seconds to make sure the salt is dissolved into the liquid.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Note: This was enough to cover about 4 chops. If you are making more, you may need to double the recipe or adjust the recipe as needed.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Place the lamb shoulder chops into a bowl or zip top bag
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Pour the buttermilk brine over the top of them to cover.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Place the chops in the fridge for 3-4 hours.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
When the brining time has finished, discard the buttermilk brine and rinse the meat with cold water to remove any residual salt.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Drizzle some olive oil onto the top side of the chops and use a brush to spread it out.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Generously sprinkle Jeff's Texas style rub onto the top side.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Flip the meat over and do the olive oil and Texas style rub again on the other side.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Let the lamb chops sit there while you go get the smoker ready.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Setup your smoker for cooking at at about 240°F.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
If you smoker has a water pan, fill it with hot water.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Make sure you have enough smoking wood available for about 30 minutes of light smoke.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Once the smoker is preheated and ready to go, place the lamb shoulder chops on the smoker grate.
