b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Watch them carefully as these may cook fast and especially if they are on the thin side.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
When they reach about 110-115°F it's time to move them to a very hot grill or under the broiler of your oven to finish up.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Tip: Use a fast reading thermometer such as the Thermapen to cook these perfectly.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
Place the meat on the grill or under the oven broiler and watch them very carefully.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
When they reach just a little above medium rare, they are done. I like to take these to about 140-145°F.
b99e6881-a08c-4cb1-97a7-ad8b7f012555
When they are finished, serve them right away for best results. If you have to hold them for a few minutes, tent some foil over them during the wait.
6a078330-2eb2-4d43-8981-61032907f58a
Make the steak marinade by placing all of the following ingredients into a bowl and stirring to combine: ¾ cup lemon lime soda (Sprite, 7-Up, etc.), ¼ cup soy sauce (low sodium is best), 3 TBS apple cider vinegar, 2 TBS Worcestershire sauce, 2 TBS Jeff's original rub recipe.
6a078330-2eb2-4d43-8981-61032907f58a
Lay the steaks onto a cutting board and cut into strips then into pieces that are about 1-inch wide.
6a078330-2eb2-4d43-8981-61032907f58a
Put the steak pieces into a zip top bag and pour the steak marinade over the pieces to cover.
6a078330-2eb2-4d43-8981-61032907f58a
Seal the bag and place in the fridge for 4 hours or overnight.
6a078330-2eb2-4d43-8981-61032907f58a
While the meat is marinating, cut up the onions and squash so they are sized to fit onto a skewer.
6a078330-2eb2-4d43-8981-61032907f58a
Place the squash into a bowl and coat generously with my Texas style rub recipe.
6a078330-2eb2-4d43-8981-61032907f58a
When the meat is finished marinating, take it out of the fridge and discard the liquid in the bag.
6a078330-2eb2-4d43-8981-61032907f58a
Pour the pieces of meat into a plate.
6a078330-2eb2-4d43-8981-61032907f58a
Thread the meat and vegetables in alternating patterns onto long skewers and place onto a grilling pan or Bradley rack.
6a078330-2eb2-4d43-8981-61032907f58a
Set up your smoker for cooking at about 230°F using indirect heat.
6a078330-2eb2-4d43-8981-61032907f58a
Smoke cook the skewers for about 45-60 minutes or until the meat reaches 140°F in the thickest part.
6a078330-2eb2-4d43-8981-61032907f58a
Serve immediately.
a81b60cf-2f1d-49c6-9798-471a1b41bafa
Soak corned beef in water to remove excess salt for at least 4 hours (overnight is better).
a81b60cf-2f1d-49c6-9798-471a1b41bafa
Dry meat with paper towels and place into a foil pan.
a81b60cf-2f1d-49c6-9798-471a1b41bafa
Cover meat with Dijon mustard and Jeff's original rub.
a81b60cf-2f1d-49c6-9798-471a1b41bafa
Massage the rub/mustard to cover the entire brisket flat.
a81b60cf-2f1d-49c6-9798-471a1b41bafa
Set up smoker for cooking at about 240°F with a mix of hickory and peach or other smoking wood.
a81b60cf-2f1d-49c6-9798-471a1b41bafa
Once smoker is ready, place pan with brisket onto grate and keep the heat and smoke going for at least 4 hours.
a81b60cf-2f1d-49c6-9798-471a1b41bafa
After 4 hours the brisket can continue to cook with just heat for an additional 2-4 hours or until it reaches 195°F in the thickest part.
a81b60cf-2f1d-49c6-9798-471a1b41bafa
Baste the meat with a mixture of ¼ cup Dijon and ¼ cup of Jeff's barbecue sauce when the meat reaches 180°F and again at 190°F.
a81b60cf-2f1d-49c6-9798-471a1b41bafa
When the meat reaches 195°F and is tender to your liking, remove from the heat and allow it to rest for at meat 30 minutes tented with foil over it.
a81b60cf-2f1d-49c6-9798-471a1b41bafa
Slice the meat across the grain into ½ inch pieces and serve.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Rinse pork chops under cold water.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Make a brine solution using ½ gallon of cold water and ½ cup of coarse kosher salt.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Mix the water and salt together until the salt is dissolved.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Place the pork chops in a lidded container.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Pour the brine solution over the chops until they are covered.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Cover with a lid or plastic wrap and place in the fridge.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Brine for about 2 hours.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Remove from brine and rinse to remove any extra salt.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Sauté about a 1/3 cup mixture of celery, onions and bell peppers with 1 TBS of cooking oil.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Remove vegetables and brown 1 lb of breakfast sausage in the same pan.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Add the vegetables to the sausage to combine and remove from heat to cool.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Season pork chops with Jeff's Texas style rub recipe inside the pocket and on the outside.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Stuff the chops with the sausage mixture.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Leave the pork chops sitting pocket side up leaning against the side of a foil pan.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Place the pan of pork chops on the smoker grate.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Smoke cook the meat for about 2 hours or until they reach 145°F in the thickest part.
c38b832c-877a-446a-8136-14bd46e04d57
Serve immediately.
25b9083a-b721-415e-8936-5e3b67042852
Remove meat from wrapper
25b9083a-b721-415e-8936-5e3b67042852
Inject cherry Dr Pepper into pork butt about every 2 inches.
25b9083a-b721-415e-8936-5e3b67042852
Generously apply Jeff's original rub to all sides of pork butt.
25b9083a-b721-415e-8936-5e3b67042852
Setup smoker for cooking at 225-240°F.
25b9083a-b721-415e-8936-5e3b67042852
Place pork butt into smoker fat cap down.
25b9083a-b721-415e-8936-5e3b67042852
When internal temperature of meat reaches 160°F, it can be wrapped in foil, if desired, to speed up the process.
25b9083a-b721-415e-8936-5e3b67042852
Let the internal temperature of the meat come to about 205°F before calling it done.
25b9083a-b721-415e-8936-5e3b67042852
Let the meat cool uncovered on the counter for about an hour.
25b9083a-b721-415e-8936-5e3b67042852
Remove the bone from the meat and discard.
25b9083a-b721-415e-8936-5e3b67042852
Pull the meat apart into sections removing any clumps of fat as you go.
25b9083a-b721-415e-8936-5e3b67042852
Further pull the meat into smaller pieces discarding any fat or gristle that you find.
25b9083a-b721-415e-8936-5e3b67042852
Season the finished pulled pork again with Jeff's original rub and stir around to disperse.
25b9083a-b721-415e-8936-5e3b67042852
The pulled pork is now ready to use as you wish.
5a354916-3c4d-4070-bca6-ca36bad7c10f
Make buttermilk brine by combining ½ gallon buttermilk with ½ cup coarse kosher salt. Stir for 2 minutes or until dissolved.
5a354916-3c4d-4070-bca6-ca36bad7c10f
Place chicken into brine-safe lidded container.
5a354916-3c4d-4070-bca6-ca36bad7c10f
Pour buttermilk brine over chicken to cover.
5a354916-3c4d-4070-bca6-ca36bad7c10f
Place container with chicken into fridge for 4 hours during brining.
5a354916-3c4d-4070-bca6-ca36bad7c10f
Rinse chicken well to remove any residual salt and discard brine.
5a354916-3c4d-4070-bca6-ca36bad7c10f
Lay chicken thighs flat on cutting board.
5a354916-3c4d-4070-bca6-ca36bad7c10f
Season liberally with Jeff's original rub.
5a354916-3c4d-4070-bca6-ca36bad7c10f
Place ½ white cheddar cheese stick and 1 teaspoon of diced jalapeño onto chicken thigh
5a354916-3c4d-4070-bca6-ca36bad7c10f
Fold chicken thigh over.
5a354916-3c4d-4070-bca6-ca36bad7c10f
Wrap stretched piece of bacon around chicken thigh to hold it closed.
5a354916-3c4d-4070-bca6-ca36bad7c10f
Wrap another piece of bacon from end to end to keep the cheese from coming out once it melts.
5a354916-3c4d-4070-bca6-ca36bad7c10f
Smoke chicken thighs for about 1.5 hours at 250°F using apple or other smoking wood.
5a354916-3c4d-4070-bca6-ca36bad7c10f
Serve immediately.
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Cube the Meat Cut the meat into 1-inch cubes or pieces
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Add the Flavor Generously apply Jeff's original rub all over the meat making sure to coat all sides
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Add the Flavor Cover container with lid or plastic wrap.
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Add the Flavor Place meat in fridge for at least 4 hours but overnight is better to allow the meat to marinate and take on the flavor.
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Prepare the Peppers Clean and deseed jalapeños.
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Prepare the Peppers Cut peppers in half then cut into pieces about ¾ inch square
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Partially Pre-cook the Bacon Cut the bacon in half
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Partially Pre-cook the Bacon Lay the half-strips of bacon into a shallow baking sheet and cook in 375°F oven for about 6 minutes
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Make the Pops Cut long skewers to the length you want or about 4 inches long.
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Make the Pops Wrap a single piece of meat in a half-slice of partially pre-cooked bacon
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Make the Pops Push pointed end of skewers through a piece of pepper then into the bacon wrapped piece of meat
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Make the Pops Continue with all meat until completed
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Smoke the Piggy Pops Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Smoke the Piggy Pops Place the pops on the smoker grate and close the door
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Smoke the Piggy Pops Once the pops are almost done, drizzle sauce on the top (optional)
7f329550-7901-4344-b8c6-8b7f0d0c7e25 Smoke the Piggy Pops Pops are done when they reach 145°F in the center (tenderloin) or 165 °F in the center for pork country style rib meat.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Brine the Chicken Add 1 cup of coarse kosher salt to 1 gallon of cold water. Stir until water returns to clear and salt is dissolved.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Brine the Chicken Add ¾ cup brown sugar and stir until dissolved into brine.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Brine the Chicken Place chicken pieces into zip top bag and pour brine solution over chicken to cover.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Brine the Chicken Seal bag or cover brining container and put into the fridge for about 4 hours.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Brine the Chicken Remove brined chicken from fridge and rinse well under cold water to remove residual salt.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Brine the Chicken Pat the chicken dry with a paper towel
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Brine the Chicken For better skin, place the chicken back into the fridge on a cooling rack, bradley rack, etc. over a baking sheet (to catch drips) for about 4 hours to dry and tighten the skin before applying glaze.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Make the Mayo Glaze Make the glaze while the chicken is brining
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Make the Mayo Glaze Into a small mixing bowl combine ½ cup of real mayonnaise, 2 TBS of Jeff's original rub, 1 TBS minced garlic and 2 TBS chopped chives
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Apply the Glaze to the Chicken Place a heaping TBS of the mayo glaze onto each chicken quarter.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Apply the Glaze to the Chicken Use your hands to massage the glaze all over the chicken getting it under the skin wherever possible.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Apply the Glaze to the Chicken Chicken is now ready for the smoker.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Into the Smoker Set up the smoker for cooking at 275°F using pecan or other smoking wood.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Into the Smoker Once the smoker is ready, place the chicken directly on the smoker grate.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Into the Smoker Let the chicken cook for 1 to 1.5 hours or until it reaches 165°F in the thickest part.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Into the Smoker For extra good chicken skin, remove the chicken before it is completely done (about 145-150°F) and place it on a very hot grill or under the oven broiler for a few minutes.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Into the Smoker Be sure it reaches a final temperature of 165°F before calling it done.
00c8b40e-c503-49f4-8b6e-3c705a7f77b9 Serve It Up Serve immediately.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Score the Fat Lay the brisket fat side up on the cutting board.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Score the Fat Using a sharp knife, cut a crosshatch pattern through the fat down to the meat.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Score the Fat Make the cuts about 1 inch apart.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Mark the Grain Flip the brisket over so that it is fat side down.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Mark the Grain Take notice of the direction the meat fibers are running.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Mark the Grain On the corner edge, make a cut halfway through the meat across those meat fibers.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Mark the Grain This is to mark the grain direction so you will know how to slice it once it's finished cooking.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Mustard and Rub Apply a thin coat of spicy mustard to the top and sides of the brisket.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Mustard and Rub Sprinkle Jeff's original rub or the Texas style rub onto the area coated with mustard.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Mustard and Rub Flip the brisket over and repeat the mustard and rub on the other side.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Smoke Setup and preheat smoker at about 225°F.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Smoke Place the brisket on the smoker grate fat side up.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Smoke Allow the brisket to cook for 18-22 hours or until it reaches 195-205°F in the center of the meat.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Rest Once the brisket is finished cooking, place it in the foil lined bottom of an empty cooler.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Rest Cover top with foil.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Rest Place towels and/or newspaper over the brisket to help insulate it.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Rest Leave in cooler for 2-4 hours to tenderize.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Slice Remove brisket from cooler and place on cutting board.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Slice Slice into pencil thick slices across the grain using the grain marker cut into the corner as a guide.
ab1c22d1-e5c1-4b91-bb97-380b9f890f55 Slice Serve and enjoy!
f4174dae-7ce5-4ab9-ba69-c2daea979b29 Prep the Prime Rib Ask the butcher to cut off the bones and then tie it all back up for you. You can also ask him to "french" the bones for you to make it look real nice.
f4174dae-7ce5-4ab9-ba69-c2daea979b29 Oil and Seasoning Apply a good coating of oil to the entire outside surface of the prime rib to help the seasoning to stick.
f4174dae-7ce5-4ab9-ba69-c2daea979b29 Oil and Seasoning Sprinkle Jeff's Texas style rub onto the meat on all sides. Don't forget the ends.
f4174dae-7ce5-4ab9-ba69-c2daea979b29 Smoke Time Setup your smoker for cooking at about 225°F
f4174dae-7ce5-4ab9-ba69-c2daea979b29 Smoke Time Apply light smoke for the entire time if possible or for at least 3 hours.
f4174dae-7ce5-4ab9-ba69-c2daea979b29 Smoke Time Monitor the temperature and when the temperature reaches about 130°F, remove it from the smoker.
f4174dae-7ce5-4ab9-ba69-c2daea979b29 Smoke Time Tent foil over the top of the meat and let it rest for 10-15 minutes.
f4174dae-7ce5-4ab9-ba69-c2daea979b29 Slice and Serve Cut the strings that are holding the roast and bones together.
f4174dae-7ce5-4ab9-ba69-c2daea979b29 Slice and Serve Remove the rack of bones and set them aside.
f4174dae-7ce5-4ab9-ba69-c2daea979b29 Slice and Serve Slice the roast into ½ to ¾ inch slices.
f4174dae-7ce5-4ab9-ba69-c2daea979b29 Slice and Serve Serve to your guests and enjoy!
b0ccf381-26ff-4446-aed9-4ab6fd073365 Mustard Place the ham on a cutting board or down in a pan.
b0ccf381-26ff-4446-aed9-4ab6fd073365 Mustard Squeeze on some regular yellow mustard and rub it over the entire surface area of the ham.
b0ccf381-26ff-4446-aed9-4ab6fd073365 Jeff's Rub Sprinkle about a half cup of Jeff's rub onto the top of the ham and rub it over the mustard creating a paste.
b0ccf381-26ff-4446-aed9-4ab6fd073365 Jeff's Rub Be sure to cover the entire surface of the ham with rub.
b0ccf381-26ff-4446-aed9-4ab6fd073365 Jeff's Rub If you need more rub, don't be afraid to use it.
b0ccf381-26ff-4446-aed9-4ab6fd073365 Jeff's Rub When the ham is ready to cook, place it on a Bradley rack or a cookie sheet to make it easy to transport to and from the smoker.
b0ccf381-26ff-4446-aed9-4ab6fd073365 Smoker Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225°F. We aren't trying to cook the ham, just bring it to a nice eating temperature of about 140°F.
b0ccf381-26ff-4446-aed9-4ab6fd073365 Smoker When the smoker is ready, place the ham directly on the grate or if you are using a Bradley rack, you can lay the rack directly on the smoker grate.
b0ccf381-26ff-4446-aed9-4ab6fd073365 Smoker Let the ham cook for about 3 hours or until it reaches an internal temperature of 140°F.
b0ccf381-26ff-4446-aed9-4ab6fd073365 Smoker Keep the smoke going the entire time if you are using an electric, gas or charcoal smoker.
b0ccf381-26ff-4446-aed9-4ab6fd073365 Serve When the ham is finished, it can be served immediately or wrapped in foil and kept warm until dinner if necessary.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Remove the membrane Remove the membrane from the boney side of the ribs. Lift it up using a butter knife or similar then use a paper towel or catfish pliers to get a good grip and pull it clean off.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Maple Syrup and Seasoning Coat both sides of the ribs with maple syrup and Jeff's original rub (recipe). Brush on the maple syrup then sprinkle on the rub to cover well. Allow the rub to sit on the first side until it starts looking wet then flip it over and repeat on the other side.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Into Fridge Overnight (optional) Place seasoned ribs into a lidded container or wrap them in plastic wrap and place into fridge overnight to enhance the flavor.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Smoke the Ribs (part one) Setup smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Smoke the Ribs (part one) Have enough smoking wood on hand to maintain light smoke for about 4 hours.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Smoke the Ribs (part one) Once smoker is ready, place ribs directly on smoker grate and close door/lid of smoker.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Smoke the Ribs (part one) When the ribs have been cooking for about 3 hours, baste them with the maple barbecue glaze.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Maple Barbecue Glaze -¼ cup of maple syrup
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Maple Barbecue Glaze -2 TBS of Jeff's original rub
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Maple Barbecue Glaze Mix ingredients together and stir well to combine. Continue to stir during use to maintain proper mixture.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Smoke the Ribs (part two) Let the ribs continue to cook/smoke for about 1.5 hours then glaze them again with the maple barbecue glaze.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Smoke the Ribs (part two) Total time is about 5 hours. If the ribs are extra meaty, they may require additional cooking time.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Smoke the Ribs (part two) The ribs are finished when they are tender.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Smoke the Ribs (part two) Check for tenderness by lifting up one end. The ribs will bend in half when they are fully done, tender and ready to eat.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Smoke the Ribs (part two) You can also pull apart on 2 adjacent rib bones to test the tenderness and looseness of the meat.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Slice and Serve Place the ribs boney side up on the cutting board.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Slice and Serve Slice between the bones using a sharp knife.
8f2db522-afad-463d-b4a7-28d166a093af Slice and Serve Serve
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Cut Pork into Cubes Ok, they don't actually have to be perfect cubes. Pieces, whether square or oblong that are about 1 inch wide will work perfectly.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Add Rub There's two ways you can go about adding the rub:
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Add Rub Bag Method (best if you want to season them the night before)
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Add Rub Place all of the pieces into a bag
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Add Rub Add 2-3 TBS of vegetable oil and ¼ cup of rub to the bag
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Add Rub Seal bag and shake, roll, massage bag to coat the pieces of meat
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Add Rub Place in fridge until ready to use
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Add Rub Fast Method (the method I used)
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Add Rub Place the meat onto a cooling rack or Bradley rack in a single layer making sure to leave a little space between each one so the smoke and heat can get to them.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Add Rub Spray top and sides with vegetable oil
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Add Rub Sprinkle Jeff's original rub onto meat
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Smoke Cook the Meat to About 160°F If you used the bag method, remove the meat from the fridge and place the pieces onto a cooling rack or Bradley rack in a single layer making sure to leave a little space between each one so the smoke and heat can get to them.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Smoke Cook the Meat to About 160°F Setup your smoker for cooking at about 225°F with pecan smoke or other favorite smoking wood.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Smoke Cook the Meat to About 160°F If your smoker has a water pan, use it.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Smoke Cook the Meat to About 160°F Once the smoker is ready, place the racks of meat into the smoker and let them cook until they reach about 160°F.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Smoke Cook the Meat to About 160°F This will take 3-4 hours depending on how cold the meat is when it goes in and how well the smoker maintains the goal temperature.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Smoke Cook the Meat to About 160°F During this time, the most important thing is the smoke flavor so keep a light smoke going constantly.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Into a Foil Pan with Sauce and More Rub When the meat reaches about 160°F it is time to start creating the delicious bark on the outside of the pork burnt ends.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Into a Foil Pan with Sauce and More Rub Place all of the pieces of meat into foil pans.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Into a Foil Pan with Sauce and More Rub Keep it to a single layer rather than piling it on top of each other. You may need to use multiple pans.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Into a Foil Pan with Sauce and More Rub Add sauce to the top of the meat and stir it around. This is for flavor, bark creation and to help the rub to stick.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Into a Foil Pan with Sauce and More Rub Sprinkle my rub generously to the top of the meat and once again stir the meat to coat well.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Cook Until Tender or about 185°F Place the pans of meat into the smoker and continue to keep the smoke and heat going as before for 1-2 more hours.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Cook Until Tender or about 185°F If you have a smoker that is capable of higher temperatures, bark can be best achieved at 275°F or even higher. The grill will also work for this.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Cook Until Tender or about 185°F The meat will need to be stirred every 30 minutes or so. More often at higher temperatures.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Cook Until Tender or about 185°F When the meat reaches 185°F and has a nice bark formation all over, it is done and ready to eat.
97101e24-6297-4e81-bd7a-f1d9892919eb Serve as Appetizer or Entree Burnt ends are great appetizers eaten with a toothpick or a pile of burnt ends next to mashed potatoes and barbecue beans is a real crowd pleaser.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Clean and Deseed the Peppers Wash the jalapeños..
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Clean and Deseed the Peppers Cut off the stem end
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Clean and Deseed the Peppers Use a thin blade knife or even an oyster shucker to scrape the inside of the peppers and remove the seeds and veins.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Soak the Peppers (optional) If you do not like any "hotness" in your jalapeños, consider soaking them in a citrus flavored soda for several hours to remove some of the capsaicin (the chemical in peppers that make them taste hot)
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Soak the Peppers (optional) After cleaning them, place them in a bowl and pour citrus soda over them to cover.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Soak the Peppers (optional) Soak them in this for 3-4 hours or even longer depending on how mild you want them to be.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Soak the Peppers (optional) I recommend tasting of a small bit of the stem end that you cut off to see how hot they are before deciding whether they need to be soaked or not. Some jalapeños are extremely mild while others can be a little less tame.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Soak the Peppers (optional) When the peppers are finished soaking, remove them from the soda. Save the soda if you wish to flavor brines, soups, whatever needs a little jalapeño flavor.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Make the Stuffing Hopefully you left the cream cheese on the countertop for an hour or so to soften. This will make it easier to work with.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Make the Stuffing Turkey Cranberry Cream Cheese Stuffing: 8 oz of cream cheese, 1/2 cup of shredded cheddar, 2TBS cranberry relish, ¼ cup of Jeff's original rub, ¾ to 1 cup turkey pieces.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Make the Stuffing Place all of the ingredients into a mixing bowl and use a spoon to fold all of the ingredients together so that it is well combined.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Fill with Stuffing Use a spoon or your fingers to press the stuffing into the open end of the jalapeño peppers making sure they are completely filled and running over the edge.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Wrap in Bacon Lay a piece of bacon on the cutting board
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Wrap in Bacon Place one of the stuffed peppers onto one end of the pepper about 1 inch from the end.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Wrap in Bacon Wrap the short end of the bacon over the top of the pepper.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Wrap in Bacon Wrap the long end of the bacon over the top of the pepper and all the way around again to seal the pepper and to use up the piece of bacon.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Wrap in Bacon Note: it is ok to cut the peppers in half so that you have boats. This makes it easier to stuff and wrap but allows the cheese to leak out a little more and gives you less jalapeño flavor.. your choice.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Smoke Until Done Once all of the peppers are stuffed and wrapped, place them on a Bradley rack or on a cookie sheet for easy transport out to the smoker.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Smoke Until Done Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-240 °F for approximately 3 hours.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Smoke Until Done Use the water pan if you have one in your smoker and be sure to have enough dry wood chips, chunks or pellets for at least 1.5 to 2 hours. It is also ok to continue the smoke throughout the entire process.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Smoke Until Done If you are not using a Bradley rack, place the peppers on the grate making sure they are not able to fall through.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Smoke Until Done Cook smoke the peppers for about 3 hours or until they peppers are nice and soft and the bacon is done cooking.
3de15b25-0da9-4a76-9d2b-282511d8dafe Serve Them Serve the turkey and cranberry stuffed abt's right away while the cheese is still oozing and hot.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Spatchcock (Butterfly) Remove the turkey from it's packaging.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Spatchcock (Butterfly) Remove giblets, neck, pop-up timer and any plastic or hardware that is holding the legs together.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Spatchcock (Butterfly) Place the turkey on your cutting board with the backbone facing up and neck end toward you.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Spatchcock (Butterfly) Using a pair of heavy duty kitchen shears, cut along both sides of the backbone to completely remove it from the turkey.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Spatchcock (Butterfly) Turn the turkey breast side up and press down with both hands to flatten it.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Brine Overnight (optional) Make a simple turkey brine using 1 gallon of cold water, 1 cup of coarse kosher salt and ¾ cup of dark brown sugar. (the sugar is optional but I think it adds a lot to the brine).
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Brine Overnight (optional) Pour the salt into the water and stir until it becomes clear again. Add the sugar and stir until it dissolves. Double or triple the brine recipe as required.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Brine Overnight (optional) Place the turkey in a plastic, glass or stainless steel container and pour the brine over the bird to cover.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Brine Overnight (optional) Place a lid or cover on the container with the bird and the brine and place it in the refrigerator overnight or 8-12 hours.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Rinse and Dry When the turkey is finished brining, discard the brine and rinse the turkey really well under cold water.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Rinse and Dry Dry the inside and outside of the turkey with clean paper towels.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Rinse and Dry Place the turkey in the fridge uncovered for about 2 hours to allow the skin to dry further.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Rinse and Dry While the drying process is occurring, make up the herb butter (recipe below)
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Make the Herbed Butter Combine 1 stick of softened butter, 1/4 cup chopped parsley, 1/4 cup chopped thyme, 1/4 cup chopped chives, 1/4 cup onion, 5 garlic cloves, 2 TBS Jeff's Texas Rub
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Make the Herbed Butter If made ahead, allow it to soften to help with the application.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Apply Herbed Butter Split the butter into (2) parts and put half of it under the skin and half of it on the outside of the skin.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Apply Herbed Butter Work your hands between the skin and the meat tearing the membrane loose as you go. Do this carefully and patiently and you will be able to completely loosen the skin from the breast meat and even the thighs and legs. Leave the skin attached around the edges (except for where your hand entered) to help hold in the butter and herbs.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Apply Herbed Butter Once the skin is loose enough, stuff some of the herbed butter in the breast area, the thighs, and the legs. Pat it down from the outside to spread it out a little more.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Apply Herbed Butter Apply the remaining herbed butter on the outside of the skin.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Season with Texas Rub Season the entire turkey skin side and meat side with my Texas rub for perfect seasoning throughout.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Smoke Time Set up your smoker for cooking at about 240°F.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Smoke Time If your smoker has a water pan, it's a great idea to use as this helps to reduce the drying effect of the heat.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Smoke Time Make sure you have enough smoking wood to last for at least 2 hours.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Smoke Time Place the spatchcocked turkey skin side up and let it smoke cook for about 4 hours at 240°F.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Smoke Time Monitor the temperature of the breast at it's thickest part and when it reaches about 158-160 it's time to move it from the heat.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Rest and Serve Quickly tent some foil over the bird and leave it for about 10-15 minutes to rest before carving.
906d0c4a-6090-4377-9742-c2732b88f172 Rest and Serve To carve, remove the leg quarters then separate the thigh from the leg. Remove the wings then remove the breast meat in one big section by cutting along the carcass as you pull back on the breast meat. Slice the breast meat into pieces and you are ready to eat.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Brine the Turkey Cutlets Make about ½ gallon of brine or whatever is required to cover the turkey cutlets.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Brine the Turkey Cutlets Basic Brine: ½ gallon of cold water, ½ cup of coarse kosher salt, ½ cup dark brown sugar (optional)
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Brine the Turkey Cutlets To this recipe you can add fruit juice, beer, wine, hot sauce, marinade, seasoning, almost anything and the flavor will make it's way deep into the meat.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Brine the Turkey Cutlets To make the brine: Start by adding ½ gallon of water to a large pitcher. Pour in the salt and stir until the salt is dissolved into the water. Add the sugar and stir once again until it is dissolved.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Brine the Turkey Cutlets Add any other ingredients you like and give it one last stir to combine. The brining solution is now ready to use.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Brine the Turkey Cutlets Place the turkey cutlets into a bowl or even a zip top bag and pour enough brine over the meat to cover. Seal it up and place in the fridge for 2-4 hours for best results.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Brine the Turkey Cutlets Once the brining is complete, you will want to discard the brining solution and rinse the turkey cutlets with cold water to remove any excess salt.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Season and Stuff Lay the turkey cutlets on a cutting board or into a foil pan and coat the top and bottom sides with my original rub (purchase recipes here).
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Season and Stuff Place about a tablespoon of diced jalapeño and a tablespoon of shredded cheddar onto one half of the cutlet.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Season and Stuff Fold the cutlet over to finish the stuffing process.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Wrap in Bacon Pick up the stuffed turkey carefully with one hand and wrap bacon around the stuffed turkey cutlet so as to hold in the cheese and the jalapeños.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Wrap in Bacon I wrapped mine tight with 2 pieces.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Wrap in Bacon Give them another good sprinkle of rub (purchase recipes here) on the outside and they are ready to cook.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Prepare Smoker Setup your smoker/cooker for cooking at about 240°F with indirect heat for about 2 hours.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Prepare Smoker If your smoker has a water pan, use it.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Prepare Smoker Make sure you have enough dry smoking wood for at least 1 hour but it is ok to keep a light smoke going for the entire cooking time of 2 hours or so.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Prepare Smoker Once the smoker is preheated and everything is ready to go, the cooking smoking process can commence.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Smoke the Turkey Bombs Bradley racks or something similar is a great way to transport these and almost anything you cook to and from the smoker.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Smoke the Turkey Bombs Place the rack in the smoker or you can lay the wrapped turkey bombs directly on the smoker grate.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Smoke the Turkey Bombs Maintain 225-240°F for the entire time and keep a light smoke flowing.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Smoke the Turkey Bombs Monitor the temperature of the turkey by using a leave in digital meat thermometer such as the Maverick ET-733 or Maverick ET-735.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Smoke the Turkey Bombs You can also check the temperature now and then using a Thermapen. Since these read so quickly, you can open the door/lid, check the temperature and close the door/lid in less than 8 seconds without a significant loss of heat.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Smoke the Turkey Bombs When they reach 160°F, they are perfectly done and ready to be taken out of the smoker. It is not uncommon for me to remove them a degree or two early since I know the temperature will continue to rise even after they come out of the smoker due to residual heat.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Smoke the Turkey Bombs Let them rest covered loosely with foil for about 5 minutes before serving.
290550eb-9e7c-4459-ab7b-a2a9071cc3e4 Serve After the resting is complete, serve a smoked jalapeño cheddar turkey bomb to each diner with plenty of tasty sides and you'll have a meal to remember.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Get the Smoker Going Unlike most of my instructions, we are going to get the smoker going first since the bacon needs to go on right from the package without any additional preparation.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Get the Smoker Going We will cook the bacon for about 45-60 minutes before adding the glaze to it which magically transforms it into smoked pig candy.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Get the Smoker Going I used a small cabinet style electric smoker for this but you can use whatever smoker you want as long as it will maintain about 240-250°F using indirect heat.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Get the Smoker Going While the smoker is coming up to temperature or preheating, go inside and get the bacon out of the package and ready to cook.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Bacon into Smoker I placed my bacon onto Bradley racks to make it easy but you can also just lay the bacon right onto the smoker grate if you want.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Bacon into Smoker I do not recommend using a cookie sheet since it's important that the smoke can get to the bacon from all sides.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Bacon into Smoker I laid the racks of bacon right on the smoker grates and then placed a throw-away foil pan under the racks of a bacon on a lower shelf to catch the bacon drippings and the glaze.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Bacon into Smoker Note: I like to reduce cleanup as much as possible.. not sure if that means I'm working smart or if I'm really lazy but cleanup is not my favorite part of this process and I work hard to reduce and even eliminate it wherever I can.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Bacon into Smoker The bacon will cook this way for about 45 minutes.. if you are running a little less than 250°F you will want to give it a few extra minutes and leave it in there about 1 hour.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Bacon into Smoker While the bacon does it's thing in the smoker, go inside and make the candy glaze.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Make the Glaze Add the following ingredients to a small mixing bowl: ½ cup brown sugar (I used the dark), ¼ cup maple syrup, ¼ cup bourbon, ½ cup Jeff's original rub, 2 TBS honey.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Make the Glaze Mix it up real well and if you want it to be a little more thin, you can add an extra tablespoon or two of bourbon (can't go wrong there).
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Make the Glaze Note: if you do not want to use bourbon for some reason, you can use Dr. Pepper in the same quantity and leave out the honey since there is additional sweetness in the soda.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 First Glazing of the Bacon Once the bacon has been cooking for about 45-60 minutes, it is time to start brushing on the glaze.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 First Glazing of the Bacon Using a long handled silicone brush, open the door and quickly brush a layer of glaze onto the top side of the bacon.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 First Glazing of the Bacon Flip the bacon over and glaze the bottom side.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 First Glazing of the Bacon Close the smoker door and set a timer for 30 minutes.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Second Glazing of the Bacon Once again using a long handled silicone brush, open the smoker door or lid and quickly brush a layer of glaze onto the top side of the bacon.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Second Glazing of the Bacon Flip the bacon over and glaze the bottom side.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Second Glazing of the Bacon Close the smoker door and once again set the timer for 30 minutes.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Cool It Very quickly remove the bacon from the grates or the bradley racks and place it onto wax paper to cool.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Cool It As it cools the bacon and glaze hardens and it becomes more and more difficult to remove from the racks.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Cool It I was not quick enough.. be faster than me and you should be ok.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Whole or Pieces? If you are able to get them off in whole strips then you can decide if you like them better that way. If you have issues with them breaking up, it's still ok to serve them as pieces.
0fa498d8-86d9-4304-ab25-b24b042e7bf6 Whole or Pieces? And.. be sure to save some of the smaller pieces for that big bowl of ice cream I know you've been contemplating!
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Marinate Remove the pork sirloin from it's packaging and give it a good rinse under cold water.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Marinate Place the roast in a large zip top bag
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Marinate Pour enough teriyaki sauce over the meat to fully coat.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Marinate Press the air from the bag and zip it closed to create a vacuum and help the marinade to stay close to the meat.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Marinate Put the bagged meat in the fridge for at least 4 hours and up to overnight or 8 hours.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Marinate When the marinate time is over, remove the pork sirloin from the bag to season it.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Marinate Do not rinse the marinade off.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Season I like to place the meat in a foil pan to contain the mess
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Season Coat the entire surface of the pork sirloin roast with my original rub.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Season Be generous!
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Season Leave the rubbed meat laying while you go get the smoker ready.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Get the Smoker Ready Prepare the smoker for a 2 hour cook at about 225-240°F with enough smoking wood for at least 1 hour.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Get the Smoker Ready You can also use a grill as long as you set it up for cooking indirect.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Get the Smoker Ready Note: to cook indirect on a typical 3 or 4 burner gas grill, only light one or two of the burners on one side. Place the meat on the opposite side over unlit burners.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Get the Smoker Ready On a charcoal grill, place coals on both side of the grill and place a metal pan of water in the center between the coals. The meat goes directly over the water pan.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Get the Smoker Ready Smoke will come from wood chips wrapped in foil and placed over the coals or over the lit burners. Replace wood chips as needed to keep the smoke going for at least 1 hour.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Smoke Cook the Pork Sirloin Once the smoker or grill is ready, place the meat directly on the grate or you can use a Bradley rack for easy transport to and from the smoker.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Smoke Cook the Pork Sirloin Cook the meat at 225-240°F for about 2 hours or until it reaches an internal temperature of 145°F.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Smoke Cook the Pork Sirloin Note: For years now we have been told to cook pork to 160°F to make sure it is safe. Recently, this safe temperature was reduced to 145°F. I do understand that some folks do not deal well with change (yours truly) but if you can manage it, you will find that pork is so much better at this lower finished temperature. It ends up a lot more moist and flavorful due to it not being cooked to death.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Smoke Cook the Pork Sirloin For more teriyaki flavor, you can mix 2 parts teriyaki sauce with my barbecue sauce to make a uniquely delicious flavored sauce for this smoked pork sirloin. Apply the sauce a couple of times during the last 30 minutes in the smoker.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Serve it Up After removing the meat from the smoker, tent a piece of foil loosely over the meat and let it rest about 10 minutes before serving.
2c03facd-5e6e-4156-8f34-e6e35422e01c Serve it Up After resting, slice it up and serve it immediately.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Marinate Place the chicken wing sections into a large plastic or glass bowl.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Marinate Drizzle Franks original RedHot® sauce over the top of all the wings
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Marinate Stir them around to fully coat.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Marinate Sprinkle Jeff's original rub also called Jeff's naked rib rub onto the top of the wing sections (be generous).
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Marinate Stir the wings around to get the rub all over.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Marinate Repeat the rub and the stirring to make sure you have plenty of rub on the chicken wings.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Marinate Cover the container with a lid, plastic wrap or foil and place them in the fridge for about 4 hours to marinate.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Marinate When the marinating is finished, place the wing sections on a bradley rack or cookie sheet for easy transport out to the smoker.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Set up Smoker Set up your smoker for cooking at about 250°F.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Set up Smoker You will be keeping this heat going for about 1 to 1.5 hours so you'll want enough smoking wood for about 1 hour.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Set up Smoker Once the smoker is maintaining the proper temperature, you can proceed with the cooking process.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Smoke Chicken Wings If you used a Bradley rack, you can just place the Bradley rack right on the smoker grate and close the door or lid.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Smoke Chicken Wings Otherwise, place the chicken wing sections on the smoker grate with a little space between them to allow the heat and smoke to get to them easily.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Smoke Chicken Wings Keep a light pecan smoke going for at least 1 hour. You can also use another wood if you do not have pecan or if you have another favorite smoking wood.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Smoke Chicken Wings A Thermapen is really useful for checking things like chicken wings. It's quick and you can check a lot of wings in a very short period of time.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Smoke Chicken Wings A Thermapen is a really nice hand held thermometer that checks the temperature of meat in around 2-3 seconds by simply poking the meat with the probe.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Smoke Chicken Wings You can use a different thermometer if you have one, just make sure it is accurate so you don't undercook the chicken.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Smoke Chicken Wings When the chicken reaches an internal temperature of 175°F, it is time to super heat and crisp the skin.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Crisp Skin This process can be done on the grill or under the oven broiler--
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Crisp Skin I highly recommend using the broiler feature on your home oven for this to get a more consistent heating. Turn it on "High" and it should be ready within just a minute or two.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Crisp Skin Important: Transfer the chicken to a cookie sheet to prevent the grease from dripping down onto your oven floor and starting a fire.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Crisp Skin Electric (or Gas) broiler at top of oven:
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Crisp Skin Place the pan about 10-12 inches under the broiler.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Crisp Skin After a minute or so the skin will start to sizzle/bubble and get dark, and when they reach a nice brown color, it is time to flip them over.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Crisp Skin Flip the chicken pieces over and do the same on the other side.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Crisp Skin Gas broiler in a drawer under the oven:
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Crisp Skin Place the pan of chicken under the broiler and leave the drawer pulled out so you can watch it the entire time. This type of broiler usually has the food closer to the heat so it will get done really fast.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Crisp Skin Very quickly the skin will start to sizzle/bubble and get dark, and when they reach a nice brown color, it is time to flip them over.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Crisp Skin Pull the pan out of the broiler, flip the chicken pieces over and repeat the broiling process to crisp the skin on the other side.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Crisp Skin Note: The time will vary depending on how far the chicken is from the broiler element but it is imperative that you do not walk away during this process. Turn on the oven light, if you have one and watch them so they do not burn. When you see the sizzling of the skin, let that go on for about 15 seconds then proceed to flip them over.
f7d48316-7d90-4e6a-8170-f2593bd40d74 Serve When the smoked chicken wings come out off the grill or out from the broiler, serve them immediately for best results. There's nothing quite as good as smoked chicken wings still hot and burning your fingers.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Remove Fat and Membrane The whole rack and even the pieces already cut up will usually have a layer of fat on top of the meat. I choose to remove this as there is plenty of fat within the meat and I like for the rub to make direct contact with the meat.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Remove Fat and Membrane I asked the butcher to do this for me but it's pretty easy to do with a sharp knife. Be sure to remove any silverskin you find as well.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Remove Fat and Membrane Some of the fat runs deep into the meat and so you just have to trim it down level with the meat and stop, otherwise, you'd be cutting so far into the meat, the rack would separate into pieces.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Remove Fat and Membrane Do the best you can and let the heat melt the rest of it away as it keeps the beef short ribs juicy.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Remove Fat and Membrane Flip the rack of beef ribs over to the membrane side and either remove the membrane or score it really good with a sharp knife. I got a small corner loose then grabbed it with a paper towel to pull it clean off.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Marinate & Season the Meat With the fat and silverskin removed, place the rack of ribs into a plastic or glass container and pour enough Worcestershire sauce over the meat to wet it real good.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Marinate & Season the Meat Add several tablespoons of minced garlic to the top and use a spoon to spread it over the meat. I used minced garlic in a bottle as it works just fine for things like this.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Marinate & Season the Meat Finally, sprinkle a good layer of my Texas rub (purchase recipes here) onto the top meat side and let it sit there for a few minutes and mingle with the other ingredients.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Marinate & Season the Meat Once it looks nice and wet, flip the rack of beef short ribs over to top side down.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Marinate & Season the Meat Pour a little more Worcestershire sauce down in the bottom of the container to make sure the meat is making contact with the sauce.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Marinate & Season the Meat Place a lid or cover on the container and put it it the fridge for at least 3 hours but up to 8 hours is perfectly fine.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Set up Smoker While the meat is finishing up the marinating time, go ahead and get the smoker ready to go.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Set up Smoker You'll want to set it up for cooking at about 250°F with about 3-4 hours worth of smoking wood.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Smoke Time I like to place the rack of ribs down in a foil pan to contain the juices while it cooks and especially if I plan to cover with foil later.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Smoke Time Bone side down, meat side up is the proper configuration.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Smoke Time Place the pan into a 250°F smoker and maintain light smoke for at least 3-4 hours.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Smoke Time If your smoker has a water pan, I recommend using it.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Smoke Time Use a leave-in digital probe meat thermometer so you can monitor the temperature. The probe should go into meat only, without touching bone.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Smoke Time The beef short ribs are cooked to about 200°F before calling them done. I took mine to 203°F and inserting a sharp skewer into the meat was giving me almost no resistance at all.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Smoke Time You can expect the beef short ribs to take 7-9 hours to reach 200°F. Be sure to use the Temperature NOT the time to tell you when they are done.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Smoke Time If you want to cover them at 160°F internal meat temperature it will help to speed them along but the bark formation will not be as good. I left mine uncovered down in the pan for the entire time.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Smoke Time Once the ribs were finished cooking, I removed them from the smoker to the countertop and placed another foil pan on top to hold in a little heat while the meat rested for about 30 minutes.
1b934e01-bec9-4382-84de-f6835f76aad3 Cut and Serve Cut the rack of ribs into individual bones and let folks dig in.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Rinse These often come packaged in sets of (2) and it rarely says so on the package for some reason. A good way to tell is by the weight-- most tenderloins will weigh around 1 lb each so a 2 lb package probably has (2) tenderloins. If it says 1.17 lbs, there's probably only one in there.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Rinse Remove these from the package and give them a good rinse under cold water.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Rinse Pat dry with a paper towel and lay them on the cutting board.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Remove Silverskin Use a very sharp knife to remove the silverskin that will often be along one side.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Remove Silverskin Slip the knife under one end and just follow it to the end. If you miss a part of it, just give it another go.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Remove Silverskin While you have the knife in hand, it's a good idea to remove any excess fat as well.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Apply Rub I normally use my original rub on all pork but I wanted to try out the Texas style recipe on these pork tenderloins so I did one with the original recipe and one with the Texas style recipe.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Apply Rub As an afterthought, I also decided to use a different sticking base for each one.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Apply Rub Mayonnaise contains oil and egg and makes a great base for applying rub and helping it to stick. I often use this on chicken but felt it would marry better with the Texas style rub recipe.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Apply Rub I used my normal mustard base with the original rub recipe on the other pork tenderloin.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Apply Rub Make sure to get the rub applied well to all sides and the ends.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Set up Smoker Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Set up Smoker If your smoker came with a water pan, use it.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Set up Smoker When your smoker is up to temperature and holding steady, it's time to cook.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Smoke Cook I placed the tenderloins on a Bradley rack to make it easy but you can also just place them directly on the smoker grate.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Smoke Cook Keep the smoke going for at least 30 minutes but it's ok to keep a light smoke going for the entire time as well.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Smoke Cook I highly recommend the use of a remote digital probe meat thermometer.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Smoke Cook Is it vitally important that the pork tenderloin be removed from the smoker at 145°F. This is the safe temperature for pork.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Serve Place a foil pan or a piece of foil over the tenderloins for about 10 minutes to let them rest.
74152826-bbd2-490d-a0aa-7b63a8683233 Serve Once rested, slice the pork into pieces and serve immediately.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Prepare the Sausage Most of the smoked sausage that I purchase locally comes (2) per package. Lay the links parallel with sides touching to speed up the cutting and cut them into ¾ to 1-inch long pieces.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Prepare the Sausage Use a knife to cut an "X" in the top side of each piece of sausage down about 1/2 to 2/3 of the way through. Make sure to NOT cut all the way through.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Make the Cheese Mixture Leave the cream cheese on the cabinet for about an hour prior to use so it can soften and be easier to work with.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Make the Cheese Mixture Place the 8 oz of cream cheese into a medium sized mixing bowl. Add a good handful of grated cheddar (about a cup if you want to measure) and 3-4 TBS of Jeff's rub (purchase recipes here).
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Make the Cheese Mixture Combine all of the ingredients. A fork works well for this. Please note: I halved the recipe to make about 20 of these and had some left over.. the full recipe will make enough for about 40-50 depending on how much you use in each one
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Stuff It If you have an icing tool or bag, that will work well for operations like this. Otherwise, you can just put the cheese mixture into a small ziptop bag and cut off a small corner to make a stuffing tool that will work great.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Stuff It Use one hand or a helper to open up the "X" in the sausage. Put the cut corner of the stuffing tool into the opening and squeeze until it oozes out of the sides and top of the sausage pieces. Be as generous as you like. You can't get too much of this stuff.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Add the Peppers Cut off the stem of the peppers and carefully clean out the seeds and ribs of the peppers if you want to. The peppers will be hotter if you leave some of the seeds in there.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Add the Peppers I recommend using gloves any time you deal with hot peppers in any way.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Add the Peppers Once cleaned, cut the peppers into slices that are about 1/8-inch thick. Thicker is fine if you want more of the pepper flavor to come through.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Add the Peppers Lay a pepper slice on top of each piece of stuffed sausage.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Wrap in Bacon Cut pieces of bacon in half and use ½ slice for each piece of sausage.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Wrap in Bacon Wrap the bacon across the top and bottom of the stuffed sausage pieces.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Wrap in Bacon Try to end up with the ends of the bacon under the sausage to help hold it. Tip: Bacon can easily be stretched to adjust the length.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Wrap in Bacon No toothpick is needed in most cases as the bacon is sticky and will usually hold fine with no further pinning required.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Season Generously Make up a batch of Jeff's rub (purchase recipes here) and put some of it into a cheese shaker or other spice dispenser with large holes. Sprinkle the rub onto the tops of the stuffed and wrapped sausage pieces. Be generous with the rub as it is low on salt and high on flavor.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Season Generously If you haven't already, place the wrapped and stuffed sausage poppers onto a Bradley rack or a cookie sheet to aid in transporting them out to the smoker.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Smoke Time Setup your smoker, grill or other cooking device for 250°F. If your smoker will not get that hot, then 220 or 225 °F will work but please note that it will take longer and the bacon will not end up as firm as it would otherwise.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Smoke Time Use the water pan if you have one and apply smoke for at least 1 hour if you are using a charcoal, gas or electric smoker.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Smoke Time Leave the sausage pieces in the smoker until the bacon starts to get done. At that point you can paint on some good barbecue sauce (purchase recipes here) if you want to add another layer of flavor. I think it definitely adds to the "goodness" but use your own judgement there or do some with and some without to get a fair comparison from your guests.
2031edbb-f108-48be-a489-4005551f8dc8 Serve These will go fast once you take them into the house so, eat a couple before you announce "done" and then rearrange them on the serving platter so no one will notice that a couple are missing
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 What to Buy For this recipe I purchased a whole boneless pork butt but after having sliced it up myself, I highly recommend that you just buy a package or two of pork steaks to make it a lot easier. I do not mind slicing it up, but I am all about convenience.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 What to Buy If you do decide to use a pork butt, I recommend some freezer time for the butt to stiffen it up a little bit. You don't want it frozen but just at that point where it's solid enough to cut good slices.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 What to Buy A meat slice would also work well for this if you have one or have access to one.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Prepare the Meat Remove as much of the fat on the outside as you can, you don't need the fat cap for these. Use a sharp knife and you don't have to spend a lot of time with it. Just remove what you can and move along.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Prepare the Meat Cut the pork butt into ¼ inch slices then into strips that are about 2 inches wide. If you are using pork steaks, you can probably get 2 to 3 strips from each steak.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Marinate Layer the strips of meat into a bowl and sprinkle my rub onto each layer. The rub will draw some of the moisture out of the meat and it will become a thick marinade that will flavor the strips of pork very deeply.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Marinate Once all of the meat is layered into the bowl, sprinkle some extra rub on top and cover the bowl.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Marinate Place the bowl in the fridge overnight to marinate.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Marinate Note, you can also use a zip top bag if that is more convenient. Place all of the meat into the bag and then pour enough rub into the bag to coat the meat really well. ½ cup is probably enough but you will have to make sure that all of the meat is coated well.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Marinate Massage the closed bag to combine the meat and the rub then place in the fridge overnight.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Put it on a Stick Do not rinse the meat when it is finished marinating.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Put it on a Stick Use long wooden skewers that are about 12-inches long if possible
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Put it on a Stick Push the skewer through the meat making sure to keep it inside the meat if possible. If it seems to be hard to push through, try twisting the skewer as you push.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Put it on a Stick As the sticks are loaded, place them into a Bradley rack with room between each one so the smoke and heat can have ample access.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Smoke it Setup your smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F for about 2 hours and apply smoke for at least 1 hour.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Smoke it If your smoker has a water pan, fill it ¾ full with water to create a nice humid environment inside the smoker to reduce drying.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Smoke it Place the skewers directly on oiled smoker racks or you can use the Bradley racks if you have them.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Smoke it Once the meat reaches about 170°F, coat both sides with my barbecue sauce. It is ok to crank up the heat at this point if your smoker has this ability. I used a propane smoker for this session and turned the control knob to high to help caramelize the sauce and to get a little charring on the outside.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Smoke it You could also transfer them to a hot grill for this operation. If using this option, let the meat reach 180°F in the smoker before removing them to the grill and adding sauce and high heat.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Smoke it If you plan to use the grill to finish the meat, you will want to soak the skewers in water for a few hours before loading them with meat. This will help to prevent them from catching fire in the high heat. You should also keep a spray bottle of water close by the grill to extinguish any unexpected flare ups.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Smoke it If they seem to be drying out and/or if you are not able to use a water pan in your smoker, the skewers of meat could be placed into a large roasting pan and covered in foil to finish once they get about 1 hour of good smoke.
eded50ab-13ed-406c-b668-6207e4645289 Serve Let folks start grabbing these as soon as theyjjjj are finished and while they are really hot and delicious. Be sure to provide some sauce on the side for those who like to dip. I found that I did not need sauce after the fact as there was plenty caramelized onto the meat.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Soak Bread Take two slices of loaf bread or the top and bottom half of a bun and tear it into small pieces.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Soak Bread With the bread in a small bowl, pour ½ cup of buttermilk over the bread. The bread will soak up the buttermilk and this will be part of what makes the meatloaf so moist.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Soak Bread Once the milk is soaked in, crack a couple of large eggs onto the bread mixture. Stir gently to combine.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Soak Bread Set aside
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Saute Vegetables Dice bell peppers, onion and celery so that you end up with about ½ cup of each.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Saute Vegetables If you have extra, place them in a zip top bag and place them in the freezer for later.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Saute Vegetables Put 2 TBS of olive oil into a skillet over medium heat.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Saute Vegetables Once the pan is hot enough, pour in the onions, peppers and celery and stir to mix with the oil.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Saute Vegetables Let them cook for about 10 minutes or until the vegetables start to get slightly soft.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Saute Vegetables Once the veggies are finished cooking, remove them from the pan and into a plate or bowl to cool.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Saute Vegetables Add ½ cup of Jeff's barbecue sauce and 3 TBS of Jeff's rub to the sautéed vegetables. Stir to combine.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Mix the Meatloaf Place the 1 pound of ground chuck and 1 pound of ground sausage into a large mixing bowl.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Mix the Meatloaf Add the bread, buttermilk and egg mixture to the top of the meat.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Mix the Meatloaf Add the vegetable, sauce and rub mixture to the top of the meat as well.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Mix the Meatloaf Add 1 teaspoon of salt to the top of the mixture and gently combine the ingredients together.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Mix the Meatloaf Do not overmix. Do just enough to combine and stop. Overworking the meatloaf mixture will make it tough.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Form Into a Loaf Pour or scoop the mixture onto a cookie sheet, food grade butcher paper, etc. and form into a loaf with your hands.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Form Into a Loaf You can also place the mixture into a loaf pan to form it and then dump it out onto the pan, rack or tray that you will use to cook it.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Form Into a Loaf You will notice that this mixture may be a little wetter than what you are used to using but that's ok. It will form and hold together just fine.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Form Into a Loaf I recommend about 2 inches thick in the shape of a rectangle but you can get creative with this if you like.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Form Into a Loaf If using a Bradley rack, I recommend placing a piece of wax paper under the meat so it will be easier to remove once done.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Smoke the Meatloaf Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F using indirect heat with hickory smoke or whatever smoking wood you have available.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Smoke the Meatloaf If your smoker has a water pan, I recommend that you use it.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Smoke the Meatloaf Once your smoker is maintaining the proper temperature, the cooking can commence.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Smoke the Meatloaf Place the meatloaf in the smoker.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Smoke the Meatloaf Let the loaf cook for 3-4 hours or until it reaches about 155°F.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Top with Sauce At about 155°F, brush the top and sides of the meatloaf with plenty of Jeff's barbecue sauce. Give it about 25-30 minutes to caramelize then remove from the smoker.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Top with Sauce Finish temperature for meatloaf is actually 160°F but knowing that it will continue to cook and rise in temperature even after being removed from the smoker, it is ok to remove it a few degrees early.
c25259a2-eb08-4457-b41c-8ec8dcfd187b Rest and Serve Once the meat is brought into the house, tent some foil over the top and let it rest for 15-20 minutes before slicing and serving. This resting period gives the juices in the meat time to redistribute throughout the meat.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Rinse and Pat Dry Remove ribs from package and rinse well under cold water
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Rinse and Pat Dry Pat dry with paper towels and lay on cutting board
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Remove Membrane If the ribs have a membrane (thick plastic-like skin on bone side), it’s a good idea to remove it if you can.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Slice Baby backs: Use a very sharp knife and slice right between the bones.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Slice Spare ribs: For best results, trim these up St. Louis style. This just means you remove the brisket bone that runs along the leading edge and square them up a little by removing the extra pieces of meat on the ends. Then slice them up.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Get the Smoker Going These will do well on any smoker or even a grill as long as you can maintain temperatures between 225-240°F using indirect heat.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Get the Smoker Going Make sure you have enough smoking wood for about 3-4 hours of smoke.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Get the Smoker Going If your smoker has a water pan, I recommend using it.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Get the Smoker Going Once the smoker is set up and holding the proper temperature, you can proceed with cooking the ribs.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Smoke for 2 hours Smoke them for about 2 hours at 225-240°F.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Add Rub and Braise in Foil Toss them into a foil pan. Sprinkle 1/4 cup of my original rub on them for the first layer of flavor.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Add Rub and Braise in Foil Cover the foil pan of rubbed ribs with foil. Make sure it’s tight around the edges to keep the steam inside.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Add Rub and Braise in Foil Leave them this way for 1 to 1.5 hours depending on how tender you want them.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Add Rub and Braise in Foil When this step is finished, simply remove the foil cover from the top of the pan.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Add the Main Layer of Rub and Sauce Apply about 1 cup of my barbecue sauce all over the ribs.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Add the Main Layer of Rub and Sauce Toss the ribs around in the pan to make sure they are well coated with the sauce.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Add the Main Layer of Rub and Sauce Now sprinkle about 1/2 cup of rub all over the tops of the ribs then shake the pan lightly to coat.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Finish Smoke Cooking With the top left uncovered, continue to cook the ribs for an additional 1.5 to 2 hours or until they are at the consistency that you want.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Step 10: Serve Up When they are done cooking, you can cover them with foil, and hold them on low heat for an hour or serve them right away.
17ad34ec-7afb-474b-90d1-967b33695027 Step 10: Serve Up Dump into a serving container or let folks grab them right out of the pan.. your choice.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Brine (optional) To brine the chicken breasts make a solution of: 1 quart of cold water, ¼ cup of coarse kosher salt and ¼ cup of brown sugar.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Brine (optional) Stir well until everything is dissolved.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Brine (optional) Place the chicken breasts into a zip top bag or other plastic or glass container and pour the brine over the chicken to cover. Place in the fridge for about 2 hours to brine.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Brine (optional) Once the brining is complete, remove the chicken from the brine and rinse well under cold water. Pat dry and set aside.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Make the Cream Cheese/Jalapeño Mixture Leave the cream cheese out on the table for about an hour to soften.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Make the Cream Cheese/Jalapeño Mixture Place a block of cream cheese or about 8 oz into a small to medium sized mixing bowl.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Make the Cream Cheese/Jalapeño Mixture Deseed, clean and dice 2-3 jalapeño peppers depending on how well you like jalapeño and how spicy the jalapeños are.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Make the Cream Cheese/Jalapeño Mixture Put the diced peppers into the bowl with the cream cheese and stir to combine.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Season and Stuff the Chicken Breasts Brush a little olive oil onto the chicken breasts then season the top side with Jeff's original rub.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Season and Stuff the Chicken Breasts Add a heaping tablespoon of the cream cheese/jalapeno mixture on top of the rub.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Season and Stuff the Chicken Breasts Fold the chicken over on top of itself. To make it easier to fold, you can make a shallow cut at about the halfway point of the chicken breast widthwise.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Season and Stuff the Chicken Breasts Once the chicken is folded coat the entire outside of the chicken breast with a little olive oil and season generously with Jeff's original rub.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Wrap with Bacon Lay 2 thin slices of bacon across the stuffed chicken breast.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Wrap with Bacon Lift the chicken up and hold it with one hand while you wrap the bacon "artistically" around the chicken.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Smoke Cook the Chicken Place the stuffed chicken on a Bradley rack, cookie sheet or something similar to make it easy to carry them out to the smoker.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Smoke Cook the Chicken Set up your smoker for cooking with indirect heat at around 240°F if possible.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Smoke Cook the Chicken If your smoker has a water pan, it's a good idea to use it.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Smoke Cook the Chicken I used pecan but you can use any smoking wood that you desire and have available.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Smoke Cook the Chicken Once the smoker is ready, place the stuffed chicken directly on the smoker grate and insert a probe from a digital probe meat thermometer (if you have one) so you will know the exact time it is finished.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Smoke Cook the Chicken You can also use a super fast meat thermometer such as the Thermapen but this requires you to open the door several times and you stand the chance of overcooking the chicken if it happens to get done sooner than you expect.
08cbe277-01f6-41c6-b813-bce928e3f0b1 Serve When the chicken is done cooking, remove it from the smoker and let it rest for a couple of minutes before serving.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Rinse and Dry Give the ribs a good rinse to remove bone fragments and anything else that shouldn’t be there. Pat them dry with a paper towel and lay on the cutting board.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Remove Fat/Clean ’em up I prefer to remove the membrane but it is certainly not worth a lot of time, effort and frustration. If you have trouble with it, you can skip this step and still have some of the best smoked ribs in town.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Remove Fat/Clean ’em up I have smoked ribs with the membrane and without the membrane and as far as tenderness, moisture and flavor, there’s not a big difference in my opinion either way.
