4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Remove Fat/Clean ’em up Most baby backs will not have a lot of fat but if they do, spend a few minutes removing any of it that is easy to get to with a sharp knife. I had to remove a little bit on these but I did not obsess about it.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Remove Fat/Clean ’em up Any extra flaps of meat sticking out? Slice it off and set it aside.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Rub down After you have spend minimal time doing a little prep work to the ribs, get that batch of my rib rub that you mixed up earlier and sprinkle a good coating on the top of the ribs. Just enough so that you can no longer see the meat under the rub.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Rub down Go take a break for about 10 minutes and wait for the few little granules of salt in my rub to start pulling the juice to the surface.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Rub down After a few minutes, the top surface of the ribs will start to look wet. This is the moisture in the ribs being pulled to the surface where it will mix with the rub and create a paste.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Rub down After about 10-15 minutes of waiting, I like to give it another good sprinkle of the rub for good measure and because my rub recipe is high on flavor and LOW on salt, this is not a problem ?
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Rub down After this second sprinkle, go get the smoker ready.. those ribs are ready for their destiny!
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Smoke and Heat Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Smoke and Heat I used pecan smoke for these but use whatever smoking wood that you like and have available.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Smoke and Heat Once your smoker is preheated and you have selected the wood you will use and it is producing a little smoke, you are ready to place the pork ribs in the smoker.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Smoke and Heat Place the rack(s) of ribs directly on the smoker grate boney side down, meaty side up and quickly close the door or lid to your smoker. Leave them this way for about 2 hours.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Smoke and Heat After 2 hours, either wrap them in foil or place them into a very large foil pan covered with foil over the top. Both options work equally well but the foil pan is easier and a little more leak proof. Leave them in this configuration for 2 hours in the smoker at 225-240°F.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Smoke and Heat Please note: This foil stage is where the ribs get super tender. If you do not like super tender ribs then you will need to adjust the amount of time the ribs are in the foil. Some folks only leave them in the foil for 1 hour to create ribs that are less tender.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Smoke and Heat It is now time to unwrap the ribs from the foil or remove them from the foil pan and place them back on the smoker grate at 225-240°F for about 1 hour. This is also a great time to start painting some sauce on them if you are going for sticky ribs. If you are using my rub, you won’t need sauce but you may still want some and that is perfectly fine.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Smoke and Heat This 3-step method of cooking pork ribs is known as the 2-2-1 method for smoked baby backs. (for spare ribs it’s 3-2-1 with an extra hour at the beginning)
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Smoke and Heat If you need some metrics for making sure that the ribs are actually ready to eat: Pork is safe at 145°F internally but pork ribs are perfectly tender at 195°F. Feel free to check that with a Thermapen or other digital meat thermometer in that meaty area right between the bones, The bones should be showing about ½ inch or more due to the meat pulling back, and the rack of ribs should bend nearly in half when held up at one end with a pair of tongs.
4cfbf898-e992-4015-af4b-c91b1360d82b Slice and Eat Here’s the easy part.. remove the ribs from the smoker, turn the rack upside down on the cutting board and slice between the bones with a sharp knife.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Season Steak(s) Place the ribeye steaks on a cutting board.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Season Steak(s) Note: This one was just over 2 lbs and was about 3 inches thick. Any size and/or thickness will work but thicker is better in my opinion.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Season Steak(s) Drizzle olive oil onto them.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Season Steak(s) Use a basting brush to coat the entire piece of meat with the oil.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Season Steak(s) Sprinkle a generous amount of Jeff’s Texas style rub recipe onto the top, sides and bottom of the steaks.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Season Steak(s) Note: the Original rub recipe (Jeff’s Naked Rib Rub) is also very good on steak and I have used it many times with excellent results.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Season Steak(s) Let the steaks sit on the counter for a few minutes while you get the smoker ready. You will notice that within a few minutes, the rub begins to draw some of the moisture out of the meat. The moisture then mixes with the rub ingredients and it creates a paste.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Season Steak(s) Place the steaks on a Bradley rack or a cookie sheet to make it easy to transport them to and from the smoker.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Smoke ’em up I used the Landmann propane smoker for this cook but any smoker will work great as long as it can maintain about 220°F.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Smoke ’em up Set it up for indirect cooking and use the water pan if your smoker was designed with one.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Smoke ’em up I recommend cherry wood for smoke but any smoking wood will work great for these.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Smoke ’em up Once the smoker is ready, place the steak right on the smoker grate or if you used the Bradley rack, you can just place the rack right on the smoker grate.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Smoke ’em up Keep the heat and smoke going for about any hour or until the internal temperature of the steak reads about 110-115°F.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Finish on the Grill (optional but very good) Once the steaks reach an internal temperature of 110-115°F, place them on an already preheated gas or charcoal grill. The grill needs to be very hot.. the hotter the better in my opinion.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Finish on the Grill (optional but very good) Keep a close eye on the steaks and do not leave them alone at all. Place them on the hot grill for about 2 minutes then rotate them 90° to get nice looking grill marks.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Finish on the Grill (optional but very good) In 2 more minutes or so, flip them over and do the same thing on that side.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Finish on the Grill (optional but very good) The amount of time it takes to get a good char is completely dependent on the temperature of the grill so it may take more or less than 2 minutes.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Finish on the Grill (optional but very good) As an alternative, you can bring them into the house and place them under the broiler of the oven for this charring step. You will not get the coveted grill marks but you will get a great char and color and because the heat is working on the top of the steak instead of the bottom, you’ll be able to easily see when it’s had enough and is ready to be flipped over.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Finish on the Grill (optional but very good) Leave the smoker going and if the charring is complete but the steaks are not to your desired doneness, you can easily place them right back in the smoker until the desired temperature is acquired.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Rest and Serve When the ribeye steaks have reached your desired level of doneness (I recommend medium rare or 135°F for best flavor, tenderness and juiciness), lay them on the cutting board and cover loosely with a foil pan or piece of foil to allow them to rest for 10 minutes. During the resting period, the juices in the steak will settle down and redistribute throughout the meat. The meat will also raise a few degrees in temperature.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Rest and Serve Cut or carve the steak(s) as desired and serve immediately.
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Rest and Serve You can obviously cook them to a higher internal temperature if that’s the way you like to eat steak ?
3af64e1d-8414-43e1-95e2-f1345fd37ef3 Rest and Serve Enjoy the perfectly cooked smoked bone-in ribeye steaks!
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Brine Chicken (optional) Add 1 cup of coarse kosher salt to 1 gallon of water and stir until the salt is dissolved and the water returns to clear. Add 1 cup of brown sugar and stir to mix it into the water.
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Brine Chicken (optional) Place the chicken into a food safe plastic or glass bowl and pour the brine over the chicken to cover. You can also use a large zip top bag.
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Brine Chicken (optional) Close or cover the container and place it in the fridge for about 4 hours.
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Brine Chicken (optional) After the brining has finished, rinse the outside of the chicken with cold water to remove any residual salt.
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Maple Syrup and Rub Pour maple syrup onto the chicken and use a brush to coat the chicken all over.
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Maple Syrup and Rub Sprinkle Jeff’s original rub all over the top, sides and bottom of the chicken making sure to get the rub down in all of the hard to reach spots. It is also a good idea to get some of the maple syrup and rub down under the skin wherever you can.
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Smoke the Chicken Set up your smoker for cooking at 250°F if possible. Some smokers will not cook this hot so a lower temperature will work but it will require a longer cook time for the chicken to get done.
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Smoke the Chicken Once the smoker is ready, place the chicken on the grate breast side down.
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Smoke the Chicken In gas, electric, charcoal and non-conventional cookers, apply smoke (I recommend pecan for this recipe) for the entire time the chicken is cooking. The skin does a great job of protecting the meat from the smoke and just enough gets through to make it deliciously smoky.
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Smoke the Chicken My 4 lb chicken took about 2 hours and 10 minutes to reach 165°F. Times will vary from cooker to cooker so be sure to let the internal temperature of the chicken decide when it’s done.
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Smoke the Chicken Use a digital probe meat thermometer in the thickest part of the thigh or breast to monitor the meat temperature while it cooks. You can also check the temperature with a super fast Thermapan when you baste. With the Thermapen, you can get an accurate reading in around 2-3 seconds.
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Smoke the Chicken Make the Maple Barbecue Mop Sauce by mixing 4 oz of maple syrup with 2 heaping tablespoons of Jeff's original rub.
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Smoke the Chicken After the first hour, begin to apply the maple barbecue mop sauce every 20 minutes.
ad0eb031-f1a4-41d5-8446-119c8156c1f2 Finished Once the chicken reaches 165°F it is done cooking and should be removed from the smoker. Allow it to rest for 10 minutes or so before carving to allow the juices to cool down a little and redistribute throughout the meat.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Cook bacon and shred cheese Cook bacon until it is crispy. You will need 2 slices per pork chop.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Cook bacon and shred cheese Make extra so you’ll have some to nibble on.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Cook bacon and shred cheese Let it cool then crumble into small to medium sized pieces.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Cook bacon and shred cheese Buy already shredded cheese or you can buy a block of cheese and shred it yourself.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Cook bacon and shred cheese I shredded about a cup of cheese so I had leftovers. You’ll only need about 2 TBS per pork chop.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Cook bacon and shred cheese Mix 2 TBS of shredded cheese and 2 slices of crumbled bacon for each pork chop you plan to smoke.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Stuff pork chops I purchased pork chops that were already butterflied and ready to go.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Stuff pork chops First, we’ll season the inside just a little with my original rub.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Stuff pork chops Add a little spicy brown mustard to help the rub to stick
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Stuff pork chops Sprinkle my rub on the top
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Stuff pork chops Place some of the cheese/bacon mixture to the top of the pork chop (one of the sides only)
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Stuff pork chops Fold the butterflied pork chop over on top of itself
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Season outside of chops and tie up Apply some spicy brown mustard to the outside of the stuffed pork chops
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Season outside of chops and tie up Rub the mustard all over the top and bottom of the pork chop then sprinkle Jeff’s original rub on both sides generously.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Season outside of chops and tie up Cut (3) 24 inch pieces of butchers twine for each pork chop to tie it up.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Season outside of chops and tie up Lay the pieces of twine parallel and at about 2 inch intervals.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Season outside of chops and tie up Lay the pork chop on top of the twine.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Season outside of chops and tie up Loop each piece of twine over the stuffed pork chop, pull it tight and tie a knot that will hold.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Season outside of chops and tie up Trim the extra string with scissors or a sharp knife.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Season outside of chops and tie up Place the tied up, stuffed pork chops on a bradley rack or cookie sheet and they are ready for the smoker.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Smoke time Set up your smoker for cooking indirectly at about 225-240°F using cherry or your favorite smoking wood.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Smoke time Once the smoker is ready, place the stuffed pork chops directly on the grate or if you use Bradley racks, you can just place the rack onto the smoker grate.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Smoke time Place a digital probe meat thermometer into one of the pork chops so you’ll know when it is perfectly done.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Smoke time You can expect the pork chops to take from 1.5 to 2 hours depending on actual thickness, how often you open the lid, weather conditions, and how cold the meat was when it went into the smoker.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Smoke time If you are using a smoker that is not fueled by wood, you should apply smoke for at least an hour. I usually keep a light smoke going for the entire time to replicate the real wood smoker experience.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Smoke time Ultimately, the pork chops are done and ready to eat when they reach 145°F.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Finished Serve the pork chops as they come off the smoker if possible so your eaters will get to experience the dish at it’s very best and while the cheese is still very melty.
96d5a716-7ec6-4038-b3c5-8857b2609ec4 Finished Don’t forget to cut and remove the butchers twine.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c Remove the fat Beef short ribs tend to have a lot of fat. Remove the fat and silver skin. A very sharp knife makes this job a lot faster and easier.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c Apply the Rub Place the beef short ribs in a plastic zip top bag and squirt about ¼ cup of spicy brown mustard down in the bag with about ¼ cup of Jeff’s Texas style rub recipe
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c Apply the Rub Massage and roll the bag to coat all of the ribs with mustard and rub paste.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c Let them Marinate (optional) Once the mustard and rub are applied, let them sit in the fridge overnight to really soak up the flavor of the rub. You can also use the ribs right away or as soon as you want to. Any time at all with the mustard and rub will do them good.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c Let them Marinate (optional) Do NOT rinse the ribs once they are finished marinating.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c Let them Marinate (optional) They are now ready to cook. I recommend placing them down in a disposable foil pan and leaving them there during the entire cooking process.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c Smoke the Ribs Setup your smoker for indirect heat at about 225-240°F
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c Smoke the Ribs Leave the ribs in the pan for best results.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c Smoke the Ribs Apply cherry smoke for about 2 hours.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c Foil braise with wine After applying smoke for about 2 hours, pour about 1 cup of red wine (I used Rosa Regale but any similar red sweet wine will work great)
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c Foil braise with wine Cover the pan tightly with foil and let it cook for 3 hours at 225-240°F. During this time, the wine and beef juices will create steam and the beef will get a good braising inside the covered pan serving to super tenderize the beef.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c Foil braise with wine Note: Don’t want to use wine for some reason? You can use sparkling red grape juice or even regular red grape juice to get a similar effect and flavor without the alcohol content.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c High heat finish After the braising process, uncover the ribs and turn up the heat to 300 °F. If your smoker won’t heat to that high, use the grill or even the oven to finish them off.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c High heat finish Mix 1 part Jeff’s sauce with 2 parts of the red wine (for example: 1/3 cup Jeff’s sauce + 2/3 cup red wine) and brush the ribs with this mixture.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c High heat finish Brush the ribs with this mixture 2-3 times during the next hour.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c High heat finish Use a Thermapen or other accurate digital meat thermometer to test the temperature of the ribs. When they reach 190-200°F and are fork tender, they are done. “Tender” is the best measurement of when these beef short ribs are done. Another visual indicator of doneness is the meat pulling back from the bone.
fe29ec84-3d69-4bc5-ad74-f60947e5654c Serve Once the beef short ribs are finished cooking, serve immediately.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Make the Brine Add 1 cup of coarse kosher salt to 1/2 gallon of cold water..
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Make the Brine Stir in the salt until it dissolves and the water becomes clear.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Make the Brine Add ¼ cup of Jeff's rub and 4 bottles of beer (12 oz)
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Make the Brine Stir to combine. It may get a little foamy..
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Make the Brine The brine is ready to use
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Brine the Chicken Rinse chicken pieces under cold water
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Brine the Chicken Place chicken into a plastic or glass container
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Brine the Chicken Pour the brine over the chicken to cover.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Brine the Chicken Add some ice on top to make sure it is nice and cold and place the bowl in the fridge for about 4 hours.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Brine the Chicken When the brining is finished, rinse the chicken really good to remove any extra salt residue from the surface.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Apply the Rub Place the chicken pieces into a large ziptop bag and pour ¼ cup of Jeff's rub into the bag.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Apply the Rub Zip the bag closed and roll or massage the bag to coat all of the chicken with the rub.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Apply the Rub Once the chicken is well coated, place the chicken pieces onto a Bradley rack or pan. It is now ready to cook in the smoker.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Smoke the Chicken Set up your smoker for cooking at 275°F if possible. If your smoker will not heat to that temperature, then normal smoking temperatures (225-240°F) will work fine.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Smoke the Chicken Use indirect heat (most smokers are designed for this by default).
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Smoke the Chicken Once the smoker is ready, place the chicken on the smoker grate and let it smoke cook until it reaches 165°F in the the thickest part of each piece. This should take about 1 hour but watch the temperature carefully as the times will vary from smoker to smoker and depending on how often you open the lid, how cold the chicken entered the smoker and even weather.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Smoke the Chicken About 15 minutes before the chicken is finished, brush on the beer barbecue glaze (recipe below)
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Beer Barbecue Glaze 2 TBS Jeff's barbecue sauce
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Beer Barbecue Glaze 1/4 cup beer
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Beer Barbecue Glaze Stir well to combine. You can make it more thick or thin by changing the ratio of sauce to beer.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Serve It Up Check each piece using a quick reading thermometer such as a Thermapen to make sure a safe temperature of 165°F has been obtained.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Serve It Up Serve with extra beer barbecue sauce for dipping if you like.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Notes/Comments: This chicken was extremely juicy, even the white breast meat and you could distinctively taste the beer flavor all the way through the meat.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Notes/Comments: Use any kind of beer you like.. the cheap stuff will work perfectly. I usually use Shiner Bock when I use beer in recipes and it works great.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Notes/Comments: Yes, you can use something besides beer if you like and it will still be super juicy and flavorful. Some things that work well are:
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Notes/Comments: Cherry Dr Pepper, Dr Pepper, Root beer, fruit nectar, apple cider, sparkling grape juice, buttermilk, etc.
73bc0728-b865-426d-91df-0b290fc745ef Notes/Comments: If you are not able to smoke at the higher temperature I recommended, it will take longer for the chicken to get done. At normal smoking temperatures of 225-240°F, the chicken pieces will take around 2 hours to reach 165°F.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Season Ground Meat Place ground chuck (80/20 or 85/15) into mixing bowl.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Season Ground Meat Add ¼ cup of Jeff’s Texas style rub recipe (purchase recipes here).
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Season Ground Meat Combine but don’t overwork the meat.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Form Meat into Balls Use a scale if you have one or just estimate to divide meat into 8 oz (½ lb) balls.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Form Meat into Balls Form the balls with your hands but it doesn’t have to be perfect.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Make the Pocket Use a cleaned, unopened 12 oz beverage (beer, soda, etc.)
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Make the Pocket Press the can into the center of the ball of meat to form the pocket.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Make the Pocket The meat will break a little around the edges. Use your hands to form the meat around the can.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Wrap in Bacon and Remove Can Wrap a thin slice of bacon around the meat.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Wrap in Bacon and Remove Can Hold the meat with one hand to maintain it’s shape while you remove the can gently.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Stuff with Pulled Pork and Cheese Add a teaspoon of Jeff’s Original rub recipe into the pocket for great flavor.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Stuff with Pulled Pork and Cheese Stuff with pulled pork..
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Stuff with Pulled Pork and Cheese Add more of my original rub to the top of the pulled pork..
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Stuff with Pulled Pork and Cheese Sprinkle grated cheese on top.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Stuff with Pulled Pork and Cheese I used sharp cheddar but you can use a different kind if you prefer.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Stuff with Pulled Pork and Cheese The burgers are now stuffed and ready to smoke!
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Smoke Setup your smoker for cooking with indirect heat at 225-240°F
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Smoke If your smoker has a water pan, use it.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Smoke I like to use mesquite for these and especially to get a good smoked flavor in a relatively short period of time. Use your own favorite smoking wood if desired.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Smoke Place the burgers on the grate and allow them to smoke cook for about 1.5 hours or until the burger reaches 160°F.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Smoke About 25-30 minutes before they are finished, brush with Jeff’s sauce (purchase recipes here) if desired.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Finished When the burgers are finished cooking, remove them from the smoker grate and serve immediately.
b24dbf50-9075-440c-9a8a-75f0d9324016 Finished They can be eaten as an entree or placed between buns with condiments, tomato, onions, lettuce, etc for one of the best hamburgers you’ve ever eaten.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Unwrap and Rinse Remove the pork butt from the packaging and rinse it under cold water.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Unwrap and Rinse Pat dry with a paper towel.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Unwrap and Rinse I recommend placing it in a pan during the seasoning process to make cleanup really easy.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Brush Dressing onto Meat Normally I use yellow mustard to help the rub to stick since it works so well however, you can use almost anything and to prove that, I am using zesty Italian dressing on this pork butt and it works like a charm.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Brush Dressing onto Meat Pour the dressing over the top of the meat.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Brush Dressing onto Meat Use a basting brush to make sure the meat is coated well with the dressing.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Apply Rub Sprinkle my Jeff’s naked rib rub onto all sides of the meat making sure you have good coverage.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Apply Rub Be generous to create a nice crispy bark on the outside during the cooking process.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Apply Rub It is now ready for the smoker.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Smoke Set up your smoker for indirect heat maintaining about 225-240°F for about 14-16 hours.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Smoke When you are ready, place the pork butt directly on the grate.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Smoke I like to place a pan on a lower rack if I can to catch the juices that drip down. If your smoker is configured to allow for this, it’s a great idea.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Smoke I used apple wood to impart a really wonderful flavor into the pork but you can use almost any smoking wood that you have available.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Smoke I recommend keeping the smoke flowing for at least 6 to 8 hours if you are using charcoal, electric or gas smokers.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Smoke If your smoker has a water pan, use it.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Smoke Let the pork butt smoke out in the open grate for the entire time or you can place it in a pan once it reaches about 160°F covered with foil to help it get done a little faster.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Smoke I opted to not cover this one but left it directly on the grate with a pan under it for the entire time.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Smoke When it reaches 205°F, it should be fall apart tender and can be removed from the smoker.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Smoke Those not familiar with pork butts always wonder why it’s so dark. The rub gets darker and darker as it cooks and this is what you usually want when you are making pulled pork.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Smoke If you wrap the meat at 160°F it will not end up quite as dark however it will also be soft on the outside rather than crispy.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Smoke Let it sit with foil tented over it for about an hour to cool before attempting to pull/shred the meat.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Pull and Remove Fat When you are ready, slide the bone out of the meat.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Pull and Remove Fat Separate the meat into pieces removing any pieces of fat as you go.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Pull and Remove Fat I generally use my hands only but some folks like to use large forks or special tools for this process such as bear paws.
3f845836-349a-4f56-8bda-9fdf6e9e89dd Serve You can serve the pulled pork piled high on a bun as a traditional pulled pork sandwich or use your imagination and let it run wild.
0ecfd527-704d-4c7c-b80e-3f8c11815867 Insert Handles (long wood skewer) While holding the sausage, hot link, hotdog, etc., run the skewer lengthwise through the center stopping just before it comes out the other end.
0ecfd527-704d-4c7c-b80e-3f8c11815867 Roll in Rub Put some mustard and rub into (2) separate plates
0ecfd527-704d-4c7c-b80e-3f8c11815867 Roll in Rub Roll the hot links in mustard
0ecfd527-704d-4c7c-b80e-3f8c11815867 Roll in Rub Now roll the hot links in the rub making sure to coat well.
0ecfd527-704d-4c7c-b80e-3f8c11815867 Wrap with Bacon Lay a strip of bacon onto the work space then place the rub coated hot link perpendicular onto the bacon about 2 inches from one of the ends.
0ecfd527-704d-4c7c-b80e-3f8c11815867 Wrap with Bacon Flip the end of the bacon over the top of the hot link to get it started..
0ecfd527-704d-4c7c-b80e-3f8c11815867 Wrap with Bacon Roll the hot link to wrap the bacon around itself. Allow the bacon to overlap a bit with each round and keep it tight while it wraps.
0ecfd527-704d-4c7c-b80e-3f8c11815867 Wrap with Bacon Perform the same task on all of the hot links, sausages, brats, or hotdogs.
0ecfd527-704d-4c7c-b80e-3f8c11815867 Smoke for 2-3 hours Setup your smoker for cooking with indirect heat at about 240°F for 2-3 hours. I used cherry wood for smoke which is really great on these but you can use your favorite wood or whatever smoking wood you have available.
0ecfd527-704d-4c7c-b80e-3f8c11815867 Smoke for 2-3 hours Most things will be perfectly smoked in about 2 hours but we want the bacon to crisp up as well. Leaving it in the smoker for an extra hour will help or you can place them on a hot grill for a few minutes after a 2-hour smoking process.
0ecfd527-704d-4c7c-b80e-3f8c11815867 Smoke for 2-3 hours About 30 minutes before they are finished, paint them generously with my barbecue sauce.
0ecfd527-704d-4c7c-b80e-3f8c11815867 Smoke for 2-3 hours When the bacon is firm to crisp, remove the smoked bacon wrapped hot links from the smoker and serve immediately.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Rinse and Pat Dry Remove the country style ribs from the package and rinse them under cold water.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Rinse and Pat Dry Pat them dry with a paper towel and lay them on the cutting board or in a large pan to contain the mess you’ll make by seasoning them ?
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Mustard and Rub It’s pork.. very good pork, I might add and as most of you know, that calls for a nice sticky base of yellow mustard to help the rub to stick to the meat.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Mustard and Rub Go ahead and be generous.. it won’t taste like mustard and it won’t be yellow when it’s all said and done.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Mustard and Rub Rub it all over with you hands or if you’re squeamish, I suppose you could use a basting brush.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Mustard and Rub As long as the mustard is completely covering the meat, doesn’t matter how it gets there (within reason of course).
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Mustard and Rub Sprinkle my Jeff's original rub (purchase recipes here) onto the meat and make sure you have full coverage on all sides.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Mustard and Rub I like to rub it in a little so it turns into a paste with the mustard.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Onto the Bradley Rack (optional) If you have Bradley racks like I do, lay them on the rack with just a slight bit of space between each one to allow the smoke to get in there a little bit. Cooling racks also work well.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Onto the Bradley Rack (optional) I usually leave as much room as possible but I had other things to cook and so I had to give them a little less breathing room than usual.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Get the Smoker Ready Light up your smoker whether that means actually lighting the fire or just plugging it in and dialing in some settings. Do what it takes to get your smoker going at about 225°F.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Get the Smoker Ready Make sure the heat is indirect and use the water pan if your smoker has one.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Get the Smoker Ready I recommend a mix of mesquite and cherry wood for smoke if you can find it. If not, just use one of your other favorites that you have available.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Smoke ’em Up Once the smoker is ready, place the pork country style ribs directly on the grate or use the Bradley rack (described above) directly on the smoker grate.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Smoke ’em Up Keep the heat at about 225°F if possible.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Smoke ’em Up Keep the smoke going for at least 2 hours but longer is fine and even recommended as long as the smoke is nice and thin.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Smoke ’em Up If you have a digital meat thermometer such as the Maverick ET-733 or the Maverick ET-735 (new bluetooth model), place the probe so that the end is about in the center of one of the ribs.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Smoke ’em Up You can also use the super fast Thermapen to get a quick check on the temperature when you are adding wood or some other task that requires you to have the door open.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Smoke ’em Up You can expect these ribs to take somewhere between 3-4 hours if you maintain 225-240°F but other factors do play a part such as:
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Smoke ’em Up Temperature of the meat when it goes into the smoker
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Smoke ’em Up How often you open the smoker door
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Smoke ’em Up How well you or the smoker maintains the set temperature
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Smoke ’em Up Wind, rain, ambient temperature, etc.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Smoke ’em Up When the meat gets about 30 minutes away from being done, you can sauce them up if you want. I like sauce on these but they are also very good with just the dry rub.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Smoke ’em Up Another option is to put them into a foil pan, covered with foil once they reach about 150-160°F to help them get done faster and to help them end up more tender.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Smoke ’em Up They are done and tender at 180-185°F.
33792e4b-4804-4833-9c5e-fb4af9135788 Rest and Serve You do not have to let these rest for a few minutes but in my opinion, about 10 minutes of rest time before serving does them good.
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Make the Brine Add 1 cup of salt to 1 gallon of cold water
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Make the Brine Stir until the salt is dissolved
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Make the Brine Add 1 cup of brown sugar and stir until sugar is dissolved.
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Brine the Birds Rinse cornish hens under cold water
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Brine the Birds Place birds in food safe container such as a bowl or zip top bag
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Brine the Birds Pour brine over birds to cover
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Brine the Birds Place brining container with cornish hens into fridge for 1.5 hours
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Brine the Birds When brining time is elapsed, rinse birds under cold water
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Brine the Birds Pat dry with paper towel
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Season the Hens Apply mayonnaise liberally to cornish hens
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Season the Hens Sprinkle rub on top, bottom and sides of chickens
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Smoke 'Em Set up smoker for cooking at 230 to 260°F. If you can maintain the higher temperature, the hens will only take about 1.5 hours. At the lower end, they will take about 2 hours.
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Smoke 'Em Once smoker is ready, place birds on smoker grate breast side down
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Smoke 'Em Continue cooking until they reach 165°F as read by a digital meat thermometer.
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f Serve Remove the chickens from the grate when they are done and place one cornish hen on each person's plate with sides.
30b43e1e-7ed4-4616-ad5e-c4ce6440198f
d32a0e26-75da-465d-bf62-8d154eb6d000 Remove the Fat Cap (optional) Using a sharp knife, remove the fat cap from the roast.
d32a0e26-75da-465d-bf62-8d154eb6d000 Season the Meat Rub olive or vegetable oil all over the top, bottom and sides of the tri-tip roast.
d32a0e26-75da-465d-bf62-8d154eb6d000 Season the Meat Apply Jeff's Texas style rub generously all over the roast.
d32a0e26-75da-465d-bf62-8d154eb6d000 Smoke the Tri-tip Place the ti-tip directly on the grate of the smoker
d32a0e26-75da-465d-bf62-8d154eb6d000 Smoke the Tri-tip Using indirect heat, smoke cook the roast for about 2 hours or until it reaches medium rare (140°F)
d32a0e26-75da-465d-bf62-8d154eb6d000 Smoke the Tri-tip Remove from smoker and allow trip tip to rest under foil for about 20 minutes once it has finished cooking.
d32a0e26-75da-465d-bf62-8d154eb6d000 Slice and Serve Slice the smoked tri-tip roast thin for sandwiches or into ¼ inch slices and then strips for placing atop a salad.
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Rinse Remove the ribs from the package
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Rinse Rinse under cold water
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Rinse Allow to drain on paper towel
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Trim St. Louis Style Remove skirt, brisket bone, and end piece to square them up and create the St. Louis style spare ribs.
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Mustard and Rub Apply mustard to bone side of ribs
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Mustard and Rub Pour on about ¼ cup of rib rub and spread to cover over meat.
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Mustard and Rub Repeat mustard and rub on meaty side of ribs.
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Smoke the Ribs Setup smoker for cooking at 230 °F using indirect heat with hickory or other favorite smoking wood.
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Smoke the Ribs Place ribs directly on smoker grate bone side down.
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Smoke the Ribs Smoke for 3 hours.
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Smoke the Ribs After 3 hours, wrap in foil and place back into smoker for 2 hours.
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Smoke the Ribs After 2 hours, unwrap and place back into smoker for a final hour.
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Smoke the Ribs Brush on sauce if desired during last hour of cooking.
1830daf7-b894-4197-8751-651ea308fa22 Slice and Serve Slice the ribs between the bones and serve with warm sauce on the side.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Remove all Visible Fat Lay the thighs out on the cutting board and remove any visible fat with a sharp knife or kitchen scissors.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Cut Chicken into Pieces I tried to cut the chicken into pieces that are bite size but that is a very subjective term. Whatever you visualize as bite size, cut them that size. I got about 6-8 bites from each thigh.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Add the Rub and Marinate Put the chicken pieces into a zip top bag and pour about ¼ to ½ cup of olive or vegetable oil over the top of them.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Add the Rub and Marinate Massage the bag to make sure all of the chicken is coated with the oil as this helps the rub to stick to the meat.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Add the Rub and Marinate Add ½ cup of Jeff’s rub to the bag and, once again, massage the bag really well to coat all of the chicken.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Add the Rub and Marinate Place the bag of rubbed chicken in the fridge for at least an hour but overnight would not hurt anything.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Wrap and Stick When the chicken pieces are finished marinating in the rub, pull them out of the fridge. They will smell really good but avoid eating them raw and definitely do not lick your fingers
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Wrap and Stick I don’t like to be stingy with the bacon so I cut mine in half. You may be able to cut it into thirds if you wish as long as it will fit around your bite size pieces of chicken.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Wrap and Stick Lay a piece of the chicken on a piece of the bacon and roll ‘er up!
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Wrap and Stick Push a skewer through the bacon wrapped chicken piece..
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Wrap and Stick Do that about 5 more times on the same skewer.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Wrap and Stick Make as many skewers as you can with the chicken that you cut up.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Smoke the Chicken Skewers Set up your smoker for cooking at about 250°F if possible. Cooking these a little hotter will help the bacon to crisp up and chicken can definitely handle the higher heat just fine.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Smoke the Chicken Skewers I used pecan just because it’s my favorite and it goes really well with a lot of things.. poultry is one of them.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Smoke the Chicken Skewers As usual, to make it really simple, I loaded the finished skewers onto bradley racks. These racks are about 11 x 15 and if they will fit on your smoker grate, they are very, very handy to have.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Smoke the Chicken Skewers Set the bradley rack on the smoker grate or you can place the chicken skewers directly on the smoker grate.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Smoke the Chicken Skewers Smoke cook at 250°F for about 1.5 hours, sauce them real good then let them go another 30 minutes before taking them out of the smoker.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Smoke the Chicken Skewers Use an instant read thermometer such as the Thermapen (reads in around 2-3 seconds) to check each piece and make sure it has safely reached 165°F.
f1f696d0-595c-4cec-accd-109abf389244 Eat ‘em Up Pull them off the sticks to serve as appetizers or serve an entire skewer to each person as an entree with home fries or even some baked beans.
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Score the Ham (optional but highly recommended) Lay the ham on a cutting board.
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Score the Ham (optional but highly recommended) Using a sharp knife, score the meat about ½ inch deep along the horizontal and vertical axis of the ham. Perfection is not required here.. just a way for the rub and smoke to get a little more access.
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Score the Ham (optional but highly recommended) Note: Spiral cut hams will not need to be scored.
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Add the Seasoning Apply some spicy brown mustard to the ham to help the rub to stick.
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Add the Seasoning Generously pour on some of Jeff’s original rub and massage it in. My rub with the spicy brown mustard creates this really nice crust that is, in my opinion, the best part of the ham. Don’t be skimpy with the rub;-)
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Smoke It In times past I have just said to smoke the ham for 3 hours and that works to get it up to a good eating temperature but I feel that the ham is actually better if you take it on up to about 140-145°F.
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Smoke It Note: Smaller hams will take less time, larger hams will take more time. If you have limited time, consider smoking 2 smaller hams rather than 1 large one to speed up the process.
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Smoke It Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F and make sure that you have about 3-4 hours worth of good smoking wood. I used pecan but hickory or almost any fruit wood would also work really good on this.
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Smoke It Once the smoker is heated up and holding steady, place the ham on a Bradley rack and place the rack on the smoker grate or you can just place the ham directly on the smoker grate.
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Smoke It Please note, you can use almost any type of ham including the spiral cut variety.
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Smoke It Once the ham is about 1 hour from being done, baste it twice, 15 minutes between each basting, with my Dr. Pepper and Honey Barbecue Glaze
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Smoke It To make the Dr. Pepper and Honey Barbecue Glaze: 1/3 cup of Jeff’s Barbecue Sauce, ½ cup of Dr. Pepper (Not diet), ¼ cup of Honey
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Smoke It Add all ingredients to a small bowl and mix well.
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Smoke It Apply to ham with a basting brush making sure to get it down into the score marks and all over the top and sides of the ham.
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Rest, Slice and Serve When the ham reaches 140 to 145°F in the center, pull it out of the smoker and set it on the cabinet for about 15 minutes to rest.
fc7d2974-da59-46e9-ac95-ca94c9905992 Rest, Slice and Serve Slice, serve and enjoy!
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Prepare the Meat and Vegetables If you are doing sausage with bologna, you will want to have about 4 sausage links and about 2 lbs of bologna.
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Prepare the Meat and Vegetables If using sausage only, you'll want to use an extra 3-4 links.
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Prepare the Meat and Vegetables Cut the sausage up into pieces that are about 1-2 inches long.
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Prepare the Meat and Vegetables Cut the bologna up into chunks as well. Don't forget to remove the wrapper
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Prepare the Meat and Vegetables Remove the stem, core and seeds from the peppers and slice them up into strips as shown.
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Prepare the Meat and Vegetables Slice the onion into pieces.
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Marinate Overnight Place the meat and vegetables into a large ziptop bag with ½ cup of oil and 1 cup of Jeff's rub
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Marinate Overnight Place the bag into the fridge overnight if possible to let all of the flavors meld together or at least for a couple of hours.
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Marinate Overnight When the marinating is finished, pour the contents into a 9x13 or whatever container you are using.
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Smoke Sausage and Peppers with Bologna Set up your smoker for indirect cooking at about 225°F for 2 hours or until the vegetables are sufficiently tender to your liking.
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Smoke Sausage and Peppers with Bologna Apply smoke from cherry, apple or your favorite smoking wood for at least 1 hour or you can keep it going for the full 2 hours for great flavor.
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Smoke Sausage and Peppers with Bologna Stir the meat and vegetables 3-4 times during the process to make sure the smoke has access to everything.
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Smoke Sausage and Peppers with Bologna When the vegetables are tender to your liking and the meat has had time to get sufficiently hot and smokey, the dish is complete.
93380e18-9fd4-4e8d-8221-54667ecb852d Serve the Deliciousness Serve over rice or on top of buns
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Season the Corned Beef Rinse the corned beef brisket under cold water
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Season the Corned Beef Lay the meat in a pan (recommended) so you can season it on all sides without making a huge mess.
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Season the Corned Beef Brush vegetable or olive oil onto all sides of the meat to help the rub to stick
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Season the Corned Beef Apply a generous portion of my Texas style rub to all sides of the corned beef brisket
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Season the Corned Beef My corned beef had a seasoning packet which included seeds of fennel, coriander, mustard and caraway along with allspice, cinnamon, pepper, dried chili and pieces of bay leaf. I decided to go ahead and use it on the very top of the beef to enhance the color and flavor.
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Season the Corned Beef If your’s does not have a seasoning packet, you can add on some common pickling spices (available in a small can where you purchase spices)
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Season the Corned Beef You can season the night before if you wish or you can perform this task right before you are ready to smoke the corned beef. Your choice.
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Season the Corned Beef Once seasoned, the corned beef brisket is placed on a rack to make it very easy to transport the beef to and from the smoker.
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Smoking the Beef Set up your smoker for cooking indirect at 225-240°F using cherry wood if you have it. Any there smoking wood will work fine.
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Smoking the Beef If you have a water pan, use it. A little humidity in the smoker goes a long way toward helping the meat to not dry out as bad in the smoker.
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Smoking the Beef Once the smoker is ready to go, place the corned beef brisket flat in the smoker on a rack or directly on the grate.
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Smoking the Beef Monitor the temperature of the brisket using a digital probe meat thermometer so you will know exactly when it’s done.
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Smoking the Beef The meat is safe to eat when it reaches 160°F but is usually cooked to 190°F or higher to allow it to get more tender.
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Smoking the Beef You can expect this to take from 6-10 hours depending on the thickness of the corned beef brisket that you are using. The thicker is is, the longer it will take to reach it’s done temperature.
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Slice and Serve When the meat is done cooking, it can be held for 3-4 hours (if needed) wrapped in foil until dinner time as long as it is kept at or above 140°F.
5aaa8b7e-fca4-41d6-8e67-d0bd9058036d Slice and Serve To serve, slice the meat up into ¼ inch pieces.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Marinate Chicken Wings Place a single layer of the wings in a disposable pan
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Marinate Chicken Wings Drizzle with olive or vegetable oil and brush it on to coat all sides thoroughly.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Marinate Chicken Wings Sprinkle a generous amount of Jeff’s original rub onto the wings then flip them over and apply rub to the other side as well.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Marinate Chicken Wings Let the rub “settle in” and when it starts getting that wet look, place the wings in a ziptop bag.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Marinate Chicken Wings Place them in the fridge for 2 hours.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Brine Wings with Buttermilk Make the brine: Pour the quart of buttermilk into a pitcher and add in ¼ cup of salt. Stir for about 20 seconds to make sure the salt is dissolved.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Brine Wings with Buttermilk Pour the brine into the bag with the marinated chicken making sure that all of the chicken is submerged in the brine.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Brine Wings with Buttermilk Place the bag of chicken back into the fridge for another 2 hours.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Re-season Wings with Rub After 2 hours of brining, remove the chicken wings from the fridge and pour them into a disposable aluminum pan for seasoning.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Re-season Wings with Rub The wings do NOT need to be rinsed off. The buttermilk and rub together adds a lot of flavor and because my rub is low on salt, the salt in the brining process is perfectly fine.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Re-season Wings with Rub Add more rub to the chicken wings by placing the wings in a single layer and reapplying the rub just like you did in the beginning.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Re-season Wings with Rub Flip all of the wings over and rub the other side as well..
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Re-season Wings with Rub Leave the wings sitting for a few minutes while you get the smoker ready!
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Smoke Chicken Wings Set up your smoker for cooking at about 250°F if possible. Lower temperatures will work if your smoker will not get up to 250°F as long as you know that it will take them a little longer to reach their finish temperature.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Smoke Chicken Wings I recommend using hickory on these or even mesquite if you want to.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Smoke Chicken Wings Place the chicken wings directly on the grate
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Smoke Chicken Wings You can expect the chicken wings to reach 165-170°F in about 1 hour.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Smoke Chicken Wings Use a good quality instant read thermometer such as the Thermapen to test the temperature and make sure all of them are perfectly and safely done.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Sauce and Broil Just before the wings are finished cooking, turn on the broiler in your oven so it’s ready to caramelize the sauce just as soon as they are finished in the smoker.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Sauce and Broil You will also need to get the sauce ready by mixing 2 parts Jeff’s sauce with 1 part honey. To make a cup of the honey barbecue sauce, mix ⅔ cup of Jeff’s barbecue sauce with ⅓ cup of honey.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Sauce and Broil Bring the finished wings into the house and brush the sauce onto the top of the chicken wings as generously as you dare.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Sauce and Broil Place them under the broiler for about a minute or until the sauce starts to bubble furiously (WATCH THEM CAREFULLY).
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Sauce and Broil Remove them, flip them over, sauce the bottom side and broil that side for about a minute once again.
7a489fba-b96e-461f-aa83-1ed98a2837dc Watch them Disappear Holler, “done!” and watch them evaporate from before your eyes
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Marinate the Chuck Roast Rinse the chuck roast under cold water and dry with a paper towel
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Marinate the Chuck Roast Make the Bourbon Beef Marinade: 2 TBS Jeff’s original rub, 1 cup beef broth, ¼ cup Bourbon, ¼ cup Worcestershire sauce, 2 TBS lemon juice
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Marinate the Chuck Roast Add all ingredients to a pint jar and mix well.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Marinate the Chuck Roast Place the meat down in a large pan and cover the pan with stretch wrap. This prevents huge messes while injecting by keeping the marinade contained inside the enclosed area.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Marinate the Chuck Roast I recommend an injector with a large needle so the rub does not get stuck. Many injectors have very small openings in the needle and the coarse rub will clog easily.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Marinate the Chuck Roast Stir the marinade before each fill of the injector.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Marinate the Chuck Roast Once the injector is full of marinade, press the end of the needle into the meat at a 45 degree angle and depress the plunger to push the marinade into the meat. You will see it plump up. Once it starts running out, it’s time to move to a new location.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Marinate the Chuck Roast I usually inject about every inch.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Marinate the Chuck Roast Use about half of the marinade inside the meat and then pour the rest over the top.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Marinate the Chuck Roast Cover the foil pan and place in the fridge for about 8 hours to marinate. Flip the meat over after 4 hours so both sides are able to sit in the marinade for a while.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Season the Meat After marinating the meat, the only thing left to do is to add my rub to the outside. This will create a nice crust and give you that perfectly seasoned bite you are looking for. (With the meat already wet from the marinade, there is no need to add mustard or oil to help the rub to stick.)
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Season the Meat If possible, place the chuck roast on a Bradley rack and sit that right on top of the pan. This allows the smoke to have full access to the meat and the juices from the roast can drip down into the pan keeping the smoker clean and giving us some nice, tasty meat juice.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Season the Meat My original rub is perfect on this chuck roast. Use the Texas rub once it’s finished being pulled/chopped if you need more saltiness.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Smoke the Chuck Roast Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F with enough wood to last at least 4 hours or longer.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Smoke the Chuck Roast I used a mix of mesquite and apple but you can use another favorite if you desire.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Smoke the Chuck Roast Place the chuck roast directly on the grate or if you have the Bradley racks I mentioned earlier, you can use the same configuration as I did.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Smoke the Chuck Roast If you have a vertical smoker with multiple racks, you can also just place the pan on a lower grate to allow the juices to drip down into the pan.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Prepare the Vegetables While the chuck roast smokes away, you can cut up your peppers and onions and get them ready to go.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Finish Cooking the Chuck Roast When the roast reaches about 150°F, pour the vegetables into the drip pan and place the roast right on top
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Finish Cooking the Chuck Roast If you need more juice, just add about a cup of beef broth.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Finish Cooking the Chuck Roast Cover the top of the pan tightly with foil and place the pan back into the smoker to finish.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Finish Cooking the Chuck Roast Be sure to use a digital probe meat thermometer to keep tabs on the internal temperature of the meat.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Finish Cooking the Chuck Roast When the roast reaches about 210°F, it is done cooking and is ready to be pulled/chopped and served.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Finish Cooking the Chuck Roast I recommend letting it rest uncovered for about 20 minutes before processing it further.
df937479-d118-4968-a7cd-9b39b7cf0270 Serve the Bourbon Smoked Chuck Roast The chuck roast can be served in any number of ways, similar to brisket. We chose to serve the meat and vegetables piled high on wheat hoagie buns topped with parmesan cheese and my Texas rub.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Brine the Trout Make enough brine to cover the number of fish you are smoking. Brine is easy and cheap to make so I usually just make a gallon unless I know for sure that I don’t need that much.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Brine the Trout Make my basic brine recipe using 1 gallon of water, 1 cup of coarse kosher salt, 1 cup of brown sugar (Dark is best, light will work), ¼ cup of lemon juice (2 lemons squeezed, approx.)
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Brine the Trout Add the coarse kosher salt and lemon juice to the gallon of water in a large pitcher and mix until the salt is dissolved then add the brown sugar and mix thoroughly.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Brine the Trout Place the trout into a lidded bowl or a zip top bag
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Brine the Trout Pour enough brine over the fish to cover completely.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Brine the Trout Seal the bowl or bag and place it in the fridge for about 2 hours.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Brine the Trout Once the fish are done brining, rinse them under cold water to remove any residual salt.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Season and Stuff the Trout Brush olive oil onto the entire inside flesh of the fish. This makes the rub stick to the fish really well and helps to keep the fish moist while it cooks.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Season and Stuff the Trout Hold the trout open and sprinkle a good hefty portion of my Texas style rub into the inside of the fish.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Season and Stuff the Trout Stuff the inside of the fish with equal portions of the oregano and chives.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Season and Stuff the Trout Place about 3 slices of lemon into each fish
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Season and Stuff the Trout The fish are now ready to smoke.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Smoke the Trout Set up your smoker or grill with indirect heat maintaining 225°F and a light flavored wood such as alder or apple.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Smoke the Trout Once the smoker is ready, place the fish directly on the oiled grate. Note: To make sure the trout do not stick to the rack or grate, you can place each fish on a piece of parchment paper cut to the basic footprint of the fish. Usually about 3 inches wide and 10-12 inches in length will work great for “good eating size” fish.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Smoke the Trout Cook the fish until it reaches an internal temperature of 145°F. At this point the meat of the fish will flake easily and it will be perfectly done. This will usually take about an hour.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Finishing Up Once the trout is smoked and ready, remove it from the smoker right away.
6b833f6b-f72a-4a55-92f3-938fc3e33938 Finishing Up Serve the trout immediately for best results.
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Clean Them Place the oysters in a colander and run cold water over them to remove grit and pieces of shell
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Clean Them Clean the shells while you are at it for good presentation
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Clean Them Dry the oysters carefully with a paper towel
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Season Lay the oysters on the cutting board and sprinkle Jeff's rub on them lightly
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Season Flip them over and season the other side
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Wrap with Bacon Cut bacon into thirds
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Wrap with Bacon Place an oyster on one end of the bacon
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Wrap with Bacon Wrap the bacon around the oyster allowing it to overlap by ½ inch
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Wrap with Bacon Use scissors to cut off any extra bacon
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Wrap with Bacon Secure with a toothpick
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Wrap with Bacon Sprinkle more of Jeff's rub onto each wrapped oyster
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Smoke 'em Up Set up smoker for cooking at 225°F with indirect heat
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Smoke 'em Up Once smoker is ready, place oysters onto smoker grate
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Smoke 'em Up Allow the oysters to cook for about 1 hour and 45 minutes or until the bacon is browned and beginning to crisp
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Smoke 'em Up Remove the oysters from the smoker just as soon as they are finished cooking
2acd2c17-9a26-46e1-8cbc-555246e35a6a Serve Serve immediately with hot sauce or a 50/50 mix of Louisiana Hot Sauce and Jeff's Barbecue sauce and watch them disappear.
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Make the Meatball Mix Place the ground chuck, ground pork (or sausage), egg, parmesan, jalapeño, onion, grated cheddar, bread crumbs, rub, barbecue sauce, Worcestershire and yogurt into a large mixing bowl and get in there with your clean bare hands to combine everything thoroughly.
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Form the Meatballs Use your hands to form meatballs that are about 1.5 inch in diameter. I used an ice cream scoop to make sure I was getting the same amount every time then rolled it between my cupped palms to make it round.
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Add the Cubed Cheese Press the ¼ inch cubes of cheese right down into the center of each meatball.
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Add the Cubed Cheese Roll the meatball between cupped palms again to reform them into round shapes.
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Add the Cubed Cheese Optional: Transfer the meatballs to a Bradley rack or cookie sheet to help transport them to the smoker.
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Smoke the Cheesy Meatballs Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225°F using apple wood if you have it. Other fruit woods will work as well as pecan, oak, or almost any smoking wood that you have and like.
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Smoke the Cheesy Meatballs Once ready, place the cheesy meatballs (or the entire Bradley rack if you are using them), directly onto the smoker grate.
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Smoke the Cheesy Meatballs Keep the smoke going the entire time and do your best to maintain 225°F throughout.
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Brushing on Sauce (optional) I chose to serve the sauce on the side but I was asked by more than one person why I did not sauce them. I'm just saying.. you might consider it;)
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Brushing on Sauce (optional) If you choose to sauce them, do so at about the 30 and 45 minute mark. This will give the sauce time to glaze over so they are not too sticky.
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Finishing Up Check the temperature of the meatballs and when they reach 160 °F, they are done. This should take about an hour, but you might check them sooner than this to get a feel for how fast they are getting done. The amount of time required will be determined by the temperature of the meatballs when they go into the smoker, how often you open the door and let the heat escape, the diameter of the meatballs
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Serve the Cheesy Smoked Meatballs Serving the cheesy smoked meatballs simply means that you bring them into the house (after having hid a few for yourself).
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Other Options Wrap in half slices of bacon
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Other Options Use these for meatball subs (delicious)
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Other Options Use ground turkey or ground chicken for healthier choices
93143c30-b8a6-4c1f-abad-8eb01ae339c6 Other Options Use over pasta (spaghetti, linguini, etc.)
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Brine for Great Flavor and Juiciness Make a basic brine from 1 gallon of water, 1 cup of kosher salt and ¾ cup of brown sugar.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Brine for Great Flavor and Juiciness Add the salt to the water and stir until dissolved.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Brine for Great Flavor and Juiciness Add the brown sugar and stir once again until it is dissolved.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Brine for Great Flavor and Juiciness Put the chicken quarters down into a large zip top bag and then pour the brine into the bag over the chicken to cover.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Brine for Great Flavor and Juiciness Brine in the refrigerator or in temperature of 33 to 39°F for 4 hours.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Brine for Great Flavor and Juiciness When it’s done brining, give the chicken quarters a good rinse and you are ready to proceed.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Season the Chicken Quarters Brush on some olive oil to help the rub to stick
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Season the Chicken Quarters Apply a tablespoon or two of my rub to the top of the chicken and spread it all over with your hands so that it mixes with the oil and creates a nice paste.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Season the Chicken Quarters Make sure to get oil and rub up under the skin a little as well.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Season the Chicken Quarters Move the seasoned chicken quarters to a Bradley rack or similar device and it’s ready to go into the smoker.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Smoke the Chicken Setup your smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Smoke the Chicken Place the chicken directly on the grate leaving about 1 inch between them to allow the smoke full access to the meat.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Smoke the Chicken Leave the chicken quarters in the smoker using indirect heat for about 1 hour during which time it will reach about 140°F internally.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Smoke the Chicken Use dry pecan, cherry or another favorite wood for smoke the entire time it is in the smoker.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Smoke the Chicken Be sure to use a thermometer such as the Maverick ET-733 to monitor the temperature of the chicken while it cooks in the smoker and grill.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Finish the Chicken on the Grill Heat the grill to very high heat just before the chicken is finished smoking.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Finish the Chicken on the Grill Once an hour of smoking has passed, place the chicken on the grill over direct heat.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Finish the Chicken on the Grill Brush on a little of my sauce while it finishes cooking.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Finish the Chicken on the Grill Watch the chicken carefully to make sure it does not burn.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Finish the Chicken on the Grill When the chicken quarters reach 165-170 °F, they are finished cooking and are ready to eat.
cfe07a61-c426-4435-aec9-4afdf6ba0d35 Serve the Chicken Serve the chicken quarters immediately when they are finished cooking.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Smoking a Brisket Last week, I showed you how to smoke a brisket from start to finish and those instructions are archived HERE.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Smoking a Brisket When it gets finished, separate the flat part of the brisket from the thicker, more fatty end called the point. The point is used to make the burnt ends.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Smoking a Chuck Roast Brisket is really expensive right now and you may find a chuck roast to be a little easier on the wallet.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Smoking a Chuck Roast Smoke the chuck roast at 225°F until it reaches 160°F.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Smoking a Chuck Roast Wrap it in foil and continue cooking it until it reaches about 200 °F.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Separate Top from Bottom Once you remove the flat end, you will notice that there is a thick vein of fat that runs through the middle of the brisket. I run my knife along the bottom of this to separate them.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Separate Top from Bottom Slice/remove the fat from the top of the pieces.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Slice and Cube the Meat Slice the meat into pieces that are about 1 to 1-1/2 inch thick.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Slice and Cube the Meat Further cut the thick slices into pieces about 1 inch wide to make cubes of meat.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Slice and Cube the Meat Add some sauce to each one
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Slice and Cube the Meat Sprinkle on some rub generously then roll them around to coat well.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Slice and Cube the Meat If you want more rub, you can also place some rub in a plate and roll the sauced brisket pieces in the rub.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Slice and Cube the Meat The rub and sauce together is what makes that nice caramelized coating on the outside that tastes so good.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Wrap in Bacon Now that the little tasty morsels of goodness are covered in a nice layer of sauce and rub, you can cut pieces of thin bacon in half and wrap each one.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Smoke It Setup whatever smoker or grill you have available for cooking at 225°F.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Smoke It With the bacon wrapped version we are making in this recipe, I recommend using a Bradley rack or something similar to give them open access to the heat and smoke.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Smoke It You can also crank up the heat to help the bacon to crisp up a little bit. Using thin bacon helps a lot.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Smoke It Brush on a little sauce if desired about 30 minutes before removing them from the heat.
c70fd181-5574-480f-b4d3-46f56362f3fa Smoke It Serve 'em up and Enjoy!
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Prepare Score the fat cap down to meat in a crosshatch pattern - 1 inch increments
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Prepare Massage about 2 TBS of mustard and about 3-4 TBS of Jeff's rub onto the top and bottom side of the brisket
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Smoke Preheat smoker to 225°F
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Smoke Place brisket fat side up on smoker grate
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Smoke Place pan under brisket if possible to catch juices
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Smoke Apply smoke for at least 6 hours
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Smoke Smoke cook brisket for about 16 to 18 hours or until it reaches 200°F in the flat
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Smoke Remove brisket from smoker when finished and cool for 30 minutes on counter
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Chop and Re-smoke After cooling, separate flat from point
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Chop and Re-smoke Remove fat cap from top of flat
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Chop and Re-smoke Chop remainder of flat and put meat into a foil pan
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Chop and Re-smoke Add half of defatted juices back into chopped meat
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Chop and Re-smoke Place pan of chopped brisket back into smoker for 30 minutes
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Finish Up and Serve Add more of the defatted juices if needed and season with Jeff's Texas style rub to taste
669d9f08-5213-4231-8943-5a482a622d70 Finish Up and Serve Serve immediately with warm barbecue sauce on the side
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Butterfly and Pound the Turkey Breast(s) Lay the turkey breast on the cutting board and butterfly it.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Butterfly and Pound the Turkey Breast(s) Lay plastic wrap on top of the turkey breast and pound the meat to flatten it evenly to about ¼ inch thick.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Season and Stuff the Turkey Breasts Sprinkle a little of my rub on the inside surface area of the turkey breast.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Season and Stuff the Turkey Breasts Spoon some of the uncooked stuffing onto the top of the seasoned meat. Leave about ½ inch around the edges and about 2 inches on the end away from you.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Season and Stuff the Turkey Breasts Add some dried sweetened cranberries and chopped pecans to the top of the stuffing.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Roll It Up and Tie It Roll up the turkey breast as tightly as you can.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Roll It Up and Tie It Use 4 pieces of cooking twine to tie the stuffed and rolled turkey breast into place.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Season the Outside Sprinkle the Texas style rub on the outside of the turkey breast.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Season the Outside Place the turkey breast(s) on a Bradley rack or cookie sheet to make it easy to transport to and from the smoker.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Smoke the Meat Set up whatever smoker you have available for cooking at about 225°F using indirect heat. If your smoker came with a water pan, use it.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Smoke the Meat Once the smoker is heated and ready, place the stuffed, rolled turkey breasts directly on the smoker grate.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Smoke the Meat Use pecan wood if you have it or any fruit wood will work really well with this.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Smoke the Meat I recommend keeping the smoke going for at least 2 hours if possible. You can also keep the smoke going the entire time as long you keep the smoke thin and light.. what we call thin blue smoke.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Smoke the Meat About once every hour, baste the turkey with a little melted butter to keep the outside of the meat moist so it does not dry out.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Finish and Serve Use a digital probe meat thermometer to monitor the temperature of the meat while it cooks.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Finish and Serve When it hits 165°F in the center, it is perfectly done and should be removed from the smoker right away.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Finish and Serve Let it rest on the cabinet for 10 minutes then remove the strings.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Finish and Serve Slice it into ½ to ¾ inch slices.
5a8bcbe3-3079-49db-b700-576fa54f22ba Finish and Serve Serve immediately with all of your other favorite fixings and sides.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Clean Up the Pork Tenderloins Remove the pork tenderloins from the package, give them a rinse under cold water and pat them dry with a paper towel.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Clean Up the Pork Tenderloins Lay them on the cutting board and do your best to remove any silver skin, extra fat, etc.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Season the Pork Tenderloins As usual, I like to use the old trusty yellow mustard base on this pork to help that rub to stick really well.
