4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Season the Pork Tenderloins Sprinkle on a few tablespoons of rub and massage it into the meat all over.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Season the Pork Tenderloins If you are doing these the night before (recommended) simply put them in a big ziploc bag and place in the fridge overnight.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Season the Pork Tenderloins If you are ready to smoke, you can lay them on a Bradley rack with a little space between them and you are good to go.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Setup the Smoker You can use whatever smoker or grill you have access to.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Setup the Smoker Set it up for cooking at about 225°F using indirect heat.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Smoke the Meat Place the pork tenderloins directly on the grate or place the Bradley rack with the meat on the grate.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Smoke the Meat You can probably expect these to take around 1.5 to 2 hours to reach the perfect safely done temperature for pork at 145°F.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Smoke the Meat Keep the smoke going for the entire time if you can or for at least an hour to get some good smoke flavor on the meat.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Smoke the Meat I used cherry to go along with the cherry compote but any fruit wood or even pecan would be really good on these.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Smoke the Meat When the pork tenderloins reach about 110°F or about an hour into the cook, brush some of the cherry bourbon compote onto the top of each one.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Smoke the Meat Wait about 20 minutes and repeat.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Smoke the Meat Be sure to use a tested digital thermometer to monitor the temperature while they cook. You are looking for about 145°F but I often remove them a couple of degrees early if I plan to wrap them in foil and hold them for 30-60 minutes until dinner time.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Make the Cherry Bourbon Compote Into a medium sauce pan, place ¼ cup Bourbon, ¼ cup brown sugar, ½ cup water, and a 12-13 oz jar of cherry preserves.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Make the Cherry Bourbon Compote Using medium heat, bring the mixture to a rolling boil then reduce heat slightly to simmer for 10 minutes.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Make the Cherry Bourbon Compote The compote will reduce by about 1/3 by the time it is finished.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Make the Cherry Bourbon Compote When 10 minutes have elapsed, remove the compote from the heat and allow it to cool.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Finish and Serve the Smoked Pork Tenderloin Remove the pork tenderloins from the smoker and bring them into the house.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Finish and Serve the Smoked Pork Tenderloin If necessary, wrap them in foil and then in a thick towel on the counter to hold them for 30-60 minutes until dinner time.
4e067b57-e376-4776-916b-5212a525af0e Finish and Serve the Smoked Pork Tenderloin When ready to serve, remove from the foil, slice and serve about 1/3 to ½ tenderloin per person
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 About Prime Rib (Standing Rib Roast) Ask the butcher to semi-detach the bones, to tie it up and to french the bones. They are usually happy to offer these services.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 About Prime Rib (Standing Rib Roast) Note: Figure on 1 bone for every 2 people eating.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Season the Meat Lay the prime rib on the cutting board
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Season the Meat Brush on a little olive oil or cooking oil to help the rub to stick.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Season the Meat Mix up a batch of the Texas style rub recipe and use it generously all over the prime rib.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Setup the Smoker You can use any smoker to smoke this prime rib but I recommend that you use one that allows you to easily control the temperature.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Setup the Smoker Set up your smoker to maintain about 225°F for about 5-6 hours.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Smoke the Prime Rib Once the smoker is ready to go, place the prime rib roast directly on the grate, bones down.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Smoke the Prime Rib I used dry mesquite wood for flavor but you can use pecan, or almost any fruit wood such as cherry for great results.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Smoke the Prime Rib Keep the smoke going the entire time if you desire or you can go for about 3 hours and that should be plenty.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Smoke the Prime Rib Use a digital probe meat thermometer to monitor the temperature and be sure to test it in boiling water beforehand to make sure it is reading within a degree or two of 212°F.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Smoke the Prime Rib I recommend cooking the prime rib to medium rare or about 135-140°F.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Finish Up Once the smoked prime rib hits that magic number of 138 °F or whatever you deem it to be, remove it quickly from the smoker and move it to the house. There is no need to wait to cut it but you can hold it for 30 minutes or so by tenting foil over the top of the roast.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Finish Up When ready to slice it up, clip the strings, remove the bones and then slice it into pieces about ¾ inch thick.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Worcestershire butter recipe One stick or ¼ lb. of (real) salted butter, room temperature, 1-½ TBS of Worcestershire sauce, and 1 tsp of the Texas style rub recipe.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Worcestershire butter recipe Mix/fold everything together until all ingredients are combined really well.
f119f1e2-57a9-4bb2-a464-b5be64e2e451 Questions How to reheat slices of the prime rib? Very carefully! You do not want to overheat the meat which will cook it and take it beyond medium rare. I sometimes just set it on the counter to let it come up to room temperature and just eat it that way to preserve all of that original good flavor. You can also wrap it up in a piece of foil with just a teaspoon of water or beef broth in the bottom of the foil. Place it into a 225 degree oven for about 30 minutes or until it gets as warm as you like it. Be sure to not let it exceed 140°F or it will no longer be medium rare.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Getting the Ribs Prepped Remove the membrane.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Getting the Ribs Prepped Apply some vegetable oil or yellow mustard to the ribs to help the rub to stick real nice to the meat.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Cinnamon (optional) Use a 50:50 mix of cinnamon and white sugar
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Cinnamon (optional) After you add the vegetable oil, just sprinkle a very light dusting of the cinnamon sugar on both sides of the ribs (it doesn’t take a lot).
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Cinnamon (optional) For an alternative to the extra layer of cinnamon, I had a reader tell me that he mixes in 1 TBS of cinnamon per batch of my rub for a nice flavor.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Season the Ribs Sprinkle my rub on the bone side first.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Season the Ribs Let the ribs sit there just a few minutes to let the rub absorb the oil and create a paste.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Season the Ribs Flip ribs over to meaty side up and repeat oil and rub
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Season the Ribs Let the ribs sit there a little longer while you go get the smoker ready.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Set Up the Smoker Set up your smoker for cooking at about 240°F if possible. Be sure to use a tried and true thermometer to make sure that your smoker is running at the temperature that it says it is.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Set Up the Smoker Once your smoker is heated up and ready to smoke, it’s time to get those ribs on the grate.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs Step 1
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs Place the ribs bone side down if possible.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs Let the ribs cook at about 240°F and with smoke for 2 hours.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs Step 2
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs At the end of 2 hours, wrap the ribs with foil.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs Do this carefully so as to not tear the foil. If you do happen to tear it, just double wrap it with another piece.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs Place the wrapped ribs back into the 240°F smoker and you can even stack them all together if you need to.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs Let them cook in this wrapped state for about 2 hours.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs Step 3
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs With a total of 4 hours past, you now want to unwrap them again.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs They will be very soft on the outside and very tender on the inside, and this last step is to firm up the outside just a little before serving them.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs Remove the foil and place them back into the 240°F smoker for 1 hour.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs Alternative for Step 3
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Smoke the Pork Baby Back Ribs Throw them on a very hot grill and let the high heat give them a good char. Paint on some barbecue sauce if you like sticky ribs.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Serve the Ribs Slice up the ribs and serve them
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Questions What if I want to do spare ribs or St. Louis style spares? No problem. Follow the same basic process but add an extra hour to the first step. It will end up being 3-2-1.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Questions Should I put liquid down in the foil during step 2? You can and many do but I found of late that I get better results with less steam. By leaving out the liquid, there is less steam and the rub stays intact better.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Questions Should I brine my ribs? I have liquid brined the ribs for about 6 hours and the results were very good. Dry brining using 1 TBS of kosher salt for the entire rack makes the meat too salty and “hammy” for my liking so I don’t recommend it.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Questions Not enough room. Is it ok to use a rib rack? If you have to use a rib rack due to space constraints, that is fine but I feel that the flat, bone side down is the best position since that allows the juices to pool on top of the meat and keeps the ribs more moist while they cook.
cb9e21fc-cdb6-457a-9b76-a7c6045c83a5 Questions Do I need to use a water pan? If your smoker came new designed to be used with a water pan, it is always a good idea to use it unless you are drying meat/making jerky.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Slice the Steaks You can purchase the ham steaks already sliced into ½ inch pieces or you can do it yourself. I recommend purchasing them already sliced or asking your butcher to do it for you. Their meal slicer will make quick work of it.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Season the Ham Steaks Lay the ham steaks in a Bradley rack or even a cookie sheet.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Season the Ham Steaks Brush some cooking oil on the top side to help the rub to stick. You can also use yellow mustard if you are so inclined.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Season the Ham Steaks Sprinkle some of Jeff’s rub on the top side of the ham steaks.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Season the Ham Steaks The ham steaks are now ready to go into the smoker.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Smoke the Ham Steaks Setup the smoker for cooking at about 225°F for about 1 hour.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Smoke the Ham Steaks Place the Bradley racks with the ham steaks onto the smoker grate or lay the ham steaks onto the smoker grate (rub side up).
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Smoke the Ham Steaks Let the ham steaks cook smoke for about 30 minutes then spoon on some of the cranberry glaze (instructions below) and spread it out all over the top of the ham steaks.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Make the Cranberry Glaze Ingredients: 12 oz package of cranberries (fresh or frozen), 1 cup sugar, 1 cup water, 1-½ teaspoons orange peel (grated)
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Make the Cranberry Glaze Place cranberries and sugar in a food processor or blender. Chop cranberries coarsely.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Make the Cranberry Glaze Put sugar/cranberry mixture into a medium saucepan.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Make the Cranberry Glaze Add 1 cup of water and grated orange peel and bring to a boil stirring occasionally.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Make the Cranberry Glaze Reduce heat and simmer stirring occasionally until mixture is reduced to about 2-1/3 cups (about 10-12 minutes).
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Make the Cranberry Glaze Allow glaze to cool slightly before using.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Make the Cranberry Glaze (optional) I wanted the glaze to not be coarse and chunky so I put it back into the food processor until it was smooth.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Put Glaze on Ham Steaks & Finish Smoking Continue cooking/smoking ham for an additional 30 minutes after you put the glaze on the ham.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Put Glaze on Ham Steaks & Finish Smoking Since the ham is already cooked, we are only adding additional smoke flavor and heating them to a good eating temperature.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Put Glaze on Ham Steaks & Finish Smoking When 1 hour has expired, the double smoked ham steaks should be appropriately hot and nicely smoked.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Put Glaze on Ham Steaks & Finish Smoking Place the double smoked ham steaks under the broiler for a couple of minutes to caramelize the glaze just a little. Watch it carefully so that it does not burn.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Alternative Options: Brush my barbecue sauce on the ham about 30 minutes into the cook time.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Alternative Options: Use your favorite jelly or jam on the ham about 30 minutes into the cook time.
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Alternative Options: Honey and/or maple syrup is always great as a glaze on ham
0318e860-cc0e-4fba-8d9c-46440c0f6e4d Alternative Options: Serve the ham right away or keep it covered and warm until dinner.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Brine the Turkey First, make the brine
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Brine the Turkey Maple Turkey Brine Recipe: 1 gallons water, 1 cup of kosher salt (coarse), 12 oz of real maple syrup, 2 TBS of Jeff’s Rub
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Brine the Turkey Place a quart of the water in a pot over medium heat and add the maple syrup and rub to the water to help it melt and mix together better.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Brine the Turkey Stir for about 3-4 minutes then remove from the heat and let it cool to room temperature..
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Brine the Turkey Put the 3 quarts of cool, unheated water into a gallon sized pitcher and mix in the salt. Stir until the salt has completely dissolved.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Brine the Turkey Add the heated mixture to the salted water
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Brine the Turkey You need a food safe plastic/glass or other non-reactive container large enough to hold the turkey and enough brine to cover.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Brine the Turkey Remove the turkey from it’s packaging and remove any “gifts” that are stuffed down inside of the cavity.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Brine the Turkey Place the turkey in the brining container
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Brine the Turkey Pour enough brine over the turkey to cover it. If the turkey tries to float, put a heavy plate on top of it to hold it under the water.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Brine the Turkey I recommend using a smaller container if possible and placing the container in the fridge for optimum cooling. Add a bag or two of ice to help keep the water at less than 40°F if it will not fit in the fridge.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Brine the Turkey Leave the turkey in the brine for 10-12 hours or overnight.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Brine the Turkey When the turkey is finished brining, rinse it well under cold water to remove any residual salt on the surface of the meat.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Season the Turkey Since we are going with a maple theme this year, it only seems fitting to use maple syrup as our base to help the rub to stick.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Season the Turkey I placed the turkey in a baking pan to catch the mess.. yep, I don’t like cleanup!
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Season the Turkey Pour the maple syrup all over the turkey.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Season the Turkey Use a silicon brush or your hands to get it all over.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Season the Turkey Sprinkle Jeff’s rub all over the turkey
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Season the Turkey For a little extra flavor, work your hands down under the skin of the turkey and try to get some maple syrup and rub in there.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Season the Turkey At this point the turkey is ready to go in the smoker.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Get the Smoker Ready You can use practically any smoker (even the grill) to cook the Thanksgiving turkey this year as long as you can maintain a range between about 220 and 250°F using indirect heat.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Get the Smoker Ready Preheat the smoker/grill and once it is maintaining about 240°F , you are ready to smoke!
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Smoke the Thanksgiving Turkey Place the turkey directly on the grate breast side up, or if you want to keep the smoker a little cleaner, you can leave the turkey on the baking sheet.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Smoke the Thanksgiving Turkey If you are using a smoker that has multiple levels, you can place the turkey on a Bradley rack to make it easy to transport it to the smoker and then back into the house once it’s finished. Multiple levels allow you to place a pan on a lower rack to catch the syrup and turkey juices.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Smoke the Thanksgiving Turkey I used pecan wood for this turkey but almost any fruit wood or a mix of pecan and fruit wood such as apple, plum, or cherry, would be great.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Smoke the Thanksgiving Turkey Let the turkey smoke for about 2 hours without touching it.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Smoke the Thanksgiving Turkey At the 3 hour mark begin mopping the bird with the maple barbecue mop sauce every hour
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Smoke the Thanksgiving Turkey Maple Barbecue Mop Sauce: 6 oz maple syrup, 2 heaping TBS of Jeff’s original rub
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Smoke the Thanksgiving Turkey Heat the maple syrup in the microwave then add the rub. Mix well then continuously mix while using.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Smoke the Thanksgiving Turkey Use a silicon brush or basting mop to apply the mop sauce to the top, sides, legs and wings of the turkey.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 When is the Turkey Done? I highly recommend using a good digital probe meat thermometer to monitor the temperature of the turkey while it cooks.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 When is the Turkey Done? Turkey breast which is white meat cooks a little differently than the darker meat found in the legs and wings and it is important to find the happy medium between getting the two meats perfectly done.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 When is the Turkey Done? I usually go with the breast temperature and as long as both the white breast meat and the legs are at least 165°F , I call the turkey done.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 When is the Turkey Done? I recommend 165°F simply because I believe that’s the optimum temperature based on my experience.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Rest the Turkey I recommend allowing the turkey to rest after it is done cooking. During this time, the juices settle back down in the meat and are less prone to spurt out when you cut into it.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Rest the Turkey When I go out to get the finished turkey, I usually take a large roasting pan lined with foil and a lid. The turkey goes from the smoker into the roasting pan and the lid is quickly placed on top to preserve the heat.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Rest the Turkey When I get it into the house, I allow it to sit on the cabinet for about 20-30 minutes before removing/carving the meat.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Carving the Smoked Turkey I start by removing the legs and wings.This gives me good access to cut slices of the breast meat.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Carving the Smoked Turkey I recommend placing the dark meat and white meat in separate piles so folks can get what they want without having to dig around for it.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Questions Why breast side up? I sometimes cook the turkey breast side down for a short time then flip it over for the rest of the time, breast side up. This is not as important in smokers where the heat is really even and the heat is not moving from the bottom of the smoker to the top. In my experience, breast side up keeps the delicate breast meat the furthest from the heat and helps it to get done without any unintended blasts of heat. This also gives me the best access to mop and baste the meat with the maple barbecue mop sauce. All in all, I don’t think either way is a deal breaker. If you’ve had success with breast side down the entire time, then go for it.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Questions Can I stuff the turkey before smoking it? No. Smoking turkey at low temperatures makes it unsafe to block heat flow into the cavity of the turkey. Wait until the turkey is done then stuff it with the already cooked stuffing for table presentation. It is ok to place a few pieces of onion, apple, carrot, etc into the cavity as long as heat can travel freely into the cavity.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Questions How do I reheat the turkey if I cook it ahead of time? It just so happened that I had to reheat the turkey used in this newsletter. It was finished about 4 hours before we were ready to eat so I placed it in a roasting pan with a good fitting lid and put the entire pan in the fridge. About one hour before dinner time, I put the lidded roasting pan with the turkey into the oven preheated to 350°F. Just before closing the oven door, I basted it once again with some leftover maple barbecue mop sauce. After about 45 minutes the turkey was up to 120 °F internal temperature so I turned it down to 250 °F where it stayed for another 30 minutes until we were ready to carve it. It was a good eating temperature and was just as juicy as it ever was.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Questions Can I make the turkey ahead of time? Obviously, the best smoked turkey is going to be right out of the smoker the same day but if you have scheduling issues and must cook it ahead of time, you can certainly do that and it will still be the best turkey most folks have ever had. Ideally, you can make it less than 2-3 days before you need it and you can leave it in the fridge and simply reheat it the way that I did in the previous question. If it will be more than 3 days, it must be placed in the freezer. Thawing in the fridge is the best option and will take about 1 day for every 5 pounds of turkey. Once the turkey is thawed, place it in a pan with a lid. Add about 1 cup of water to the bottom of the pan. Make extra maple barbecue mop sauce and baste the turkey liberally just before heating it. Preheat the oven to 350 °F and place the pan of turkey, lid intact, into the oven for about 45 minutes to 1 hour or until it reaches a good eating temperature.
4392b9e6-874f-447b-8c8c-71d9eb56a967 Questions How much turkey do I need to smoke? For the bone to meat ratio in smoking size turkeys around 12 lb, you should figure about 2 uncooked lbs per person which will give you a good size helping per person with a few leftovers. For a 12 person thanksgiving dinner, I would make (2) 12 lb turkeys.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Make the Basic Buttermilk Brine Ingredients: ½ gallon water, 1 quart buttermilk, ¾ cup coarse kosher salt, and ½ cup dark brown sugar (light will work).
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Make the Basic Buttermilk Brine Place the water into a gallon sized pitcher.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Make the Basic Buttermilk Brine Add the salt and stir until the salt dissolves
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Make the Basic Buttermilk Brine Add the buttermilk and brown sugar and stir again for about 30 seconds to combine.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Make the Basic Buttermilk Brine Set the brine aside while you get the turkey legs out of the package.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Brine the Turkey Legs Remove the turkey legs from the package and place them into a ziptop bag or a lidded plastic/glass container.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Brine the Turkey Legs Pour enough brine over the turkey legs to cover them completely.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Brine the Turkey Legs Place a lid on the container then refrigerate the brining container for about 10 hours.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Brine the Turkey Legs When the turkey legs are finished brining, remove them from the brine and rinse them really well under cold water.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Season the Turkey Legs Drizzle olive oil over the drumsticks then spread it all over with your hands or a brush.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Season the Turkey Legs Sprinkle Jeff’s rub on all sides of the turkey drumsticks
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Prepare the Smoker Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225-240°F.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Prepare the Smoker If your smoker has a water pan, use it.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Smoke the Turkey Legs Once the smoker is going and maintaining the proper temperature, place the turkey legs on the grate.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Smoke the Turkey Legs It is best to monitor the temperature using a digital probe meat thermometer.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Smoke the Turkey Legs Once the turkey legs reach 165 °F in the thickest part, they are done and should be removed from the heat right away.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Rest the Turkey Legs & Serve Immediately wrap the smoked turkey legs in foil individually and let them sit and rest for about 10 minutes before serving them.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Questions Where can I find the giant turkey legs? Unfortunately, I have not been successful at finding the really big ones like you see at state fairs and amusement parks. The folks who do have them, do not give up their suppliers so, for the purpose of use lowly backyarders, I think we are going to have to stick with the smaller ones found at our local supermarkets.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Questions Should I dry the skin on the turkey legs? Some folks dry the skin (in the fridge) after brining them and before smoking them. This is to make the skin end up more crispy. I don’t normally administer this step but it does not hurt anything if you want to try it out. Simply brine the legs as usual, then pat them dry and place them on a rack. Let them air dry in the fridge for several hours before putting my rub on them and smoking them.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Questions Can these turkey legs be injected instead of brined? Of course you can, but, in my opinion, the flavor is not the same. When I eat a turkey leg, I am looking for a slightly salty and highly flavorful taste. In my opinion, injecting just does not do the job like brining does. The next time you do a batch, inject one of them and brine the rest. You will be able to see the difference and make a decision as to whether injected smoked turkey legs are for you.
7e95a7bf-c958-42f3-9d78-66ed43965860 Questions Can the turkey legs be smoked at a hotter temperature? Turkey, like most other poultry, does not benefit greatly from low and slow cooking other than the fact that it gets more time in the smoke. If you need to smoke them faster, you can certainly do that just be aware that if you take it past about 260°F, the sugar in the rub will burn and char. I tend to do them lower to give them more smoke flavor and to make sure my rub maintains it’s great flavor without burning.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Marinate the Beef Country Style Ribs Remove the beef from it’s package and give them a good rinse under cold water.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Marinate the Beef Country Style Ribs Place the meat in a ziptop bag or other plastic/glass lidded container
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Beef CSR Marinade -1/2 cup orange juice
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Beef CSR Marinade -1/2 cup worcestershire
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Beef CSR Marinade -¼ cup soy sauce
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Beef CSR Marinade -4 cloves, minced garlic
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Beef CSR Marinade -2 TBS Jeff’s rub
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Beef CSR Marinade -2 TBS molasses
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Beef CSR Marinade -1 tsp cayenne
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Beef CSR Marinade Mix well and pour over beef country style ribs to cover
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Season the Ribs with Jeff’s Rub Remove the meat from the marinade (do not rinse).
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Season the Ribs with Jeff’s Rub Coat the meat with yellow mustard
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Season the Ribs with Jeff’s Rub Pour some rub onto the meat and massage it into all sides.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Season the Ribs with Jeff’s Rub Lay the seasoned meat onto a bradley rack or cookie sheet for easy transport out to the smoker.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Get the Smoker Ready Prepare your smoker for cooking at about 225°F with indirect heat.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Get the Smoker Ready Fill the water pan with water if your smoker has one and have enough smoking wood to last about 2 hours. I use and recommend pecan if you have it.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Get the Smoker Ready Let the smoker preheat to 225 °F before placing the meat in the smoker.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 An Important Note About Beef Country Style Ribs I have been smoking this cut for long enough to know that every location and butcher does them a little different. Interestingly enough, they all tend to look similar but some of them are cut from the chuck roast while others are cut from more tender parts. For this reason, I recommend you monitor the internal temperature of these and check the tenderness once they reach about 135°F which is a good medium rare. If they happen to be tender at 135 then they are ready to eat. If they are still tough as shoe leather, then you likely have some made from the chuck roast and they will need to be cooked to about 185 or so. From my research, it seems that most of them are chuck and will take 4-5 hours of smoky heat to tenderize them but I did want to caution you to make sure.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Smoking the Beef Country Style Ribs Place the Bradley rack on the smoker grate or place the meat directly on the smoker grate and let the smoking begin.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Smoking the Beef Country Style Ribs Be sure to use a digital probe meat thermometer to monitor the temperature.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Smoking the Beef Country Style Ribs When the meat reaches about 135 °F (about 1 to 1.5 hours), check it for tenderness by sticking a toothpick or thermometer probe into it. If it feels tender, remove a piece of the meat and cut/taste it to see where you are as described above in the “Important Note“.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Smoking the Beef Country Style Ribs If it is done, then all is well.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Smoking the Beef Country Style Ribs If it is not done, continue to smoke cook the meat until it is tender to your liking. This can take as many as 4-5 hours in some cases.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Smoking the Beef Country Style Ribs I recommend wrapping them in foil for a couple of hours to help them tenderize more.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Sear the Outside on the Grill (optional) Once my beef ribs were done cooking in the smoker, I immediately placed them on a very hot grill to get a little sear on the outside and, in my opinion, it was worth it.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Sear the Outside on the Grill (optional) Brush some of my sauce on the outside and let them cook for about 4 minutes on each side putting them at the 2 o’clock position first for about 2 minutes then at the 10 o’clock position for a couple of minutes to get perfect 90 degree sear marks on the outside.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Sear the Outside on the Grill (optional) Flip them over and repeat the 2 and 10 position to get the good looking and tasty sear on the other side.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Serve it Up Serve the beef CSR ribs immediately.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Questions Do I have to marinate the meat? No. The marinating step is completely optional. The ribs will be good even if you don’t but I do highly recommend that you do if possible.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Questions If it becomes obvious that the meat will need longer cooking times, how long and when to wrap in foil? When the meat reaches about 160°F is a great time to wrap the meat in foil or optionally, place it in a foil pan covered with foil. Leave the meat wrapped in the foil until it reaches about 185°F or when you determine that it is tender to your liking. Then place the meat on the grill (as described above) for a few minutes to add some great flavor and color to the outside. This is also a great time to brush with some sauce if you so desire.
65fb37da-4de2-4119-8c8a-6583b432b951 Questions How do you recommend serving the meat? I have been known to just give each person an entire “rib” but I also like to slice it thin and place it on top of a vegetable salad.
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Season the Bacon Peel the bacon apart
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Season the Bacon Layer it into a lidded container and drizzle maple syrup and rub between each layer.
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Season the Bacon Spread the syrup out with a brush before sprinkling on the rub.
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Marinate the Bacon Overnight Once all of the bacon is layered into the container with maple syrup and rub, cover it and place it in the fridge overnight to marinate.
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Prepare the Bacon for Smoking To smoke the bacon and turn it into bacon candy, lay it on a jerky rack or onto bradley racks. Be sure to leave a little space between each piece to allow the smoke easy access and to make sure they don’t stick together.
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Prepare the Bacon for Smoking Sprinkle more rub and brown sugar onto the bacon just before it goes into the smoker
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Get the Smoker Ready Prepare your smoker for cooking at about 225°F with indirect heat.
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Get the Smoker Ready Let the smoker heat up to 225°F before placing the bacon in the smoker.
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Get the Smoker Ready If you need further help with your smoker, try one of these links:
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Smoke the Bacon Candy Place the bacon into the smoker and let it smoke away for about 1 hour over indirect heat.
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Smoke the Bacon Candy At the end of an hour, take it out of the smoker and flip the bacon pieces over to the other side. Once again, make sure the pieces do not touch.
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Smoke the Bacon Candy Brush on more maple syrup and brown sugar
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Smoke the Bacon Candy Smoke for an additional hour
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Smoke the Bacon Candy Remove to parchment paper right away and let it cool for about 30 minutes before eating it for best results.
9ca9386a-62d4-418b-a340-eff6c7284573 Smoke the Bacon Candy Break the bacon up into 3rds or halves and let the frenzy begin!
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Rinse and Cleanup the Ribs Remove the beef back ribs from the packaging and give them a good rinse under cold water.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Rinse and Cleanup the Ribs Lay the ribs on the cutting board and remove any large clumps of fat.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Rinse and Cleanup the Ribs Turn the rack of beef ribs over and remove the membrane on the boney side
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Rinse and Cleanup the Ribs Get ahold of the thick layer of plastic-like membrane by prying up on it with your finger, a butter knife or whatever works best for you.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Rinse and Cleanup the Ribs Once you have it started, get ahold of it with a paper towel and pull it off.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Rinse and Cleanup the Ribs I don’t usually season the boney side of beef ribs.. just doesn’t seem to be justified but feel free to do so if you wish.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Rinse and Cleanup the Ribs Flip them over to meat side up and proceed with the seasoning process.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Season/Marinate the Beef Ribs Overnight Please note that you can apply the mustard and rub right before the ribs go into the smoker and it will be fine but if you have time to do this the night before and let them marinate in the rub for several hours, the ribs will be even better.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Season/Marinate the Beef Ribs Overnight Apply some yellow mustard to the meat side of the beef ribs.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Season/Marinate the Beef Ribs Overnight Rub the mustard into the ribs with your hands and don’t forget the sides and any crevices down between the rib bones.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Season/Marinate the Beef Ribs Overnight Put a tablespoon or two of Jeff’s original rub onto the meaty side of the ribs and massage it in with the mustard to create a paste that is extremely flavorful. This paste not only tastes amazing, but it creates the perfect crust on the outside of the ribs.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Season/Marinate the Beef Ribs Overnight Wrap the ribs in plastic wrap and place them in the fridge overnight or for at least 4 hours to allow some of the flavor of the rub to get into the top layer of the meat.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Season/Marinate the Beef Ribs Overnight Note: I recommend placing the wrapped ribs into a cookie sheet or pan to prevent any runaway leaks.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Season/Marinate the Beef Ribs Overnight The next morning, remove the ribs from the fridge, unwrap them from the plastic and lay them in a Bradley rack or cookie sheet in preparation for transporting them out to the smoker.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Get the Smoker Ready Prepare your smoker for cooking at about 225°F with indirect heat.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Get the Smoker Ready If your smoker has one, fill the water pan with water .
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Get the Smoker Ready Let the smoker heat up to 225 °F before placing the meat in the smoker.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Smoke the Beef Back Ribs Place the Bradley rack in the smoker or lay the beef back ribs directly on the smoker grate bone side down.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Smoke the Beef Back Ribs I recommend a good hearty smoke like mesquite, hickory or pecan but you can use any smoking wood that you have available and they will be fine.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Smoke the Beef Back Ribs I like to apply smoke for the entire time to replicate the flavor of a wood burning smoker but if you do not like a more subtle smoke flavor, it is ok to smoke them for less time and finish with just heat.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Smoke the Beef Back Ribs Let the beef ribs cook until they are tender. (This usually happens at around 185-190 °F and can take anywhere from 4-6 hours or even more depending on variables such as weather, how often you raise/open the lid, and the starting meat temperature.
ad4e10e9-8248-4be8-b99d-dc02170aed67 Slice and Serve Let the smoked beef back ribs rest for about 10 minutes, then slice them up and serve to your family and guests.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Make the Brine Solution Put ¼ cup of kosher salt and 1 tablespoon of Jeff’s rub (purchase recipes here) in a plastic, glass or other non-reactive container.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Make the Brine Solution Pour 1 quart of apple juice over the salt and rub and mix well.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Make the Brine Solution Note: The salt will dissolve, the rub will not.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Make the Brine Solution Set the brine aside while you get the tenderloins ready.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Trim the Tenderloins Most packages of pork tenderloins include (2) of them.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Trim the Tenderloins Remove them from the package, rinse them with cold water and pat them dry with a paper towel.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Trim the Tenderloins To help make sure they cook evenly, trim off the tails and anything that looks irregular so that the ends are square and the thickness is consistent from end to end.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Trim the Tenderloins The pieces trimmed off are seasoned like everything else and cooked separately. Chef’s treats!
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Trim the Tenderloins The tenderloins are then placed into a plastic bowl, zip top bag or other brining container.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Trim the Tenderloins Cover the tenderloins with the apple juice brine that you made earlier then place a lid on the container and put it in the fridge for at least 4 hours but I recommend overnight.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Trim the Tenderloins Once the pork tenderloins are finished brining, remove them from the brine and rinse them really well under cold water. This removes any excess salt that might have accumulated on the outside of the meat.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Seasoning the Pork Tenderloins Apply a little yellow mustard and about a teaspoon of rub per tenderloin. Rub it all in together to create a nice paste on the outside of the meat.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Making the Pork Tenderloins Round This is optional but I do highly recommend it as it affects the finished product in a big way.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Making the Pork Tenderloins Round You will notice that the tenderloins are sort of oblong and flat on the top and bottom.. we want them to be round so that they will cook more evenly and make better looking slices on the plate.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Making the Pork Tenderloins Round This is easy to do using butchers twine about every 2 inches along the meat.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Making the Pork Tenderloins Round Lay the pork tenderloins on a smoking plank but you can also use a Bradley rack or you can place them directly on the smoker grate if you want to.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Making the Pork Tenderloins Round The plank does not infuse as much smoke into the meat as it does on a grill due to the lower temperature but it does make a great presentation.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Making the Pork Tenderloins Round Leave the tied up tenderloins on the counter while you go get the smoker ready.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Get the Smoker Ready Prepare your smoker for cooking at about 225°F with indirect heat.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Get the Smoker Ready Fill the water pan with water if your smoker has one and have enough smoking wood (apple recommended) to last about 1.5 to 2 hours.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Get the Smoker Ready Let the smoker preheat to 225 °F before placing the meat in the smoker.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Smoke the Pork Tenderloins Place the pork tenderloins in the smoker directly on the grate or use a plank or Bradley rack as mentioned earlier.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Smoke the Pork Tenderloins Keep the smoke going the entire time if possible and let the pork cook until it reaches an internal temperature of 145 °F in the center of the meat as measured by a digital probe meat thermometer.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Smoke the Pork Tenderloins Note: spray the outside surface of the meat with apple juice about every 30 minutes but do it quickly to minimize heat loss. If your smoker has a difficult time recovering when opened, you should probably skip this step.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Smoke the Pork Tenderloins Serve it Up
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Smoke the Pork Tenderloins When the pork reaches 145 °F, remove it from the smoker and let it sit for about 10 minutes before slicing.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Smoke the Pork Tenderloins Be sure to remove the butcher’s twine.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Apple Barbecue Sauce Make a batch of apple barbecue sauce by mixing equal parts of Jeff’s barbecue sauce with apple juice.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Apple Barbecue Sauce I used 1/3 cup of apple juice and 1/3 cup of barbecue sauce.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Notes/Comments: These are great as an entree with a couple of vegetables but they also work well as a slider.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Notes/Comments: Use apple sauce instead of mustard as a base for the rub to switch things up.
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Notes/Comments: Do not overcook the pork. The USDA now says that 145 °F is completely safe for whole cuts of pork (unground).
a97decb8-c97d-4341-9927-1e42a9d649e7 Notes/Comments: Since the pork is brined, be sure to use a rub like mine that has very little salt. If you use a store-bought rub it will probably be way too salty.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Saute the Vegetables Place the 2 TBS of butter into a large pan or skillet over medium heat.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Saute the Vegetables Let the butter melt.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Saute the Vegetables Add the green onions, celery, carrots, onions, and garlic to the melted butter. Let it cook for about 4-6 minutes stirring occasionally.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Saute the Vegetables Once the carrots get slightly soft, (won’t take long if you grated them) add the 1/3 cup of Jeff’s barbecue sauce to the vegetables and mix together well.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Saute the Vegetables Note: After about 4 minutes, if the carrots are not soft, cover the vegetables with a lid for a couple of minutes to help speed things along.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Saute the Vegetables Set the vegetable/sauce mixture aside to cool for about 10-15 minutes. It will need to be room temperature or less before adding it to the meat.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Mix the Meatloaf Together Place 1.5 lbs of ground chuck (80/20) and ¾ lb of ground breakfast sausage (Hot) into a large mixing bowl.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Mix the Meatloaf Together Add the slightly beaten eggs, bread crumbs, chopped parsley, Jeff’s rub, and sautéed vegetables to the mixing bowl and mix the meat and other ingredients together until combined.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Mix the Meatloaf Together After it’s mixed well, form into a loaf and set it out on the cutting board.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Form the Meatloaf into Muffins and Refrigerate Separate the loaf into 6 equal portions and place each portion into an area of the large size muffin pan.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Form the Meatloaf into Muffins and Refrigerate Press the meat into place and flatten the top.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Form the Meatloaf into Muffins and Refrigerate Cover the top of the muffin pan with plastic wrap and place in the fridge for at least 2 hours or overnight to firm it up.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Remove Meatloaf Muffins from Pan After 2 hours or the next morning, remove the muffins from the muffin pan and arrange them on a Bradley rack or cookie sheet.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Remove Meatloaf Muffins from Pan Note: if you have trouble getting them out, use a butter knife along the sides to help loosen them up. You could also line each hole with foil or wax paper to make it easier to get the meatloaf out.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Setup the Smoker Setup your smoker or cooker for cooking indirect at about 225°F using your electric, charcoal, gas or wood smoker.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Setup the Smoker If your smoker came with a water pan, be sure to use it.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Smoke the Beef and Pork Meatloaf Place the meatloaf muffins into the smoker directly on the smoker grate or to make it easy, use the Bradley rack and just lay the entire rack on the smoker grate.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Smoke the Beef and Pork Meatloaf Maintain 225 °F of the entire time and keep the smoke going for at least 1 hour but for better smoke flavor, just keep the smoke going for the entire time.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Smoke the Beef and Pork Meatloaf About 30 minutes before the meatloaf is finished or at about 150°F, brush a layer of Jeff’s barbecue sauce (purchase recipes here) all over the top and sides of the meatloaf muffins.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Smoke the Beef and Pork Meatloaf The meatloaf is done when it reaches 160 °F in the center.
523e6854-a49d-4ed0-813f-dba8afbc8bb9 Serve it Up When the meatloaf is done cooking, serve immediately with mashed potatoes, corn, mixes vegetables, etc.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Pounding Out the Chicken Lay the chicken on a piece of plastic wrap then cover it with another piece of plastic wrap. This is to keep the mess to a minimum.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Pounding Out the Chicken Use a meat hammer or other heavy object to pound the chicken breast a little bit.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Seasoning the Chicken Breasts Brush or spoon a little olive oil onto the chicken breasts and sprinkle a generous amount of Jeff’s Rub onto the top and bottom of the chicken breasts.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Marinading the Chicken Overnight Once seasoned, place the chicken breasts into a ziptop bag, press out the air and place the bag into the fridge overnight or for at least 4 hours.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Marinading the Chicken Overnight After 4 hours or the next morning, remove the chicken breasts from the fridge and place them on a Bradley rack or cookie sheet to make it easy to transport them out to the grill or smoker.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Gas Grill Light 1 or 2 of the burners on a gas grill and leave 1 or 2 of the burners unlit (3-4 burner gas grills)
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Gas Grill Place wood chips or chunks wrapped in foil over the flame to create smoke.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Gas Grill Maintain 225°F by manipulating the setting of the burners on the hot side.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Gas Grill Place the chicken breasts on the cool side of the grill for about 45 minutes or until they reach about 125°F.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Gas Grill Sauce both sides of the chicken with my beer bbq sauce recipe (½ cup of Jeff's barbecue sauce and ½ cup of beer mixed together well)
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Gas Grill Keep the smoke going for the entire time to ensure great smoked flavor.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Gas Grill After 45 minutes or 125°F move the chicken breast to the hot side of the grill.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Gas Grill Turn the grill to high heat and cook for an additional 7 minutes on each side or until the chicken reaches 165 °F in the center as measured by a meat thermometer.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Charcoal Grill For a charcoal grill, you use the same basic concept, using charcoal.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Charcoal Grill Place an aluminum pan in the center of the grill filled with water.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Charcoal Grill Pile the charcoal on both sides to create hot zones on the sides with a cooler center.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Charcoal Grill You can also just pile all of the charcoal on one side of the grill with a water pan on the other side and get the same effect.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Charcoal Grill Lay wood chunks on the charcoal or very near the charcoal to get some smoking action.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Charcoal Grill Place the chicken breasts on the cool zone of the grill for about 45 minutes or until they reach about 125°F.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Charcoal Grill Sauce both sides of the chicken with my beer bbq sauce recipe (½ cup of Jeff's barbecue sauce and ½ cup of beer mixed together well)
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Charcoal Grill Keep the smoke going for the entire time to ensure great smoked flavor.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Charcoal Grill After 45 minutes or 125°F move the chicken breast to the hot zone of the charcoal grill.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cook The Chicken Breast on the Charcoal Grill Cook for an additional 5-7 minutes on each side or until the chicken reaches 165 °F in the center as measured by a meat thermometer.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cooking the Chicken Breasts in the Smoker Place the chicken breasts directly on the smoker grate.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cooking the Chicken Breasts in the Smoker Smoke the chicken for about 1.5 hours (depending on thickness) or until it reaches 165°F.
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cooking the Chicken Breasts in the Smoker About 20 minutes before it gets finished, sauce both sides of the chicken with my beer bbq sauce recipe (½ cup of Jeff's barbecue sauce and ½ cup of beer mixed together well)
db5a5548-f279-457c-a2cb-46f50309429b Cooking the Chicken Breasts in the Smoker Serve immediately!
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 St. Louis Style Trimming I found these ribs already trimmed and membrane removed and they were at a great price. If you have regular spare ribs, you will need to remove the membrane and trim off the bone on leading edge so that you are only left with actual ribs.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Season the Ribs Brush some oil onto each side of the ribs to help the rub to stick. I often use mustard, honey, and an assortment of other things as well to serve this purpose.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Season the Ribs Apply Jeff’s rub (purchase recipes here) to the ribs generously.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Season the Ribs Wait until it has that “wet” look, flip the ribs over and apply oil and rub to the meaty side.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Season the Ribs Once both sides are oiled and rubbed with Jeff’s rub, my original naked rib rub recipe, wrap the ribs in plastic wrap and allow to marinate for 8-10 hours in the fridge.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Season the Ribs The next morning, pull the ribs out of the fridge and remove the plastic.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Making the Butter Injection Make the butter injection right before you pull the ribs out of the fridge.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Making the Butter Injection Run about a cup of my rub through the coffee grinder to powder it. This helps it to not get stuck in the small holes in the injector.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Making the Butter Injection Mix a heaping tablespoon of the powdered rub into a stick (¼ lb) of melted butter and mix thoroughly.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Inject the Ribs Lay the marinated ribs on a piece of plastic wrap then cover the ribs with a piece of plastic wrap. This prevents the butter from becoming a geyser that can shoot across the kitchen suddenly.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Inject the Ribs Fill the injector with hot melted spicy butter and push the needle into the meat between each bone so that the tip is about 1 inch into the meat.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Inject the Ribs Depress the plunger as you move the needle left and right at different angles to ensure that the butter is getting in there real good.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Inject the Ribs Slowly pull it out as you continue to depress the plunger.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Inject the Ribs Keep injecting butter until you see it seeping out somewhere.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Inject the Ribs Flip the ribs around and do the same on the opposite edge at about 1 inch into the meat.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Inject the Ribs If you need more butter, make another batch so you don’t have to scrimp on it. Give it all it will take!
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Rub it Down Again Spread the butter that seeped out all over the top of the ribs and sprinkle on a little more of my rub.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Get the Smoker Ready to Smoke Pre-heat your smoker to between 225 and 240°F and make sure you have at least 3-4 hours of smoking wood available.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Smoking the St. Louis Style Spare Ribs I wanted to use a Bradley rack (I love those things in case you haven’t noticed) so I cut the rack of spare ribs in half as you’ll notice above. This makes them very easy to maneuver, flip over, wrap, etc.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Smoking the St. Louis Style Spare Ribs Place the ribs on the smoker grate bone side down and let the smoking begin!
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 The 4-1-1 Style Spare Rib Cooking Method
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Step One Place the ribs on the smoker bone side down, as mentioned above, and let them smoke their little porky hearts out for about 4 hours at 225°F.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Step Two Wrap the ribs in a double layer of heavy duty foil, not real tight but tight enough so they can steam real nice inside and find their tender side.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Step Two Place the wrapped ribs back into the smoker for 1 hour at the same exact temperature.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Step Three After the ribs have tenderized for 1 hour, remove the foil and place the ribs back into the smoker, just like in step one, for one additional hour. This additional hour, resets the crust, brings a little more color to the outside of the ribs and can even give them an extra bit of smoke should you choose to add smoke during this time.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Serving the Smoked Spare Ribs When the ribs are finished, bring them in, let them rest for about 10 minutes then slice them up.
dde5c356-d4e2-42b5-a4bb-461a01335027 Serving the Smoked Spare Ribs I recommend placing them bone side up to slice since that allows you to see the direction of the bones making it easy to slice between them.
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Precook Some Bacon Lay bacon into a flat cookie sheet then place another cookie sheet on top of that to hold the bacon flat while it cooks.
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Precook Some Bacon Cook bacon until is about 75% done and is still flexible enough to wrap around the salmon filets.
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Make the Round Filets Lay the salmon filet on your cutting board.
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Make the Round Filets Pull out any pin bones that you find using a clean pair of needle nosed pliers or tweezers.
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Make the Round Filets To find the pin bones, simply run your fingers along the fish and you'll feel the little bones sticking up just above the flesh. They are usually located right along the side of the thickest part of the fish.
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Make the Round Filets Cut the fish into strips width wise. Use a piece of bacon to measure how wide it needs to be.
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Make the Round Filets Once the strips are cut, use a sharp knife to remove the skin from each piece.
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Make the Round Filets Roll (2) pieces in a plate of Jeff's rub to coat
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Make the Round Filets Lay the pieces on top of each other. Thick part on top of the thin part of the fish.
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Make the Round Filets Roll it together to form a circle.
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Make the Round Filets While holding it securely, wrap a piece of bacon around it and secure with a toothpick or a piece of butchers twine.
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Smoke the Filet Mignon of Salmon Set up your electric, charcoal, gas or wood smoker for about an hours worth of cooking at 225-240°F and a nice fruit wood or something that is not too strong such as alder, cherry, apple, pecan, etc.
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Smoke the Filet Mignon of Salmon Place the salmon filets on the smoker grate and let them smoke cook for about 1 hour or until they reach 145 °F in the center.
32c62024-77ca-4ff7-aeab-af36e0643554 Serve the Smoked Filet Mignon of Salmon Just as soon as the salmon is finished cooking, serve them immediately for best results.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Remove the Skin from the Chicken Quarters Get a good hold on skin at the larger thigh end and pull it toward the leg and it will come clean off.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Parboil the Carrots and Potatoes Fill a pot with your potatoes and carrots and cover them with water. Bring the water to a boil and let it boil for about 5 minutes for small carrots and potatoes.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Parboil the Carrots and Potatoes Pour the potatoes and carrots into a colander and run cold water over them to stop the cooking process.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Prepare the Foil Packages Place the skinned chicken onto the center of a piece of foil that is about 18x18 inches square.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Prepare the Foil Packages Pile some sausage pieces, potatoes, carrots, a quarter of an onion and a half ear of corn around the chicken.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Prepare the Foil Packages Sprinkle some of my Texas style rub (recipe included when you purchase the recipes for my original rub and sauce) onto the chicken, sausage and vegetables.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Prepare the Foil Packages Now sprinkle about 2-3 tablespoons of Jeff's original rub onto the top of everything for amazing flavor.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Prepare the Foil Packages Add a tablespoon of butter on top..
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Prepare the Foil Packages Roll up the edges of the foil around the meat and vegetables to form a bowl shape.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Prepare the Foil Packages Be sure to leave it open for now to allow the smoke in
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Smoke the Campfire Chicken Set up your smoker for cooking at about 240°F although it would not be unheard of to take it on up to 275°F or so if you need to get them done faster. Chicken handles high heat quite well.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Smoke the Campfire Chicken Be sure to have enough Pecan or other smoking wood for about 1 hour of smoke.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Smoke the Campfire Chicken Place the foil "bowls" of chicken, sausage and vegetables into the smoker and let them smoke away for about 1 hour.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Smoke the Campfire Chicken After one hour, pull the foil together at the top and pinch it closed.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Smoke the Campfire Chicken Place a probe from a digital probe meat thermometer into one of the pieces of chicken before closing it up so you will know when it is done.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Smoke the Campfire Chicken I shoot for 170°F on these.
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Serve it Up Have plates already setting on the table with a single paper towel on the plate (to protect the plate from grease from the smoker grates)
7e34df36-d8d2-4d85-a52b-46219c23f913 Serve it Up When the chicken is done, lay a foil packet on each plate and call Dinner!
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Make the Burger Dogs Separate the ground chuck into pieces that are about ¼ lb each and, without overworking the meat, make a ball out of one of those ¼ lb pieces.
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Make the Burger Dogs Lay the ball on a piece of wax paper and carefully form it into a patty that is about 4-5 inches in diameter.
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Make the Burger Dogs Lay 2 hotdogs on top of the burger patty with a little space between them.
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Make the Burger Dogs Sprinkle shredded cheese on top of the hot dogs
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Make the Burger Dogs Add a nice healthy portion of my rub for amazing flavor
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Make the Burger Dogs Top it with another patty made exactly like the first one
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Make the Burger Dogs Pinch the edges together to seal in all the goodness
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Make the Burger Dogs Season the top of the burgers with Jeff's rub or a mixture of Pepper and salt
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Make the Burger Dogs Place the burgers onto a Bradley rack and you are ready to smoke 'em!
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Make the Burger Dogs If you want more smoked burger dogs, double, triple or even quadruple the recipe.
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Smoking the Burger Dogs Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225 °F and be sure to have enough smoking wood to keep the smoke going for at least an hour but I recommend letting the smoke go the entire time.
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Smoking the Burger Dogs Place the burger dogs directly on the grate or if you used a Bradley rack, place the rack on the smoker grate.
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Smoking the Burger Dogs Let the burgers cook until they reach an internal temperature of 160°F
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Serve the Burger Dogs Put the burger dogs on a toasted bun heaped with lettuce, tomatoes, onions, bacon and your favorite condiments.
3c6c0d80-3979-410c-b3c5-fa9e2f5e5323 Serve the Burger Dogs Eat and enjoy!
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Remove the Skin on Pork Picnic Roast (optional) Lay the roast on the cutting board skin side up.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Remove the Skin on Pork Picnic Roast (optional) Make a cut through the skin right down the center as shown.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Remove the Skin on Pork Picnic Roast (optional) While pulling up and away from the center, run the blade of a sharp knife along the attached skin.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Remove the Skin on Pork Picnic Roast (optional) Turn the roast over to finish removing the skin.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Mustard and Rub the Pork Spread mustard all over the meat.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Mustard and Rub the Pork Sprinkle about ¼ cup of rub all over the top of the roast then rub it in so that it mixes with the mustard.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Mustard and Rub the Pork Flip the roast over and get the bottom side the same way.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Ready the Smoker Set up the smoker for cooking at 225 °F and make sure you have plenty of smoking wood for the long haul. If you are using an electric, charcoal or gas smoker, I recommend having enough wood chips, chunks or splits for about 6-8 hours of smoke.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Ready the Smoker Once the smoker is running steady at the prescribed temperature, it is time to put the meat on the smoker grate.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Smoking the Pork Roast Place the pork butt directly on the smoker grate fat side down.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Smoking the Pork Roast Keep the cherry wood smoke going for 6-8 hours if possible.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Smoking the Pork Roast I recommend using a meat thermometer for the most failsafe way to tell when the meat is done. Once you’ve cooked a few and you want to start experimenting with the guess work, go for it.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Smoking the Pork Roast I like to leave the pork butt open and on the smoker grate for the entire time but if you want to speed things up somewhat, you can wrap it in foil once it reaches 160°F. Once you wrap it, no more smoke is required and it can even be moved to the kitchen oven at 225°F if you want to.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Smoking the Pork Roast When the pork butt reaches 200-205 in the very center, it is done.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Resting the Pork Butt Place the wrapped bundle into an empty ice cooler and fill in any remaining space with more towels, small blankets or pillows.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Resting the Pork Butt Hold for up to 4h ours if desired or it can be used immediately.
bd1f449a-371d-433d-8c05-2d63ade01c48 Pulling the Pork Use a couple of forks to pull or shred the meat removing any clumps of fat that you find.
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Season up the Chicken Wings Rinse the chicken wings under cold water then pat them dry with a paper towel
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Season up the Chicken Wings Put the raw chicken wings into a large ziptop bag and pour in about ¼ cup of olive oil.
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Season up the Chicken Wings Add about ½ cup of Jeff's rub (per 3 lbs of chicken wings) to the bag.
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Season up the Chicken Wings Close the bag and shake, rattle, and roll the bag to allow the rub to coat all of the chicken.
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Marinate Chicken Wings Overnight Place the bag of wings into a pan of some sort to ensure that they do not leak and then into the fridge to keep them cold.
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Marinate Chicken Wings Overnight Allow them to marinate in the fridge overnight or for 6-8 hours for best results.
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Marinate Chicken Wings Overnight The next morning or when you are ready to smoke the chicken wings, remove the bag of wings from the fridge and pour them into a pan so you can easily place them onto the smoker.
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Smoking the Chicken Wings Set up your smoker for cooking at 225 °F with pecan wood if possible (it’s awesome on these smoked chicken wings!).
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Smoking the Chicken Wings Smoke the wings with indirect heat and leave the water pan dry to give the skin a better texture with less humidity.
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Smoking the Chicken Wings Use pecan wood if you have it and maintain 225 -230 °F for about 1.5 to 2 hours.
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Smoking the Chicken Wings About 30 minutes before the wings are done cooking, brush the honey and beer barbecue sauce (recipe below) onto the tops of the chicken wings.
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Smoking the Chicken Wings Let them cook for another 10 minutes then flip them over and repeat on the other side.
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Smoking the Chicken Wings Cook the chicken until it measures 165°F as measured by a tested digital probe meat thermometer.
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Making the Beer and Honey Barbecue Sauce Combine 1 cup of Jeff’s barbecue sauce, 2 TBS of honey and ½ cup of beer until it is well mixed.
cee360d7-dc32-4440-adbe-8584c8a82aa5 Making the Beer and Honey Barbecue Sauce Enjoy!
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Remove Membrane Lay the ribs bone side up on a flat surface.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Remove Membrane Work your fingers or other semi-sharp object under the membrane in the center of the rack of ribs and pull upward. With a little practice, the entire membrane will pull off in one piece.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Season the Ribs with Jeff’s Rub Coat both sides of the ribs with yellow mustard.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Season the Ribs with Jeff’s Rub Apply the mustard to the bone side first, then generously apply the original rub.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Season the Ribs with Jeff’s Rub Wait about 5 minutes or so for the rub to start looking wet.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Season the Ribs with Jeff’s Rub Turn the ribs over and apply mustard and then rub to the meaty side of the ribs.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Season the Ribs with Jeff’s Rub Then apply the rub very generously to the top of the ribs.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Season the Ribs with Jeff’s Rub Let them sit for about 5-10 minutes while the rub mixes with the mustard and rib juices to form a really nice paste.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Refrigerate the Pork Ribs Overnight Once they are seasoned well, lay the ribs on a piece of plastic wrap and wrap them up nice and tight.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Refrigerate the Pork Ribs Overnight Place the wrapped ribs in a pan (to prevent possible leaks) and put them in the fridge overnight.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Refrigerate the Pork Ribs Overnight The next morning, remove the ribs from the fridge and unwrap them.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Refrigerate the Pork Ribs Overnight Leave them on the counter for a few minutes while you go get the smoker ready.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Ready the Smokers Set up your smoker for cooking at about 225°F.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Ready the Smokers Make sure to have enough smoking wood to last about 2-3 hours. Mesquite mixed with equal parts of apple is a great combination but any smoking wood will work.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Ready the Smokers Once your smoker is set up and ready to go, the ribs are ready to go into the smoker.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Smoke the Ribs Place the ribs directly on the smoker grate
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Smoke the Ribs Let them smoke for about 2 hours.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Smoke the Ribs After 2 hours, remove them from the smoker with a spatula or something that does not disturb the rub and place them on a long sheet of heavy duty foil (I use a 30-inch piece).
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Smoke the Ribs Sprinkle extra rub on the top of the ribs and wrap them up individually.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Smoke the Ribs Place the wrapped ribs back into the smoker at 225°F.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Smoke the Ribs After 2 hours, remove the wrapped ribs from the smoker and take them carefully from the foil. Be careful when you open them up, they will be very hot and the steam and rib juices in the bottom of the foil will be very hot.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Smoke the Ribs Sprinkle them once again with more rub on the top side and place them back onto the smoker grate for 1 hour.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Smoke the Ribs After the single hour, they are done and ready to come into the house
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Remove the Bones Lay the racks of ribs bone side up on the cutting board and very carefully twist the bones while pulling upward to separate them from the meat. Making a cut along both sides of the bone helps if they are a little stubborn.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Remove the Bones Note: there are sometimes some small bone pieces in the more narrow tip of the baby backs. Be sure to check for those.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Make the Smoked Baby Back Rib Sandwich Brush a little melted butter onto the inside of the bread and give it a good toasting in the oven or grill.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Make the Smoked Baby Back Rib Sandwich Lay the entire rack of ribs onto the top of the bread using a long wide knife or something similar underneath to keep the super tender ribs from breaking into pieces.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Make the Smoked Baby Back Rib Sandwich Top the ribs with Jeff’s BBQ sauce to add yet another layer of flavor.
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Make the Smoked Baby Back Rib Sandwich Top the sandwich
fc172d7d-1ab7-44de-bc00-c3f6da8612a3 Make the Smoked Baby Back Rib Sandwich Serve Immediately
3f9de9ca-2ac8-472c-b969-a2dbd071ef43 Prepare the Shrimp If the shrimp are frozen, place them in a colander and run cold water over them for a few minutes until they are thawed.
3f9de9ca-2ac8-472c-b969-a2dbd071ef43 Prepare the Shrimp Place the shrimp on a cookie sheet or flat surface and sprinkle my rub all over them.
3f9de9ca-2ac8-472c-b969-a2dbd071ef43 Prepare the Sausage Cut up the smoked sausage into circles that are about ½ inch thick
3f9de9ca-2ac8-472c-b969-a2dbd071ef43 Piggy Meet Shrimp Place the shrimp onto a flat surface and lay a sausage round right in the center of the natural “C” the body of the shrimp makes.
3f9de9ca-2ac8-472c-b969-a2dbd071ef43 Piggy Meet Shrimp Push a toothpick through the shrimp, through the sausage and through the shrimp again to hold it all together nicely.
3f9de9ca-2ac8-472c-b969-a2dbd071ef43 Piggy Meet Shrimp Repeat this process on all of the shrimp and sausage.
3f9de9ca-2ac8-472c-b969-a2dbd071ef43 Smoke the Appetizers Setup the smoker for cooking low and slow at about 225°F.
3f9de9ca-2ac8-472c-b969-a2dbd071ef43 Smoke the Appetizers Place the shrimp and sausage appetizers directly onto the smoker grate for about 30 minutes
3f9de9ca-2ac8-472c-b969-a2dbd071ef43 Smoke the Appetizers They will turn from grey to a pinkish color and the meat changes from translucent to opaque when they are done cooking
3f9de9ca-2ac8-472c-b969-a2dbd071ef43 Smoke the Appetizers Use mesquite so you can get plenty of good robust smoke flavor on the shrimp and sausage in a very short period of time.
